translation: Of the mighty [baḍavāyāḥ], the ocean-residing (samudrasthitāyāḥ) Ghoṭaka is the mouth (mukhastho) of the fire [agniḥ]. Also, there is a fire (agniḥ) located at the ocean (samudrasthā).

sloka: jaṭharasthito'gniḥ | kaukṣeye annādipācake vahnau “annarasojaṭharāgninā pacyamānoraktatāṃ pratipadyate”|
translation: The fire within the stomach, and the fire that cooks food in the hearth, are both kindled from the same "fire of digestion," which causes the transformation of food into nutrients.

sloka: agnirvaiśvānaro vahnirvītihotro dhanaṃjayaḥ | kṛpīṭayonirjvalano jātavedāstanūnapāt || barhiḥ śuṣmā kṛṣṇavartmā śociṣkeśa uṣarbudhaḥ | āśayāśo bṛhdabhānuḥ kṛśānuḥ pāvakonalaḥ || rohitāśvo vāyusakhaḥ śikhāvānāśuśukṣaṇiḥ | hiraṇyaretā hutabhugdahano havyavāhanaḥ || saptārcirdamunāḥ śukraścitrabhānurvibhāvasuḥ | śucirappittamaurvastu vāḍavo vaḍavānalaḥ || vahnerdvayorjvālakilāvarcirhetiḥ śikhā striyām | triṣu sphuliṅgognikaṇaḥ saṃtāpaḥ saṃjvaraḥ samau
translation: Agni is Vaishvanara, the fire and Vithotra, wealth-giver; Krityayoni is fiery and Jatala, born of purified water; Barhishu is Susma, dark path, Usharbudha, sharp-rayed, Ashayaasho is Bhrudabhanuh, large and bright, Krisanu is Pavaka, golden-handed, Havyavahana, carrier of oblations. Roheetasva is Vayusakha, friend of wind; Shikhavan is Asushukshani, having tufted mane; Hiranyareta is Hutabhugda, gold-spermed, consumer of sacrificial offerings. Saptarcis is Damunah, seven-rayed, Sukrashcitrabhanur, bright and variegated, Vibhavasu, shining, Suci is Appittamaurgastu, purest and greatest; Vaadava is Vaadavanalah, blower of the fire. The two flames of the fire are circled by the striya hairs (of the sacrificial animal); the sparks are in three places, causing heat, fever and burning.

sloka: haviḥ prakṣepādhikaraṇeṣu gārhapatyāhavanīyadakṣiṇāgnisabhyāvasathyaupāsanākhyeṣu ṣaḍgniṣu |
translation: In the installation of the sacrificial offerings, namely in the Garhapatya, Ahavaniya, Dakshina, Agni, Sabhya, and Upaśad fires.

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: Prajapati, initially alone, considered, "How will I propagate offspring?" After practicing austerities, he created fire from his own mouth. Hence, Agni (fire) is born from his mouth.

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: With Agni as his head, the eyes are the sun and moon, the directions are surrounded by speech, the Vedas are the ears, space is the voice, and the life force is the wind. The whole universe has its origin in the two feet, and the earth is its firm foundation; it is the inner self of all beings and resides in the banyan tree and the peepal tree, which are known as Ashvattha and Shamī. Having understood this, one should perform the ritual of making two firewood pieces (dve arani) with the intention of fulfilling desires through the Urvaśi loka (celestial world).

sloka: ityuktvā niḥsṛto'śvatthādagnirvāraṇasūcitaḥ| praviveśa śamīgarbhamatha vahniḥ suṣupsayā||
translation: Saying this, fire departed from the ashvattha tree and entered the śamī tree, thus consuming it with its flames.

sloka: kravyādamagniṃ pra hiṇomi dūraṃ yamarājño gacchatu ripravāhaḥ | ihaivāyamitaro jātavedā devebhyo havyaṃ vahatu prajānan ||
translation: I place far the sacrificial fire of Kravyada, let the enemy of Yama depart from here. May this born today, Jatavedas, carry the oblation to the gods, being known to them.

sloka: jātavedase sunavāma somamarātīyato nidahāti vedaḥ | sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ ||
translation: We offer our oblations to Jātavedas, theconsumer of soma; he expounds the Vedas and dispels darkness. May that fire of ours skillfully overcome all difficult paths and never abandon us like a river does.

sloka: purā kalpe mahākāle prapanne lokaviśrute āyudhyetāṃ mahātmānau brahmaviṣṇū parasparam tayormānaṃ nirākartuṃ tanmadhye parameśvaraḥ niṣkalastaṃbharūpeṇa svarūpaṃ samadarśayat tataḥ svaliṃgacihnatvātstaṃbhato niṣkalaṃ śivaḥ svaliṃgaṃ darśayāmāsa jagatāṃ hitakāmyayā
translation: In a previous age, at the end of the world renowned, two great souls, Brahma and Vishnu, began to fight to determine who was superior. To resolve this, the undifferentiated form of the supreme lord Parameshvara revealed his true form between them. Then, in order to benefit the world, the formless Shiva revealed his linga form.

sloka: yatra jāto mahātejāḥ kārtikeyo agni saṃbhavaḥ
translation: Where Kartikeya, possessing great tejas, was born from Agni.

sloka: vā॒yurani̭lama॒mṛta॒mathe॒daṃ bhasmā̭nta॒ śarī̭ram | oṃ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra॒ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra ||
translation: "O Air, carrier of the imperishable nectar, after reducing this body to ashes, remember (your duty), I urge you, as you had done before."

sloka: pratiṣṭhāpanaṃ savidhikotsarjanamityarthaḥ |
translation: The purpose is to establish [something] along with all prescribed rituals.

sloka: prapāstaḍāgāni ca paropakārāya na dharmāyetyevāvagamyate tathā ca darśanam dhanvanniva prapā asīti tathā sthalayodakaṃ parigṛhṇantīti ca || pra te yakṣi pra ta iyarmi manma bhuvo yathā vandyo no haveṣu | dhanvanniva prapā asi tvamagna iyakṣave pūrave pratna rājan ||
translation: It is understood that (one should) extend help to others, not for the sake of Dharma, but as if (it is a natural act like) drawing water from a well or accepting alms from supporters. Just as an arrow is drawn (in readiness to shoot), so you too, O guardian of treasures, are ready to protect. O King!

sloka: bhojāyāśvaṃ saṃ mṛjantyāśuṃ bhojāyāste kanyā śumbhamānā | bhojasyedaṃ puṣkariṇīva veśma pariṣkṛtaṃ devamāneva citram ||
translation: The horse is being groomed for the Bhoja's feast, and so is the girl adorning herself; truly, this abode of the Bhoja is splendidly decorated, as if for a god.

sloka: iṣṭāpūrtau smṛtau dharmau śrutau tau śiṣṭasaṃmatau | bhuktimuktipradaṃ pūrtamiṣṭaṃ bhogārthasādhanam ||
translation: The two Smritis and Dharmas, which are remembered and heard, approved by the worthy, and established in the Srutis (Vedas), granting fulfillment and satisfaction, are the means for achieving the purpose of enjoyment.

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: Devas, humans, gandharvas, pitrs, rakshasas, and even stationary beings take refuge in the water bodies.

sloka: triṣu lokeṣu sarvatra pūjanīyastaḍāgavān|| dharmasyārthasya kāmasya phalamāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ| taḍāgasukṛtaṃ deśe kṣetramekaṃ mahāśrayam||
translation: The wise ones consider virtue, prosperity, and desire's fulfillment to be the fruits of righteousness. Everywhere in the three worlds, the self-controlled regard the field of virtuous deeds as the supreme resort.

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: Devas, humans, Gandharvas, Pitrs, Rakshasas, and even stationary beings take refuge in the water bodies.

sloka: prāvṛṭkāle tu pānīyaṃ taḍāge yasya tiṣṭhati || ||agniṣṭomaphalaṃ tasya puruṣasya prakīrtitam |
translation: At the time of the performance of the agnihotra ritual, the one who has the power to control their senses is said to be renowned.

sloka: śakralokamavāpnoti taḍāgakaraṇātpathi | marau taḍāge pānīyaṃ yasya tiṣṭhati vai dvijāḥ ||vimānenārkavarṇena brahmalokaṃ sa gacchati |
translation: One who aspires to reach the realm of Śakra (Indra's heaven) obtains it by constructing a pond (for providing water to others and animals). For him, a Brahmin always stands ready with water in his hands at the time of death, and he reaches the abode of Brahma, with a resplendent golden chariot.

sloka: atha kūpakartustatpravṛtte pānīye duṣkṛtasyārdhaṃ vinaśyati || || taḍāgakṛnnityatṛpto vāruṇaṃ lokaṃ aśnute || || jalapradaḥ sadā tṛpto bhavati || ||
translation: When a well-builder sets to work, half of his wickedness is destroyed; the tank builder who is always contented enjoys the world of water; the one who provides water is always satisfied.

sloka: devāyatanakārī yasya devasyāyatanaṃ karoti tasyaiva lokaṃ āpnoti || || sudhāsiktaṃ kṛtvā yaśasā virājate || ||vicitraṃ kṛtvā gandharvalokaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: The one who builds a dwelling for the god, only they attain worldly gains. By making it pure like nectar with fame, they also reach the fascinating realm of the gandharvas.

sloka: puṣpapradānena śrīmānbhavati || || anulepanapradānena kīrtimān || ||dīpapradānena cakṣuṣmānsarvatrojjvalaśca || ||annapradānena balavān || ||
translation: By offering flowers, one becomes prosperous; by applying sandalwood paste, one becomes famous; by lighting a lamp, one gains sharp vision and illuminates everywhere; by giving food, one becomes strong.

sloka: devanirmālyāpanayanātgodānaphalaṃ āpnoti || ||devagṛhamārjanāttadupalepanātbrāhmaṇocchiṣṭamārjanātpādaśaucādakalyaparicaraṇācca || || kūpārāmataḍāgeṣu devatāyataneṣu ca | punaḥ saṃskārakartā ca labhate maulikaṃ phalam || ||
translation: By offering garlands to the gods, one obtains the fruit of giving a cow. By cleaning and decorating the god's residence, by purifying the leftovers of brahmins, by maintaining cleanliness of feet, by serving at the appropriate times, and by performing rituals related to various deities and wells, one becomes eligible for the original reward (of being a priest in these ceremonies).

sloka: dvārībandhiṣu kartavyamutsargaṃ gopradānikam | gosahasraṃ śubhaṃ deyaṃ mahīṃ hemañca dakṣiṇām ||
translation: Among the tasks to be done, freeing the cows is a duty of the gatekeeper. Donating a thousand cows is auspicious. The earth should be given as dakshina (fee) decorated with gold.

sloka: sadā jalaṃ pavitraṃ syādapavitramasaṃskṛtam | kuśāgreṇāpi rājendra spraṣṭagyamasaṃskṛtam || vāpīkūpataḍāgadau yajjalaṃ syādasaṃskṛtam | apeyaṃ tadbhavetsarve pītvā cāndrāyaṇaṃ caret ||
translation: The water is always pure and purifying, even if contacted by a blade of kusa grass. Water from a well, tank, or river is considered impure only if it has been touched by the foot or other parts of the body. After coming into contact with such impure water, one should perform the moon-restriction .

sloka: puṣpaiḥ suragaṇān vṛkṣāḥ phalaiścāpi tathā pitṝn | chāyayā cātithiṃ tāta pūjayanti mahīruhaḥ ||
translation: Trees honor guests, O father, with shade and also with flowers and fruits.

sloka: vṛkṣāropayiturvṛkṣāḥ paraloke putrā bhavanti || ||vṛkṣaprado vṛkṣaprasūnairdevānprīṇayati || ||phalaiścātithīn || ||chāyayā cābhyāgatān || || deve varṣatyudakena pitṝn || || setukṛtsvargaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: One who plants trees becomes the father of beings in another world. One who gives fruits, welcomes guests, and provides shade and shelter to travelers, pleases the gods with his offerings of water and libations. Such a person attains heaven by building a bridge (of meritorious deeds).

sloka: sthāvarāṇāṃ ca bhūtānāṃ jātayaḥ ṣaṭ prakīrtitāḥ | vṛkṣagulmalatāvallyastvaksārāstṛṇajātayaḥ||
translation: The six types of births recognized among immobile beings are those of trees, creepers, shrubs, herbs, and grasses.

sloka: athodyāne pravakṣyāmi praśastānpādapāndvija | ariṣṭāśokapunnāgaśirīṣāmrapriyaṅgavaḥ || || panasāśokadacalījambūlakucadāḍimāḥ | māṅgalyāḥ pūrvamārāme ropaṇīyā gṛheṣu vā || || śālmaliṃ kovidāraṃ ca varjayitvā vibhītakam || || asanaṃ devadāruṃ ca palāśaṃ puṣkaraṃ tathā | na vivarjyastathā kaściddevodyāneṣu jānatā || ||
translation:
I will tell you in the holy grove, O twice-born, the revered and worthy trees: the Ashoka, Punnaga, Sirisha, Plaksha, and Priyangu; the Panasa, Shala, Kovidara, and Bhallataka, but not the Vibhitaka;
The Devadaru, Palasha, and Pushkara are not to be excluded in the holy groves by those who know. These trees are to be planted first in the eastward direction, or even in one's own house, for they are auspicious.

sloka: āmrāśca siktāḥ pitaraśca prīṇitāḥ ||
translation: The mangoes have been eaten and the father has been pleased.

sloka: naiyagrodha audumbara āśvatthaḥ plākṣa itīdhmo bhavatyete vai gandharvāpsarasāṃ gṛhāḥ ||
translation: The nyagroda, udumbara, ásvattha, and pláksha are respectively the homes of the gandharvas and apsarases.

sloka: evameṣu purāṇeṣu taḍāga vidhirucyate|| || kūpavāpīṣu sarvāsu tathā puṣkariṇīṣu ca| eṣa eva vidhirdṛṣṭaḥ pratiṣṭhāsu tathaiva ca|| || mantratastu viśeṣaḥ syāt prasādodyānabhūmiṣu|
translation: In these ancient texts, a lotus in a pond or a well is praised; similarly, such is the established practice regarding bases of installation. However, there is a special distinction when it comes to bases for performing mantras and offerings.

sloka: vṛkṣāgrātpatitasyāpi ārohātpatitasya ca| maraṇe vāsthibhaṅge vā kartā pāpairna lipyate ||||
translation: The doer is tainted, whether it's climbing up a tree from its base or coming down from it, and even at death or the falling of a support.

sloka: jayaṃtyāḥ somavṛkṣasya tathā somavaṭasya ca | panasasya kadaṃbasya niṃbasya dvijasattamāḥ || || pāṭalā kanakasyaiva śālmalīniṃbakasya ca| biṃbāśokavaṭasyaiva pratiṣṭhāṃ naiva kārayet || || bhadrakasya śamīkoṇacaṃḍātakabakasya ca | khadirasyaiva kartavyaṃ karṇavedhaṃ na kārayet ||||
translation: The best of the twice-born should not establish the foundation of pāṭala, gold, śālmali, kiṃśuka, arjuna, niṃba, bhadraka, śami, kona, takara, and bakas trees, nor should they perform a bark-boring ceremony on khadira tree.

sloka: kārayitvā dṛḍhastaṃbhaṃ śubhapakveṣṭakāmayam | śubhaṃ kamaṭhapṛṣṭhābhaṃ bhābhāsitadigaṃtaram || pratiśraye tu vistīrṇe kārite sajale ghane || || dīnānāthajalārthāya kṛtaṃ kiṃ na kṛtaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Having constructed a firm pillar, beautiful, with a coating of whitewash and adorned with hanging pots, and having made it tall, if one provides shade to those seeking shelter during a heavy rainfall, what would not have been done for the benefit of the distressed?

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established conclusion is the acceptance of the competence to explain the rules of a tantra system. {definition of siddhanta}

sloka: saḥ caturvidhaḥ sarvatantrapratitantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthityarthāntarabhāvāt|| {tantrabhedauddeśasūtram}
translation: He who is established in the ultimate reality of the four-fold Tantra, as both independent and dependent, due to the inner nature of their interconnectedness. ({Tantrabheda Udesa Sutra})

sloka: tantrārthasaṃsthitiḥ tantrasaṃsthitiḥ tantramitaretarābhisaṃbaddhasyārthasamūhasyopadeśaḥ śāstram | adhikaraṇānuṣaṅārthā saṃsthitiradhikaraṇasaṃsthitiḥ abhyupagamasaṃsthitiranavadhāritārthaparigrahaḥ tadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇāyābhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ | tantrabhedāttu khalu sa caturvidhaḥ |
translation: The establishment of the meaning of a tantra, the establishment of a tantra, and instructions for understanding the interconnectedness of things related to a tantra comprise what is called "shastra." The settled interpretation of an object, the settled interpretation of the object's basis, the accepted interpretation of an assertion, and the adoption of unanalyzed meanings are all types of established meanings. To examine the specific characteristics of a tantra, an accepted interpretation is established. Indeed, there are four types of divisions [in this regard].

sloka: sarvatantrāviruddhaḥ tantre adhikṛtaḥ arthaḥ sarvatantrasiddhāntaḥ|| {sarvatantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: "The meaning that is in accordance with all the principles of every tantra, and which is established in a tantra that does not conflict with any other tantra, is called the correct interpretation of all tantras, {which is characterized by this definition}."

sloka: yathā dhrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi gandhādaya indriyārthāḥ pṛthivyādī bhūtāni pramāṇairarthasya grahaṇamiti|
translation: Just as the sense organs like the sense of smell are for experiencing their respective objects such as earth, etc., and the means of knowledge are for grasping the meaning of something.

sloka: samānatantrāsiddhaḥ paratantrāsiddhaḥ pratitantrasiddhāntaḥ||{pratitantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: One who is established in their own authority, who recognizes the authority of others, and whose principles of determination are in accordance with others' expectations.

sloka: yatsiddhau anyaprakaraṇasiddhiḥ saḥ adhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ|| {adhikaraṇasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: That which is a prerequisite for the success of any other undertaking is known as the siddhanta (established doctrine) of the adhikarana (subject or topic).

sloka: yasyārthasya sidhdāvanye'rthā yadadhiṣṭhānāḥ so'dhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ | yathā dehendriyavyatirikte jñātā darśanasparśanābhyāmekārthagrahaṇādibhiḥ| atrānuṣaṅgiṇo'rthā indriyanānātvaṃ niyataviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi svaviṣayagrahaṇaliṅgāni jñāturjñānasādhanāni gandhādiguṇavyatiriktāṃ dravyaṃ guṇādhikaraṇamaniyataviṣayāścetanā iti pūrvārthasidhdāvete'rthāḥ sidhyanti na tairvinā so 'rthaḥ saṃbhavatīti|
translation: The establisher of the meaning's locus is the one who has accomplished the determination of the meaning's other objects. Just as a knower, through the means of knowledge such as perception that have specific objects, apprehends an object separate from the body and senses, along with its distinct qualities; in this case, the sense organs are instruments, the objects of sense are specific, the apprehension of those objects is the mark of a knower, and knowledge of something other than the sense objects is the possessor of that knowledge. Thus, the meaning's establisher causes the understanding of the other meanings; without them, meaning cannot arise.

sloka: aparīkṣitābhyupagamāttadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇaṃ abhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ|| {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The presumption of not examining the specifics before accepting (something) is known as a settled assumption.

sloka: adhaḥ svidāsīt upari svidāsīt bhīriva vindantī |
translation: Below or above, who knows? Only the fearless one can find out.

sloka: pravṛttaṃ ca nivṛttaṃ ca dvividhaṃ karma vaidikam āvartate pravṛttena nivṛttenāśnute'mṛtam
translation: The Vedic duty is twofold, either engaged in or abstained from; one partakes immortality through engaging in it in the prescribed way and abstaining from it in the prohibited way.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: This is the prescribed performance of the agnihotra and other rituals, which involves the use of harmful materials for worldly gain, and includes the darsha and purnamasa offerings, as well as the four-monthly animal sacrifice; this is known as pravrtta, and it also includes the provision of food and other necessities for the maintenance of gods, hermits, guests, and animals.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: My illusion has been destroyed and memory regained thanks to you, O unfallen one. Established am I now, my doubts dispelled; I will carry out your command.

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Renunciation and karma-yoga, both lead to liberation. However, karma-yoga is superior to renunciation in practice.

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: A yogi is superior to ascetics, also considered superior to those who possess knowledge; a yogi is also superior to fruitive workers. Therefore, strive to be a yogi, O Arjuna.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The supreme being, O Partha, is attainable through devotion and none other way. In whom all beings reside and by whom this entire world is pervaded.

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, always perform your prescribed duties with dedication, for a person engaged in such duties obtains the fulfillment of their goals.

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: One who performs actions, having placed them in Brahman, while abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf is not touched by water.

sloka: oṃ brahmavādino vadanti | kiṃ kāraṇaṃ brahma kutaḥ sma jātā jīvāma kena kva ca sampratiṣṭhā | adhiṣṭhitāḥ kena sukhetareṣu vartāmahe brahmavido vyavasthām || ||
translation: Brahma speakers declare, "What is the cause of Brahman, when and where was it born, by what does it live, and in whom is it established? How do those who understand Brahman reside in happiness?"

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: By knowing whom, O Lord, everything else becomes known.

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe | mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca | sthitaṃ ca yacca | sacca tyaṃ ca || bṛha ||
translation: Indeed, the Brahman has two forms, one perishable (material) and the other imperishable (immaterial); motionless and also moving; real and unreal.

sloka: ātmetyevopāsītātra hyete sarva ekaṃ bhavanti |
translation: They indeed become one when considered as the Self here.

sloka: saṃyuktametatkṣaramakṣaraṃ ca vyaktāvyaktaṃ bharate viśvamīśaḥ | anīśaścātmā badhyate bhoktṛbhāvājjñātvā devaṃ mucyate sarvapāśaiḥ || ||
translation: The Lord of the universe, who is both the manifest and unmanifest, perishable and imperishable, binds the unwise soul that identifies itself with the enjoyer's nature, but one is freed from all bonds upon knowing the divine.

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: A part of me (Atman) always exists as the living entity in this world, while the mind and five senses, which have their origin in prakriti (nature), pull it towards sense objects.

sloka: na puṇyapāpe mama nāsti nāśo na janma dehendriyabuddhirasti | na bhūmirāpo na ca vahnirasti na cānilo me'sti na cāmbaraṃ ca || || evaṃ viditvā paramātmarūpaṃ guhāśayaṃ niṣkalamadvitīyam | samastasākṣiṃ sadasadvihīnaṃ prayāti śuddhaṃ paramātmarūpam || ||
translation: I possess no destruction of virtue or sin, no aging of the body, nor any change in the senses and intellect. There is no earth, water, fire, air, or ether for me. Nor is there a physical body. Realizing this, that the indestructible, secondless, all-witnessing consciousness, devoid of existence and non-existence, goes to its pure form as the supreme soul.

sloka: manorhairaṇyagarbhasya ye marīcyādayaḥ sutāḥ | teṣāṃ ṛṣīṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ putrāḥ pitṛgaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ ṛṣibhyaḥ pitaro jātāḥ pitṛbhyo devamānavāḥ | devebhyastu jagatsarvaṃ caraṃ sthāṇvanupūrvaśaḥ
translation: The sons of Manorhairaṇyagarbha, such as Marīcya and others, are remembered as the ancestors of all the seers. Indeed, the seers are born from the rishis, who are themselves born from their ancestors. Ultimately, the ancestors are born from the devas, and from the devas comes everything moving and stationary in the world.

sloka: vasūnvadanti tu pitṝnrudrāṃścaiva pitāmahān | prapitāmahāṃstathādityānśrutireṣā sanātanī
translation: The Vasus indeed speak of the ancestors, as do Rudras and Pitrs; likewise, this eternal narrative concerns the Adityas.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The Soma-drinker (Somapā) is named among the brahmins, the sacrificer (Havirbhuja) among the kshatriyas, the one who uses ghee (Ajyapā) among the vaishyas, and the clean one (Sukālinaḥ) among the shudras. The sons of the sage Kaveesh are called Somapā, and the sons of Pulastya and Vasistha are named Ajyapā.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Therefore, the mouth prepares itself, therefore the senses are made keen, therefore also the earth is enriched with various tastes, therefore the plants and crops grow.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: In Rohini, Mrigashirsha, Phalguni, Hasta, and the first parts of Uttara Phalguni and Chitra.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati || gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: When a brahmin studies the Vedas especially under the constellation Kritika, he becomes the foremost possessor of divine effulgence; his house becomes a place where fire sacrifice is performed.

sloka: kṛttikāsvagnī ādadhīta | etyāhuretadhda vā agnernakṣatraṃ
translation: The fire constellation (Agnier Nakshatram) is said to have been placed in the Krittikas.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are vasanta (spring), grishma (summer), varsha (rainy season), and sharat-hemanta-shishira (autumn-winter). These are the deities, and the ancestors are those who preside over them.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: Engaging in wakefulness and sleep throughout the night.

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: This is the wood's womb that kindles the fire; this indeed is the form assumed for the fire's sacrifice.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: With earth, air, and sky as offerings, he establishes the sacrificial fire for two additional purposes: to ward off harm and for the prosperity of all.

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: I now offer you, with oblations suitable for the sacred fire, O brahmanas, the ashvattha tree that grows from a sami seed, having arisen unshaken.

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: For one who has neglected their promise to fulfill a duty, either to properly assume the throne or to protect the kingdom, they must immediately light the sacrificial fire and offer ripe puroḍāśa, barley, and rice grains in the gārhapatya fires at midday. This is what should be done for one who has defaulted on their promise.

sloka: viṣṇuranyā devatāsītso'bravīdviṣṇavehīdamā hariṣyāvo yenāyamidamiti sa viṣṇustredhātmānaṃ vi nyadhatta pṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamantarikṣe tṛtīyaṃ divi tṛtīyamabhiparyāvartāddhyabibhedyatpṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravītanmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: Among the deities, no one is equal to Viṣṇu. He himself said, "I pervade this universe - the third of the earth, the third of the atmosphere, and the third of heaven." Having divided Himself in three parts, He dwells inside the earth as well. Then Indra, wielding his thunderbolt, asked him, "Viṣṇu, will you take this (thunderbolt) or not?"

sloka: mayi vīryaṃ tatte pra dāsyāmīti tadasmai prāyacchattatpratyagṛhṇādadhā meti tadviṣṇaveti prāyacchattadviṣṇuḥ pratyagṛhṇādasmāsvindra indriyaṃ dadhātviti yadantarikṣe tṛtī̭yamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravīnmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: "To me, he would concede his power, and to him, he would present himself," thinking, "This is Vishnu," while the other one also thinks, "This is Vishnu." In between them, the thunderbolt was held back by Indra. He (Indra) then said, "What have I here or not?"

sloka: saptadhā tu kṛte garbhe ditiḥ parama duḥkhitā sahasrākṣam durādharṣam vākyam sa anunayā abravīt
translation: In deep distress, Diti, who was seven months pregnant, spoke these words to Sahasraksha (Lord Vishnu), who is hard to approach.

sloka: vāta skaṃdhā ime sapta carantu divi putraka mārutā iti vikhyātā divyarūpā mama ātmajāḥ
translation: These seven, known as the Maruts, are my sons, endowed with physical forms that are extremely splendid and who roam in the sky, O son.

sloka: yadacarastanvā vāvṛdhāno balānīndra prabruvāṇo janeṣu | māyetsā te yāni yuddhānyāhurnādya śatruṃ nanu purā vivitse ||
translation: Having grown strong, performing deeds and proclaiming your strength among people, why don't you challenge the enemy now instead of waiting for some other time?

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: In a hundred, arises a warrior; in thousands, a scholar. Perhaps in ten thousand, one who can speak (eloquently). Rarely, one who gives (charitably).

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: Whatever wealth is acquired for the maintenance of the family, if even a little of it is diverted for one's own use without a valid reason, one incurs a flaw or blemish.

sloka: śaktaḥ parajane dātā svajane duḥkhajīvini | madhvāpāto viṣāsvādaḥ sa dharmapratirūpakaḥ | |
translation: Capable of giving to strangers, but living frugally at home, one who eats only moderate amounts of sweet and savory foods - such a person embodies righteousness.

sloka: tatra guṇānsamīkṣya yathāśakti deyam
translation: Considering the abilities, one should give according to their capacity.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: The stimulation of the senses is the incentive for begging, but one should not indulge in it. One who properly initiates religious practices and material possessions in a detached manner at holy pilgrimages should not beg for their own sensory pleasure.

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: Where there is no fear while crossing (a river), and where people are gathered, that is the spot indicated by the marker.

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: He who properly bestows gifts, taking into account the place, time, and purity.

sloka: yadyasya vihitaṃ carma yat sūtraṃ yā ca mekhalā | yo daṇḍo yacca vasanaṃ tattadasya vrateṣvapi || sevetemāṃstu niyamān brahmacārī gurau vasan | sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ tapovṛddhyarthamātmanaḥ ||
translation: Whoever follows the rules of wearing the sacred thread, cord, belt, staff, and clothing, and who controls his senses, should wear this (applied mark) as a part of his vow while serving the guru in brahmacarya (celibate studenthood) for spiritual growth.

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Offering water, putting on a sacred thread, carrying a staff, and touching the ground as a daily morning greeting.

sloka: brahma vedastadadhyayanārthaṃ yadvrataṃ tadapi brahmataccaratīti brahmacārī |
translation: For the purpose of studying the Vedas, one who is devoted to the vow of Brahmacharya (celibacy), indeed practices Brahmacharya.

sloka: mekhalājinavāsāṃsi jaṭādaṇḍakamaṇḍalūn | bibhṛyādupavītaṃ ca darbhapāṇiryathoditam || ||
translation: Wearing a girdle, clad in deer skin, adorned with matted hair, staff, and tuft, asceticism fully embraced, holding a grass blade in hand.

sloka: daṇḍājinopavītāni mekhalāṃ caiva dhārayet |
translation: Should carry a staff, sacred thread, and waistband.

sloka: muñjānāṃ valkalānāntu kramānmaujjyāḥ prakīrtitāḥ || mārgavaiyādhravāstāni carmāṇi vratacāriṇāṃ | parṇapippalavilvānāṃ kramāddaṇḍāḥ prakīrtitāḥ ||
translation: The sacred threads of the Munj grass and those made from bark are renowned in order for ascetics who follow a rule of life. Similarly, the staffs of the followers of a disciplined life using leaves, Bilva and Palasha are celebrated.

sloka: kārṣṇarauravabāstāni carmāṇi brahmacāriṇaḥ | vasīrannānupūrvyeṇa śāṇakṣaumāvikāni ca | | | |
translation: The Kaurava's armor, which is worn by celibate Brahmacharis, has been put on in an unprecedented manner, along with the bark and deer skin.

sloka: aiṇeyamajinamuttarīyaṃ brāhmaṇasya rauravaṃ rājanyasya ājaṃ gavyaṃ vā vaiśyasya sarveṣāṃ vā gavyamasati pradhānatvāt
translation: The hell of the brahmin is eating food that has not been offered to the gods, the kshatriya's is not protecting the subjects, for the vaishya it is not trading honestly, and this applies to all equally. (or) The primary duty (pradhānatva) for all castes is: for the brahmin - to offer food to the gods; for the kshatriya - to protect the subjects; for the vaishya - to trade honestly; not performing these duties leads to hell for each respective caste.

sloka: avakrāḥ satvacaḥ sarve nāvipluṣṭāstu daṇḍakāḥ ||
translation: All (sarve) of them are upright (avakrāḥ), having self-control (satvacaḥ); not even a little (na avipluṣṭāḥ) have they swerved (daṇḍakāḥ) from the path.

sloka: kauśaṃ sautraṃ vā tristrivṛd yajñopavītam || ā nābheḥ ||
translation: The sacred thread, whether it is made of Kusha grass or cotton, should be worn touching the navel.

sloka: kārpāsaṃ upavītaṃ syādviprasyordhvavṛtaṃ trivṛt | śaṇasūtramayaṃ rājño vaiśyasyāvikasautrikam | | | | vāsopavīte kārpāsakṣaumorṇānāṃ yathākramaṃ |
translation: The priest should wear a cotton sacrificial thread, turned upwards, having three strands; the warrior's should be made of hemp, unbound and with only one strand; the commoner's should be woven from goat hair, following the proper sequence of threads.

sloka: mekhalāṃ ajinaṃ daṇḍaṃ upavītaṃ kamaṇḍalum | apsu prāsya vinaṣṭāni gṛhṇītānyāni mantravat | | | |
translation: Having offered (the sacred thread, deer skin, staff, water pot) in the water, one should take them back as if they were mantras (i.e., with proper rituals and concentration).

sloka: upanīya guruḥ śiṣyaṃ sikṣayecchaucamāditaḥ | ācāramagnikāryaṃ ca sandhyopāsanameva ca ||
translation: The teacher, having initiated the student, should teach him, with a pure heart, proper conduct, duties toward fire, and the Sandhya worship.

sloka: snānaṃ abdaivatairmantrairmārjanaṃ prāṇasaṃyamaḥ | sūryasya cāpyupasthānaṃ gāyatryāḥ pratyahaṃ japaḥ | | | |
translation: Bathing with holy waters, recitation of mantras for purification, control of the life force, observing the rising sun, and daily chanting of the Gayatri mantra.

sloka: nityaṃ snātvā śuciḥ kuryāddevarṣipitṛtarpaṇam | devatābhyarcanaṃ caiva samidādhānaṃ eva ca | | | |
translation: One should perform the rites of tarpaṇa for deities, ancestors, and Rishis after daily ablutions, being always pure, as well as offer oblations in the fire and worship the devatās.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātarupāsīta gurvagnyarkasurottamān | ubhe sandhye ca yatavāgjapan brahma samāhitaḥ || ||
translation: In the evening and morning, one should reverently attend to the fire of the worthy teacher and master his passions; at both sandhyas (dawn and dusk), he should meditate on Brahman while performing the agnihotra.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaśca juhuyānnāmedhyaṃ vyastahastakaṃ | dūrādāhṛtya samidhaḥ sannidadhyādvihāyasi | sāyaṃḥ prātaśca juhuyāttābhiragniṃ atandritaḥ | | | |
translation: In the evening and in the morning, one should offer oblations with a focused mind, gathered hands, bringing firewood from a distance. One should diligently kindle the fire twice, in the evening and in the morning.

sloka: chandāṃsyadhīyīta gurorāhūtaścetsuyantritaḥ | upakrame'vasāne ca caraṇau śirasā namet || ||
translation: One should learn the meters (of the Vedas) from the teacher and perform actions, bending (one's body, i.e., showing respect) at the beginning and end by touching the feet with the head.

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: Should be always diligent in study and serving the guru, whether advised to do so or not.

sloka: yajñānāṃ tapasāṃ caiva śubhānāṃ caiva karmaṇām | veda eva dvijātīnāṃ niḥśreyasakaraḥ paraḥ | | | |
translation: For brahmins, solely performing Vedic sacrifices, austerities, and other auspicious actions leads to the ultimate good.

sloka: vedaṃ eva sadābhyasyettapastapsyandvijottamaḥ | vedābhyāso hi viprasya tapaḥ paraṃ ihocyate | | | |
translation: The twice-born should always study the Vedas; this is the primary penance for a brahmin.

sloka: madhunā payasā caiva sa devāṃstarpayeddvijaḥ | pitṝnmadhughṛtābhyāṃ ca ṛco'dhīte ca yo'nvaham | | | | yajūṃṣi śaktito'dhīte yo'nvahaṃ sa ghṛtāmṛtaiḥ | prīṇāti devānājyena madhunā ca pitṝṃstathā | | | | sa tu somaghṛtairdevāṃstarpayedyo'nvahaṃ paṭhet | sāmāni tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | | medasā tarpayeddevānatharvāṅgirasaḥ paṭhan | pitṝṃśca madhusarpirbhyāṃ anvahaṃ śaktito dvijaḥ | | | | vākovākyaṃ purāṇaṃ ca nārāśaṃsīśca gāthikāḥ | itihāsāṃstathā vidyāḥ śaktyādhīte hi yo'nvaham | | | | māṃsakṣīraudanamadhu tarpaṇaṃ sa divaukasām | karoti tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | |
translation: A twice-born person should appease the gods with milk and honey, using ghee from cows to perform rituals for the ancestors in the recitation of Ṛk mantras. With ghee and soma, they should appease the gods during the daily recitation of Yajur mantras. Through the recitation of Sāman mantras, one should satisfy the gods with a mixture of honey and ghee. Using ghee and the meat of sacrifices, one should satisfy both the gods and ancestors. A twice-born person, endowed with the ability to perform these rituals, should do so daily. They should also recite ancient sayings, narratives, and knowledge, satisfying the pitṛs (ancestors) through offerings of honey and rice balls.

sloka: yaṃ yaṃ kratuṃ adhīte ca tasya tasyāpnuyātphalam | | | |
translation: Whatever sacrifice one studies, they reap the corresponding fruit of it.

sloka: trirvittapūrṇapṛthivī dānasya phalaṃ aśnute | tapasaśca parasyeha nityaṃ svādhyāyavāndvijaḥ | | | |
translation: The twice-born learnt person partakes in the reward of charity thrice every day, as well as from constant spiritual practice.

sloka: bhaikṣeṇa vartayennityaṃ naikānnādī bhavedvratī | bhaikṣeṇa vratino vṛttirupavāsasamā smṛtā | | | |
translation: Living a life of constant begging, one doesn't become a breaker of vows; such a lifestyle is considered equivalent to fasting and is known as the practice of a vow-taker.

sloka: brāhmaṇeṣu caredbhaikṣaṃ anindyeṣvātmavṛttaye | | | |
translation: To the brahmins, giving alms and having a pure conduct towards those who do not deserve censure.

sloka: prathamaṃ tatra bhhikṣeta yatra bhikṣā dhruvaṃ bhavet |
translation: There, one should first beg where a sure alms-giving is to be found.

sloka: mātaraṃ vā svasāraṃ vā māturvā bhaginīṃ nijām | bhikṣeta bhikṣāṃ prathamaṃ yā cainaṃ nāvamānayet | | | |
translation: He should first beg alms from his mother, sister, or aunt, or any other female relative, before from others; otherwise, he should not be disrespected.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaścaredbhaikṣaṃ gurave tannivedayet | bhuñjīta yadyanujñāto no cedupavasetkvacit || ||
translation: In the morning and evening, one should beg for alms and offer them to the teacher; eat only what is permitted, and never overindulge.

sloka: vratavaddevadaivatye pitrye karmaṇyatha rṣivat | kāmaṃ abhyarthito'śnīyādvrataṃ asya na lupyate | | | | brāhmaṇasyaiva karmaitadupadiṣṭaṃ manīṣibhiḥ | rājanyavaiśyayostvevaṃ naitatkarma vidhīyate | | | |
translation: Just as the priority of a devout person is to follow vows and regard deities, ancestors, and sages, similarly, a Brahmin should follow this duty. This duty is not prescribed for a Kshatriya or Vaishya. When asked, such a vow should not be transgressed by the Brahmin.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: For those who are without Vedic rituals and righteous actions, but are praised in their own occupations, one should subsist on only fruits and roots, leaving home daily. One should not beg for alms in the teacher's family or among relatives. If no food is obtained in other places, one should first reject (the idea of) going to their own houses (for food). In case all means fail, one may wander into a village, but should strictly follow the rules and avoid harsh speech.

sloka: akṛtvā bhaikṣacaraṇaṃ asamidhya ca pāvakam | anāturaḥ saptarātraṃ avakīrṇivrataṃ caret | | | |
translation: Having not practiced begging alms and without avoiding fire, one should wander as a spiritual ascetic for seven nights, with vows unbroken.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: Always engaged in celibacy and austerities, constantly seeking initiation, self-controlled, always under the guidance of the guru, constantly studying and free from distraction – this should always be one's duty, performing it without fail.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: A virtuous man, skilled and honest, full of faith, and with mastery over his senses, conducts himself appropriately towards the three aims of life (dharma, artha, and kama) and even towards women who have been won over.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Engaged in the service of a single preceptor, O Arjuna, one who is free from pride and mud-like dirt thoroughly washes off all the impurities of not knowing the entire Vedic knowledge.

sloka: guruṃ caivāpyupāsīta svādhyāyārthaṃ samāhitaḥ | | | |
translation: One should also revere the teacher, focused on the purpose of self-study.

sloka: brahmacārī gurukule vasan dānto gurorhitam | ācaran dāsavannīco gurau sudṛḍhasauhṛdaḥ || || āhūtaścāpyadhīyīta labdhaṃ cāsmai nivedayet | hitaṃ tasyācarennityaṃ manovākkāyakarmabhiḥ | | | |
translation: Residing in the guru's abode as a brahmachari, self-controlled, and following the guru's orders, being subservient like a servant, constantly having a firm affection for the guru. One should listen attentively when called upon by the guru and share with him the knowledge gained. Always act for his welfare with mind, speech, and body.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: One who has not yet practiced on the bed (i.e., is still young) or one who is old should not take long to settle in. Upon getting up, they must greet each other. For, it is with the exertion of prana (vital energy) that youths rise and elders regain their strength through this exchange of greetings.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |
translation: One should always regularly follow the conduct of a guru. Similarly, one should act properly towards the guru's children and disciples, as well as towards one's own relatives. A student or someone of the same birth should assist in the performance of a yajña (ritual). The guru's son deserves to be honored like the guru himself. Just as a man becomes worthy by performing his duties, likewise, one attains the knowledge inherited from the guru through diligent service and respect.

sloka: teṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ śuśrūṣā paramaṃ tapa ucyate | | | | triṣveteṣvitikṛtyaṃ hi puruṣasya samāpyate | | | | tayornityaṃ priyaṃ kuryādācāryasya ca sarvadā | teṣveva triṣu tuṣṭeṣu tapaḥ sarvaṃ samāpyate | | | |
translation: Of the three, diligent service is said to be the supreme austerity; by performing one's duties in these three (body, speech, and mind), a person is fulfilled. One should always make that which is dear to both oneself and the teacher as their perpetual duty. All austerities are accomplished when one is content in these three (duty, wealth, and knowledge).

sloka: sarve tasyādṛtā dharmā yasyaite traya ādṛtāḥ | anādṛtāstu yasyaite sarvāstasyāphalāḥ kriyāḥ | | | |
translation: All his duties are fruitless if he neglects even one of the three; but if he respects them all, then all his duties bear fruits for him.

sloka: varjayetpramadāgāthāmagṛhastho bṛhadvrataḥ | indriyāṇi pramāthīni harantyapi yatermanaḥ || ||
translation: A householder who is deeply committed to his vows should avoid heedless behavior. The unruly senses can carry away even a person of sound mind.

sloka: keśaprasādhanonmardasnapanābhyañjanādikam | gurustrībhiryuvatibhiḥ kārayennātmano yuvā || || nanvagniḥ pramadā nāma ghṛtakumbhasamaḥ pumān | kalpayitvā''tmanā yāvadābhāsamidamīśvaraḥ | dvaitaṃ tāvanna viramettato hyasya viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: To keep oneself youthful, one should regularly perform acts such as oiling the hair, massaging the body, bathing, and applying colognes, under the guidance of experienced teachers. Indeed, this Agni named Pramada, who is like a pot full of ghee, must be mentally kindled by oneself, and it will continue to burn until this illumination of one's self is achieved. There is no stopping until then, for this is the nature of that Agni.

sloka: śuśrūṣāṃ satataṃ kurvanguroḥ saṃpraṇameta ca| ṣaṭ‌karmasvanivṛttaśca na pravṛttaśca sarvaśaḥ|| nācaratyadhikāreṇa seveta dviṣato na ca| eṣo''śramapadastāta brahmacāriṇa iṣyate||
translation: Constantly devoted to serving and always paying obeisance to the guru, not involved in performing any of the six sensual actions, nor ever engaged in anything, not acting beyond one's duties, not serving an enemy - this is called a brahmachari.

sloka: varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: Avoid in this world, at the current time, the consumption of alcohol and meat, as well as fragrances and garlands; all forms of harm towards living beings, including oysters; activities that are harmful to oneself such as unguents and collyrium, decorating the eyes, and wearing footwear or headgear; desires, anger, greed, dancing, singing, gambling, arguments, falsehoods, and staring at or obsessing over women; violent actions towards others.

sloka: ekaḥ śayīta sarvatra na retaḥ skandayetkva cit | kāmāddhi skandayanreto hinasti vrataṃ ātmanaḥ | | | | svapne siktvā brahmacārī dvijaḥ śukraṃ akāmataḥ | snātvārkaṃ arcayitvā triḥ punarmāṃ ityṛcaṃ japet | | | |
translation: A twice-born person, after learning the Brahmacarya discipline in a dream, should semenlessly sleep everywhere and not ejaculate. If, while still having desires, he ejaculates, he breaks his vow. Having bathed and offered oblations to the sun, he should repeat the mantra "triḥ puṇarmaṃ iti" three times.

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset | | | |
translation: Having properly memorized the Vedas or either of them in sequence, let the student reside in the householder stage as one who has not let his celibacy be defiled.

sloka: brahmavarcasakāmasya kāryo viprasya pañcame | rājño balārthinaḥ ṣaṣṭhe vaiśyasyehārthino'ṣṭame | | | |
translation: For a Brahmin seeking spiritual knowledge, his duty in the fifth stage; for a king desiring strength, it is so in the sixth; and for a merchant seeking wealth, it is in the eighth.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: (One should) learn about the conduct of brahmacarya, which lasts for twelve years or five; some say it is up to the time of the grahaṇa (eclipse), and others at the time of keśānta (when the hair falls out in tufts).

sloka: ṣaṭtriṃśadābdikaṃ caryaṃ gurau traivedikaṃ vratam | tadardhikaṃ pādikaṃ vā grahaṇāntikaṃ eva vā | | | |
translation: The 36-day discipline to be followed for the guru, consisting of the triveda ritual; or the partial observance of it; or just at the end of the period.

sloka: taṃ pratītaṃ svadharmeṇa brahmadāyaharaṃ pituḥ | sragviṇaṃ talpa āsīnaṃ arhayetprathamaṃ gavā | | | |
translation: One should first honor with a cow the revered Brahmins who have been seen to follow their own duty, who are adorned with garlands, and who sit or lie on the ground.

sloka: na pūrvaṃ gurave kiṃ cidupakurvīta dharmavit | snāsyaṃstu guruṇājñaptaḥ śaktyā gurvarthaṃ āharet | | | | kṣetraṃ hiraṇyaṃ gāṃ aśvaṃ chatropānahaṃ āsanam | dhānyaṃ śākaṃ ca vāsāṃsi gurave prītiṃ āvahet | | | |
translation: The knower of dharma has not previously acted contrary to the orders of the guru. I will serve the purpose of the guru, following his instructions with dedication. I will offer gold, land, a cow, an umbrella, a seat, grains, vegetables, and clothing to the guru, seeking to please him.

sloka: dattvā varamanujñāto guroḥ kāmaṃ yadīśvaraḥ | gṛhaṃ vanaṃ vā praviśetpravrajettatra vā vaset || ||
translation: Having received the permission of the guru, if one is authorized by the supreme being, whether they choose to enter the house or the forest, or to renounce (the world), that is set.

sloka: caritabrahmacaryasya brāhmaṇasya viśāṃpate| bhaikṣacaryāsvadhīkāraḥ praśasto dehamokṣaṇe||
translation: The expert authority over the practice of begging alms rightfully belongs to the brahmin who is pursuing celibacy, O lord of the people, in the pursuit of liberation from the body.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If one desires to permanently reside in the guru's household, they should serve and follow the instructions for bodily liberation. But if the guru has passed away, and a worthy son or relative of the guru is available, then they should continue to serve in that way. If none of these are present, one should engage in performing fire rituals and other duties while awaiting a suitable situation.

sloka: naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī tu vasedācāryasaṃnidhau | tadabhāve'sya tanaye patnyāṃ vaiśvānare'pi vā | | | |
translation: A perpetual brahmachari (student celibate) should always reside in the teacher's proximity. Otherwise, it would be as if he has made his wife or even Vaisvanara (fire) his resort.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: The virtuous Brahmin who practices celibacy without interruption reaches the highest position and does not return to this world again.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: Included in that are the seven domestic sacrifices: Aupasana, Homo, Vaisvadeva, Parvana, Masika, Pitrimedha, Sarpa-bali, and Rishabha-bali.

sloka: yatho etaddhutaḥ prahuta āhutaśśūlagavo baliharaṇaṃ pratyavarohaṇamaṣṭakāhoma iti sapta pākayajñasaṃsthā iti ||
translation: The seven domestic fires (or sacrifices) have been established, which include the offerings made through ignition, invocation, and baliharana, culminating in the eightfold sacrifice known as the Aṣṭaka Ahuti in the Pākayajña ritual.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: During their child-bearing years, some become pregnant.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Is there anyone who is properly skilled and intelligent, who has prepared the oblations at the right time, and who constantly knows when to tend the fire and offer the purifying fuel, who is worthy of worship and engaged in sacred rituals, who takes away our sins through the sacrifice and always protects us?

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name of the four Vedas are the Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvanash. The fifth one is Itihasa-Purana. The knowledge of these five branches of learning is known as Pitrya, Raasavidya, Nidhidhyavana, Devavidya, Brahma-vidya, Bhootavidya, Kshatra-vidya, Nakshatra-vidya, and Sarpa-devajna-vidya. One should meditate upon these names.

sloka: vāgvāva nāmno bhūyasī vāgvā ṛgvedaṃ vijñāpayatu yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vāṅnābhaviṣyanna dharmo nādharmo vyajñāpayiṣyanna satyaṃ nānṛtaṃ na sādhu nāsādhu na hṛdayajño nāhṛdayajño vāgevaitatsarvaṃ vijñāpayati vācamupāssveti
translation: "Let speech correctly determine the names, let it reveal the four Vedas - Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana Veda, and fifthly the Itihasa-Purana. Speech indeed will become all that is to be spoken. Let speech make known dharma, not adharma; satya, not anrita; sadhu, not asadhu; hridayajna, not ahridayajna. Thus, speech alone makes everything known; one should meditate on speech."

sloka: saṃkalpo vāva manaso bhūyānyadā vai saṃkalpatate'tha manasyatyatha vācamīrayati tāmu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmāṇi
translation: A thought, indeed, originates from the mind; then it becomes firm and is named. When named, it is uttered in the form of a mantra, and various actions are associated with that mantra.

sloka: tāni ha vā etāni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni samklṛpatāṃ dyāvāpṛthivī samakalpetāṃ vāyuścā''kāśaṃ ca samakalpantā''paśca tejaśca teṣā~ samklṛptyai saṃkalpamupāssveti
translation: These are indeed resolutions that, having been established in resolve, bring about the coming together of heaven and earth, air and ether, and also light. Therefore, one should practice (meditatively engage with) this resolution.

sloka: cittaṃ vāva saṃkalpādbhūyo yadā vai cetayate'tha saṃkalpayate'tha manasyatyatha vācasīrayati tāsu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmaṇi
translation: The mind, indeed, becomes resolved and creates intentions when it thinks, reflects, and directs speech. In such instances, a single action arises in the mind, just as a name arises in a mantra.

sloka: prāṇo hyovaitāni sarvāṇi bhavati sa vā eṣa evaṃ paśyannevaṃ manvāna evaṃ vijānannativādī bhavati
translation: The life-force (prana) indeed becomes all of these when one sees, thinks, and understands in this way.

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: Wealth earned through diligent effort, free from causing harm to others, is said to be either scant or plentiful, and ought to be given away.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ putradārādhisarvasvanyāsayācitam | pratiśrutaṃ tathānyasya na deyaṃ tvaṣṭadhā smṛtam || ||kuṭumbabhaktavasanāddeyaṃ yadatiricyate | madhvāsvādo viṣaṃ paścāddāturdhamo'nyathā bhavet || ||
translation: Property commonly owned by family members is to be dedicated to them; this is well-known and should not be given to others, as Tvasta is remembered. If it is given elsewhere, it could become bitter like the taste of madhuka fruit or turn out unfavorably.

sloka: bhūdīpāṃś cānnavastrāmbhas tilasarpiḥpratiśrayān | naiveśikaṃ svarṇadhuryaṃ dattvā svarge mahīyate || yāsmṛ || gṛhadhānyābhayopānac chatramālyānulepanam | yānaṃ vṛkṣaṃ priyaṃ śayyāṃ dattvātyantaṃ sukhī bhavet || yāsmṛ ||
translation: One who seeks illumination, giving up attachment to clothes, food, and shelter, is not considered great in heaven by merely gifting gold. One becomes completely contented by giving away house, grains, fearlessness, ornaments, vehicles, favorite trees, and comfortable bed – this is remembered.

sloka: trīṇyāhuratidānāni gāvaḥ pṛthvī sarasvatī | atidānaṃ hi dānānāṃ vidhdānaṃ tato'dhikam||
translation: They say that cows possess three types of generous gifts: earth, Saraswati (a river and a goddess of knowledge and arts). While giving is important, the highest form of giving is adhikam (something more than what is given), which can be interpreted as going above and beyond in one's acts of generosity.

sloka: annaṃ dadhi madhu trāṇaṃ gobhūrukmāśvahastinaḥ | dānānyuttamadānāni uttamadravyadānataḥ || vidyādānādanāvāsaparibhogauṣadhāni ca | dānāni madhyamānīha madhyadravyadānataḥ || paribhoga iti paribhogasādhanaṃ khaṭvāsanādi | upānatpreṅkhayānāni chatrapātrāsanāni ca | dīpakāṣṭhaphalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam || bahutvādarthajātānāṃ saṃkhyā śeṣeṣu neṣyate |adhamānyavaśiṣṭāni sarvvadānānyatī viduḥ ||
translation: Food, curd, honey, protection, cows, gold, horses, and elephants; the best gifts are these given out of abundance. Knowledge, a session with the teacher, consumables, medicinal herbs - these are middling gifts given out of moderate means. Paribhoga (comfortable necessities like clothes, blankets, umbrellas), upanatpreṅkhayānāni (decorative items), chatrapātrāsanāni (seats and vehicles), dīpakāṣṭhaphalādīni (lamps, wood, fruits) - these are the finest gifts given over many years. Among numbered things, only the remainder is counted; inferior gifts are always considered leftovers.

sloka: sarvadānairgurutaraṃ sarvagānairviśiṣyate | pānīyaṃ naraśārdūla tasmād dātavyameva hi||
translation: Among all generous persons, the most excellent is he who gives water. Therefore, O best among men, water should be given.

sloka: tasmāt tvaṃ sarvadānāni hitvānnaṃ samprayacchaha na hīdṛśaṃ puṇyaphalaṃ vicitramiha vidyate| annameva viśiṣṭaṃ hi tasmātparataraṃ na ca||
translation: Therefore, you should always give up everything else and offer only that (to the gods in a ritual), for there is no fruit of merit in this world more excellent or superior than that.

sloka: atidānāni sarvāṇi pṛthavīdānamucyate | acalā hyakṣayā bhūmirdogdhrī kāmānihottamān ||
translation: The earth is called imperishable, as it withstands all actions and is superior in fulfilling desires, being unchanging and never depleted.

sloka: yadaṅaga dāśuṣe tvamagne bhadraṃ kariṣyasi | tavet satyamaṅgiraḥ|| so aṅagirobhiraṅagirastamo bhūda vṛṣā vṛṣabhiḥ sakhibhiḥ sakhā san ṛgmibhirṛgmī gātubhirjyeṣṭho marutvāna no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: "O auspicious one, when you will protect the cows and people of Dashusha, becoming their benefactor, you will truly become the chief among the Angirasas, dear to your friends who are like bulls. May you be honored as Indra among us."

sloka: ta~hāṅgirā udgīthamupāsāṃcakra etamu evā''ṅgirasaṃ manyante'ṅgānāṃ yadrasaḥ
translation: There, the udgeeth (a type of hymn) that was performed is considered as that very Angirasa's (Angirasa is a revered sage), such is the opinion of those who know Angirasas.

sloka: yenā naḥ pūrve pitaraḥ padajñāḥ svarvido abhi gā adrimuṣṇan
translation: By which our forefathers, possessing knowledge of the path to heaven, first offered oblations to the mountain-dwelling god.

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: The brāhmaṇas, who are wise and experts in the four sacred Vedic texts, know well the short and profound words that lead to salvation, hidden in the cave of the heart. Ordinary people speak of the mundane world.

sloka: sūtrārtho varṇyate yatra padai: sutrānusāribhiḥ| svapadāni ca varṇyante bhāṣyaṃ bhāṣyavido vidu: ||
translation: The meaning of aphorisms is explained using words and their own words are also explained by those who know the commentary.

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ||||{avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The components of a promise are the stated reason, example, means, and explanation.

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: Explanation is also a quality of the treatise; with these fifteen types, the treatise gets adorned.

sloka: tatra pradhānakalpanā dvidhā pradhānasya kalpanā pradhānena vā kalpanā pradhānakalpanā |
translation: The conception of the primary (pradhāna) is twofold - either as the primary element itself, or as the one giving rise to the primary element.

sloka: saptadaśa tācchīlyādīnītyuktam |
translation: Seventeen [are mentioned as] vertebrae, starting from the head.

sloka: buddhimānātmanaḥkāryagurulāghavaṃkarmaphalamanubandhaṃdeśakālaucaviditvāyuktidarśanādbhiṣagbubhūṣuḥśāstramevāditaḥparīkṣeta
translation: A skilled physician should be consulted, who is knowledgeable about the time, place, and reason; who is proficient in their tasks and understands the results of actions; and who has a clear understanding of the teachings of the scriptures.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra, armed with his thunderbolt, alone slew ninety-nine fierce enemies.

sloka: tad vāṃ narā sanaye daṃsa ugramāviṣkarṇomi tanyaturna vṛṣṭim dadhyaṅa ha yanmadhvātharvaṇo vāmaśvasya śīrṣṇā pra yadīmuvāca
translation: I will now declare to you, O men, the mighty and fierce bite of that serpent, which Madhavatharana, the blower of the vama shusha, spoke of before, along with the rain.

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Maghavan, go now with good fortune and seek alms from the best of the knowers of sacred formulas, who is devoted to a vow of learning, and whose body is lean due to asceticism. Do not delay.

sloka: anannadānasya phalaṃ tvayedamupabhujyate | tarhyannadānato nānyaccharīrārogyakārakam || nānyadannādṛte puṃsāṃ kiñcitsañjīvanauṣadham | mahīṃ gatvā mahārāja kuruṣva vacanaṃ mama ||
translation: The result of not giving food and charity is being enjoyed by you alone. There is no other medicine for the body's well-being than giving charity, O king. Therefore, go and make (do) my words come true by traversing the earth.

sloka: prabhāte kālyamutthāya sarastadupacakrame | athāpaśyaṃ śavaṃ tatra supuṣṭamajaraṃ kvacit || ||
translation: Upon waking at dawn, he would perform his ablutions and then behold there, a well-nourished, ageless corpse.

sloka: paśyato me tadā rāma vimānādavaruhya ca | taṃ śavaṃ bhakṣayāmāsa sa svargī raghunandana || || tathā bhuktvā yathākāmaṃ māṃsaṃ bahu supīvaram | avatīrya saraḥ svargī saṃspraṣṭumupacakrame || ||
translation: Upon observing from his aerial chariot, Lord Rama disembarked and consumed the corpse of that divine being (the vulture Jatayu). After eating his fill of the delicious meat, the celestial bird ascended to heaven and approached me to inquire.

sloka: tasya me svargabhūtasya kṣutpipāse dvijottama | bādhete paramodāra tato 'haṃ vyathitendriyaḥ ||| ||
translation: Of him who has become mine in heaven, if there is a lack of food and water, oh best of the twice-born, it grieves me greatly.

sloka: gatvā tribhuvanaśreṣṭhaṃ pitāmahamuvāca ha | bhagavanbrahmaloko 'yaṃ kṣutpipāsāvivarjitaḥ ||| ||
translation: After reaching the best among the three worlds, his father said to him, "O Lord Brahma, this is the hunger and thirst-free world of Brahma."

sloka: pitāmahastu māmāha tavāhāraḥ sudevaja | svādūni svāni māṃsāni tāni bhakṣaya nityaśaḥ || ||
translation: My grandfather has told me this, O Sudevajan: You should eat daily these sweet and salty morsels of meat.

sloka: svaśarīraṃ tvayā puṣṭaṃ kurvatā tapa uttamam | anuptaṃ rohate śveta na kadācinmahāmate || || dattaṃ na te 'sti sūkṣmo 'pi tapa eva niṣevase | tena svargagato vatsa bādhyase kṣutpipāsayā || ||
translation: By engaging in the supreme austerity of nourishing your own body, it grows bright white and never decays. If you were to give away even the subtlest portion in charity, and instead devote yourself solely to austerities, then you would go to heaven, my dear, fettered by hunger and thirst.

sloka: pūrvameva mayā sṛṣṭo jāmbavānṛkṣapuṅgava:| jṛmbhamāṇasya sahasā mama vaktrādajāyata||
translation: Jambavan, the foremost of bears, was created by me long ago, emerging suddenly from my face as it was opening wide.

sloka: bhadraśca bhadraguptaśca bhadravindrastathaiva ca| saptabāhuśca vikhyātaḥ kanyā bhadrāvatī tathā| sambodhanī ca vikhyātā jñeyā jāmbavatīsutāḥ || ||
translation: Bhadra is auspicious, Bhadragupta and Bhadravindra are similarly named. The seven-armed one is also well-known, as is the famous daughter named Bhadrāvatī. The salutation-worthy Jñeyā is known as the daughter of Jāmbavatī.

sloka: jāmbavān ṛkṣarājastu bherīśabdairmanojavaḥ | vijayaṃ dikṣu sarvāsu mahotsavamaghoṣayat || ||
translation: Jambavan, the king of bears, swiftly sounded victory signals with loud roars on all sides during the grand festival.

sloka: mayā mahābaleścaiva yajñe viṣṇussanātanaḥ| pradakṣiṇīkṛtaḥ pūrvaṃ kramamāṇastrivikramam||||
translation: By the strength of both of us, O perpetual Vasudeva, has this three-stepped ritual circumambulation been performed in the sacrifice.

sloka: sa idānīmahaṃ vṛddhaḥ plavane mandavikramaḥ| yauvane ca tadā'sīnme balamapratimaṃ paraiḥ||||
translation: I, now an old man, previously had unmatched strength in my youth, while my movements were slow and feeble.

sloka: nīla magnisutaṃ caiva hanumantaṃ ca vānaram| pitāmahasutaṃ caiva jāmbavantaṃ mahābalam||||
translation: The son of Nila, Hanuman, the monkey, and Jambavan the mighty.

sloka: ṛkṣavantaṃ girivaraṃ vindhyaṃ ca girimuttam| anveṣayan pariśrāntaḥ sa dadarśa mahāmanāḥ|| ||
translation: While searching around the excellent mountain, Vindhya, which is like a lion among mountains, a great-souled one finally saw the hermitage on the top of the mountain.

sloka: vedānto nāmopaniṣatpramāṇaṃ tadanusārīṇi| śārīrakasūtrāṇi ca |
translation: The Upanishads, known as Vedanta, serve as the authority and are to be followed; the same applies to the Sutras concerning the body.

sloka: avidyādeḥ saṃsārabījasya viśaraṇād vināśanādityanena arthayogena vidyā upaniṣaducyate |
translation: The seed of saṃsāra, caused by avidyā, is said to be destroyed and rooted out by the pursuit of knowledge, like sunlight.

sloka: paraṃ brahma vā gamayatoti brahma gamayitṛtvena yogād vidyopaniṣad |
translation: Leads to the supreme Brahman through the power of yoga and knowledge.

sloka: garbhavāsajanmajarādyupadravavṛndasya lokāntarepaunapunyena pravṛttasya avasādapitṛtvena upaniṣadityucyate |
translation: The scripture (Upanishad) is called the means of overcoming the collection of misfortunes from pregnancy, birth, old age, and other adversities in the world for someone who acts with accumulated merit.

sloka: mokṣalakṣaṇamityetatparaṃ rahasyam ityevaṃ | saiṣā śāṃbhavī vidyā kādividyeti vā hādividyeti vā sādividyeti vā rahasyam |
translation: This is the supreme secret known as the mark of liberation. Is it the Shambhavi knowledge or simply called 'ka' or 'ha' or 'sa'?

sloka: īśakenakaṭhapraśnamuṇḍamāṇḍūkyatittiraḥ | aitareyaṃ ca chāndogyaṃ bṛhadāraṇyakaṃ tathā ||
translation: The Īśa, Kena, Praśna, Mundaka, Māṇḍūkya, Aitareya, Chāndogya, and Brihadāraṇyaka Upanishads.

sloka: ekamevādvitīyam| sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma |
translation: The one without a second, indeed, everything here is Brahman.

sloka: sarve vedā yatpadamāmananti tapā~si sarvāṇi ca yadvadanti | yadicchanto brahmacaryaṃ caranti tatte pada~ saṃgraheṇa bravīmyomityetat || ||
translation: I will tell you in brief the footstep of that which all the Vedas proclaim as the highest, and which those who desire Brahmacarya follow.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: This indeed is the ultimate reality, both higher and lower, that is the syllable "Om."

sloka: yo divi tiṣṭhandivo'ntaro yaṃ dyaurna veda yasya dyauḥ śarīraṃ yo divamantaro yamayaty eṣa ta ātmā'ntaryāmyamṛtaḥ || ||
translation: The one who dwells in the division between heaven and earth, whom no daytime knower knows, whose body is heaven, and who envelops the underworld – this self is the inner controller, the immortal.

sloka: sa ya eṣo'ṇimaitadātmyamida~ sarvaṃ tatsatya~ sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly understands this self-knowledge and that everything is identical to the self, Śvetaketu, that indeed is the truth.

sloka: sarvaṃ hyetad brahmāyamātmā brahma so'yamātmā catuṣpāt || ||
translation: Indeed, all of this is Brahman, this self is Brahman. This self is four-footed (all-pervading).

sloka: hṛdayaṃ nirabhidyata hṛdayānmano manasaścandramā |
translation: The heart has been pierced through by the one who is like the moon to the mind (meaning: the one who has captivated the mind completely).

sloka: tadaikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tattejo'sṛjata | tatteja aikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tadapo'sṛjata |
translation: Then (tada) looked (ikṣata) with a desire (bahu) for many (syāṃ) progeny (prajā) to be produced (prajāyeya). Then (tattejo) the fire (agni/teja) desired (ikṣata) with a desire (bahu) for many (syāṃ) offsprings (prajā) to be produced (prajāyeya). Then (tadapo) the water (ap) produced (asṛjata).

sloka: kṣaraṃ pradhānamamṛtākṣaraṃ haraḥ kṣarātmānāvīśate deva ekaḥ | tasyābhidhyānādyojanāttattvabhāvādbhūyaścānte viśvamāyānivṛttiḥ || ||
translation: The imperishable Lord, who is the supreme reality and the indestructible part within all beings, pervades as the individual soul. Through meditation on Him, one attains the realization of the self, and ultimately, at the end, the universe merges into the divine illusion.

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The meters, sacrifices, and rituals, as well as what has happened, will happen, and the Vedas declare; this entire moving creation is created from me through my illusive power, and other than me, something else is not bound by my illusive power in this.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyāvayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: Illusion (māyā) is indeed primal nature (prakṛti); the controller of illusion (māyinaṃ) is Maheśvara. All this universe is pervaded by its constituents (avayava-bhūtaiḥ).

sloka: idaṃ vai tanmadhu dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇo'śvibhyāmuvāca | tadetadṛṣiḥ paśyannavocat | rūparūpaṃ pratirūpo babhūva tadasya rūpaṃ praticakṣaṇāya | indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īyate yuktā hyasya harayaḥ śatā daśetiy ayaṃ vai harayo 'yaṃ vai daśa ca sahasraṇi bahūni cānantāni ca | tadetadbrahmāpūrvamanaparamanantaramabāhyam ayamātmā brahma sarvānubhūrityanuśāsanam || ||
translation: Indeed, this was said by Dadhyang Atharvan to Asvin brothers. A seer, having seen the form of that very form, spoke thus: "A counter-form has become of his form for the purpose of being perceived." Indra manifests himself in many forms through his maya. His maruts are attached (to him). There are ten and hundred and thousands, even countless (others). This very Brahman is before and after, both internal and external to all. This self is Brahman, the instruction that everything is to be experienced.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation: Just as from the navel (of the Lord) the universe is created and sustained, and just as plants grow from the earth and hair from the body of a living entity, similarly this whole universe is born from the imperishable.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and reliable testimony are the three established means of valid knowledge that establish the existence of an object of knowledge.

sloka: tasmācca viparyāsāt siddhaṃ sākṣitvamasya puruṣasya | kaivalyaṃ mādhyasthyaṃ draṣṭṛtvamakartṛbhāvaśca || ||
translation: Therefore, due to the reversal of understanding, the true nature of the self as pure consciousness, independence, witnessing, and non-actorship remains concealed.

sloka: saṃghātaparārthatvāt triguṇādiviparyādadhiṣṭhānāt | puruṣo'sti bhoktṛbhāvāt kaivalyārthaṃ pravṛtteśca || ||
translation: The person exists, being the one who enjoys, with control over the three gunas and their permutations, for the purpose of achieving isolation (kaivalya).

sloka: adhyavasāyo buddhirdharmo jñānaṃ virāga aiśvaryam | sāttvikametadrūpaṃ tāmasamasmādviparyastam || ||
translation: The discriminative understanding, the righteousness, knowledge, renunciation, and power are the satvic qualities; the reverse of these is tamasic.

sloka: abhimāno'haṃkāra: tasmādvividha: pravartate sarga: | ekādaśakaśca gaṇastanmātrapañcakaścaiva || ||
translation: Egoism and pride being the cause, the process of creation becomes twofold; it is characterized by the eleven elements, the group of five and the subtle five.

sloka: ubhayātmakamatra mana: saṅkalpamindriyaṃ ca sādharmyāt | guṇapariṇāmaviśeṣānnānātvaṃ bāhyabhedāśca || ||
translation: The mind is of a dual nature, and so is resolution and the senses, due to their similarity; distinction in gunas (qualities) and external differences are special.

sloka: hetumadanityamavyāpi sakriyamanekamāśritaṃ liṃṅgam | sāvayavaṃ paratantraṃ vyaktaṃ viparītamavyaktam || ||triguṇamaviveki viṣaya: sāmānyamacetanaṃ prasavadharmi | vyaktaṃ tathā pradhānaṃ tadviparītastathā ca pumān || ||
translation: Rooted in cause, eternal, all-pervading, active, single, with form, dependent, manifest, and non-manifest; the three qualities, the common, unconscious, and associated with nature - this is the distinction of the perceptible and the impersonal.

sloka: vatsavivṛddhinimittaṃ kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttirajñasya | puruṣavimokṣanimittaṃ tathā pravṛtti: pradhānasya || ||
translation: Just as the churning of milk leads to the emergence of butter, so too is the manifestation of human liberation brought about by the primary cause, the Supreme Pradhana.

sloka: tasmānna badhyate'ddhā na mucyate nāpi saṃsarati kañcit | saṃsarati badhyate mucyate ca nānāśrayā prakṛti: || ||
translation: Therefore, neither is bound nor released or wanders about in some form; one both binds and is released, depending on the various bases of nature.

sloka: raṅgastha ityupekṣaka eko dṛṣṭāhamityuparamatyanyā | sati saṃyoge'pi tayo: prayojanaṃ nāsti sargasya || ||
translation: A spectator, having seen one as a detached observer, does not look further. Even when there is a gathering, there is no purpose for these two in procreation.

sloka: tadabhāvavati tatprakārako'nubhavo'yathārthaḥ| yathā śuktāvidaṃ rajatamiti| saiva apramā ityucyate||
translation: The absence of that gives rise to a false experience similar to it, just like the falsely perceived silver in a shell. Such a misunderstanding is called.

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: Preferring one thing over another, a person chooses according to their own interest. Whoever gives up that which is preferable and chooses the inferior, loses merit and good fortune.

sloka: brahmacaryyācaraṇasya yaḥ śāstrabodhito'vadhiḥ | tāvadvedamupāsyāsamāptaveda evāśramāntaraṃ gato yaḥ sa vratasnātakaḥ |samāpya vratamasamāpya vedaṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vratasnātakaḥ
translation: For the rule-abiding practitioner of Brahmacarya, who is educated in the scriptures, upon completing their vow and moving on to the next asrama, they are considered a vratasnata; having completed their vow and returned to the Veda, they are also considered a vratasnata.

sloka: vedamadhītyagurusannidhau vedābhyāsaṃ yaḥ karoti sa vidyāsnātakaḥ |samāpya vedamasamāpya vrataṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāsnātakaḥ
translation: The one who studies the Vedas in the presence of a guru and practices it, is known as a knower of knowledge; similarly, the one who completes their vow after completing the Vedas, is also known as a knower of knowledge.

sloka: pālitasamyagvrataḥ prāptavedo yo dvitīyāśramaṃ gataḥ sa ubhayasnātakaḥ |ubhayaṃ samāpya yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāvratasnātaka iti
translation: One who has properly fulfilled his vows, having duly completed the second stage of life (i.e., grihastha asrama), and having bathed after both, is called a "vidyavratasnata" (one who has taken a vow of study).

sloka: tadya itthaṃ viduḥ | ye ceme'raṇye śraddhā tapa ityupāsate te'rciṣamabhisambhavantyarciṣo'harahna āpūryamāṇapakṣamāpūryamāṇapakṣādyānṣaḍudaṅṅeti māsā~stān || ||
translation: Those who, in this very life, worship faith and austerity are said to be constantly increasing in spiritual merit, surpassing those who perform the six monthly duties (such as sacrifices) by far.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: They say that this is the divine vehicle (devayāna) of Agni (fire-god) in daytime, of Surya (sun-god) at dawn, white (shukla) and reddish (rakottaraṃ) in complexion, independent (svarāṭ) and intellectual (taijasaḥ), omnipresent (viśvaḥ), and aware (prājña) due to its inherent nature. It is always engaged in self-sacrifice and self-pacification. The one who is established in the Self (ātmastho) never retreats from this.

sloka: atha ya ime grāma iṣṭāpūrte dattamityupāsate te dhūmamabhisambhavanti dhūmādrātri~ rātreraparapakṣamaparapakṣādyānṣaḍdakṣiṇaiti māsā~stānnaite saṃvatsaramabhiprāpnuvanti || ||
translation: Then, those who worship these villages with favorite offerings and gifts at the time of their prosperity, they become smoky like fire; day after day, night after night, through six months of the year, and finally reach the annual cycle.

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: The subtle transformations of substances, smoke, night, waning moon, the southern course, Soma, Darsha, herbs and grains, food, and semen are, in sequence, the birth-and-death cycle of the beings in this world, reoccurring again and again.

sloka: athaitayoḥ pathorna katareṇa ca na tānīmāni kṣudrāṇyasakṛdāvartīni bhūtāni bhavanti jāyasva mriyasvetyetattṛtīya~sthānaṃ tenāsau loko na sampūryate tasmājjugupseta tadeṣa ślokaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, one should beware of this verse regarding the third state (of dreamless sleep), where neither the small entities of "be born and die" are present, nor are they experienced.

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: In the process of directly realizing that (tad), he becomes eager through questioning and contemplation.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: In the world, these two paths of light and dark are eternal; one leads to a unidirectional journey, while the other makes one return again.
