sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: O Fire, go to the goddesses in these three worlds and be pleased! Surround them and drink the sacred nectar.

sloka: ā vakṣi devā~ iha vipra yakṣi cośan hotarni ṣadā yoniṣu triṣu ||
translation: O priest, you indeed declare the gifts to the gods in the three sacred fires, which are always present in this world.

sloka: yajñasya ketuṃ prathamaṃ purohitamagniṃ narastriṣadhasthe samīdhire ||
translation: The first sign of a sacrifice is the householder's fire, which he should kindle with (the help of) thirty-six handfuls of sacred grass.

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: The south direction is indeed considered primary, for it is the father of the fires, namely the Garhapatya and Ahavaniya fires; therefore, one should always make offerings to them in that direction.

sloka: gārhapatyena santya ṛtunā yajñanīrasi | devān devayate yaja ||
translation: By performing the marriage ceremony, you propitiate the gods because it establishes the proper season (for having children and other actions).

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These very three are the worlds, these very three are the stages of life. These very three are the Vedas, and these very three are the fires.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: One should welcome a guest in this way and offer alms to a mendicant, following the proper scriptural practices.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: In the well-nourished sacrificial fires presided over by learned brahmins, the oblation destroys great sins and also protects from danger.

sloka: bhikṣāṃ apyudapātraṃ vā satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | vedatattvārthaviduṣe brāhmaṇāyopapādayet | | | |
translation: Should a mendicant bowl or a respectable object be offered following proper procedure, it should be given to the Brahmin who is versed in the true meaning of the Vedas.

sloka: yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī | | | |
translation: By giving a cow to the teacher according to the proper procedure, one obtains that reward of merit; similarly, by giving alms to a twice-born person, one acquires that same reward of merit.

sloka: na mṛ॒tyu: āsīt amṛta॒ṃ na tarhi॒
translation: Death has never been, nor will it ever be equivalent to immortality.

sloka: ānī̭t avā॒taṃ sva॒dhayā॒ tat ekamtasmāddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa
translation: Having approached one's own teacher, nothing else is superior or comparable to learning that one teaching.

sloka: tapasa॒: tatmahi॒naajāya॒taekam
translation: Through intense meditation, a single-minded focus is attained.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: The divine and formless person exists, both inside and outside of all beings, unattached, independent, and pure, transcending the physical elements.

sloka: sahasraśīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ sahasrapāt
translation: The Being with a thousand heads and a thousand eyes, a thousand feet.

sloka: puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ yadbhūtaṃ yacca bhavyam
translation: The entirety of what has been and will be is nothing but the Purusha (Cosmic Being).

sloka: tasmādvirāl̤ajāyata virājo adhi pūruṣaḥsa jāto atyaricyata paścādbhūmimatho puraḥ
translation: Then, from him (the cosmic egg), the radiant Viraj was born, who became superior to him (the cosmic egg). After that, he spread out in all directions, first above and then below.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the first age of the gods, he was born along with them; in the second age of the gods, he was born at the very beginning. Then arose from him the desires and longings of all creatures.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The truth is one, but the learned refer to it in many ways.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: In the beginning, there was only the unreal. Then the real was born from it. The real then formed itself. Therefore, it is called self-created and its action is called meritorious. Indeed, that action is pleasure itself.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: In the beginning, this was non-existent. Then the seers said, "Was it so before or did it not exist at all?"

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: There is nothing here that has not been covered by death, nor is there anything uncovered that death has not enveloped. The mind thinks only of "This should be mine." While performing sacred rites for that very purpose, water is produced and named after the performer as "belonging to so-and-so."

sloka: sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam | taddhaika āhurasadevedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyaṃ tasmādasataḥ sajjāyata || || sattveva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam || ||
translation: In the beginning, there was only one reality, not a second; from that single reality, everything else emerged. Therefore, everything in existence is a manifestation of that one reality alone.

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The text that reveals a non-worldly means for the accomplishment of desired goals and the removal of undesirable ones is called Veda.

sloka: ekaviṃśatiśākhātmaka ṛk śataśākhātmaka yajuḥ sahasraśākhāmayasāma navaśākhāmayātharvva iti purāṇam api ca śrīmārkaṇḍeya uvāca |
translation: The ancient Markandeya said: The Rigveda has 21 branches, the Yajurveda has 100 branches, and the Samaveda has a thousand branches; the Atharvaveda has nine and additional branches.

sloka: tebhyastaptebhyastrayo vedā ajāyanta | agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurvedaḥ sūryāt sāmavedaḥ |
translation: From the heated (or glowing) ones, these three Vedas were born: from Agni came the Rigveda, from Vayu the Yajurveda, and from Surya the Samaveda.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, the Ṛc, Sāma, and Yajur are the sacrificial formulas to be used during initiation.

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: This is the exhaled breath of the great being, namely the four Vedas - Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvangirasa.

sloka: upa tvāgne divedive doṣāvastardhiyā vayaṃ namo bharanta emasi
translation: Approaching you again and again, O Agni, we have become guilty; we bow down to you.

sloka: vedaśāstrārthatattvajño yatra tatrāśrame vasan | ihaiva loke tiṣṭhansa brahmabhūyāya kalpate | | |
translation: One who in that hermitage knows the true purpose of the Vedas and Shastras, they become eligible for becoming Brahman even while dwelling here in this very world.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The Vedanta Shastras, which reveal the Brahman through human words and establish the path of dharma.

sloka: sanātanaṃ niteyam | vedāpauruṣeyatvapakṣa eva manorabhimataḥ| pūrvakalpe ye vedāsta eva paramātmamūrterbrahmaṇaḥ sarvajñasya smṛtyārūḍhāḥ | tāneva kalpādau agnivāyuravibhya ācakarṣa|
translation: The eternal duty, namely the Vedas being considered as non-human, is the one desired in his heart by the self-aware omniscient Brahman. In the previous cycle of existence, it was the very Vedas that embodied the divine form of Brahman that drew forth Agni and Vayu at the beginning of the creation.

sloka: yathā ca śrutiḥ agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurveda ādityātsāmaveda ||
translation: Just as the shruti (revealed scripture) in the Rigveda of Agni, Yajurveda of Vayu, and Samaveda of Aditya.

sloka: anantā vai vedāḥ |
translation: The Vedas are indeed infinite.

sloka: pitṛdevamanuṣyāṇāṃ vedaścakṣuḥ sanātanam | aśakyaṃ cāprameyaṃ ca vedaśāstraṃ iti sthitiḥ | |
translation: The eternal Vedas are the eyes of all human beings and their ancestors, and the indescribable and unspeakable knowledge contained within them is considered to be established as the Vedic scriptures.

sloka: vedo'khilo dharmamūlaṃ smṛtiśīle ca tadvidām | ācāraścaiva sādhūnāṃ ātmanastuṣṭireva ca | | | |
translation: The Vedas are the root of duty, learning is the foundation of the smrtis, good conduct is the ultimate resort of the saintly, and self-satisfaction is the highest goal of the individual.

sloka: bibharti sarvabhūtāni vedaśāstraṃ sanātanam | tasmādetatparaṃ manye yajjantorasya sādhanam | | | |
translation: One who upholds all living beings and the eternal Vedic scriptures, I believe this to be the highest means of controlling the senses.

sloka: ārṣaṃ dharmopadeśaṃ ca vedaśāstrāvirodhinā | yastarkeṇānusaṃdhatte sa dharmaṃ veda netaraḥ | | | |
translation: One who, with the help of valid reasoning, sustains and upholds the traditional teachings of dharma that do not contradict the Vedic scriptures, knows dharma; others do not.

sloka: yānīhāgamaśāstrāṇi yāśca kāścitpravṛttayaḥ| tāni vedaṃ puraskṛtya pravṛttāni yathākramam||
translation: The teachings and practices mentioned in the various scriptures, these should be followed in proper sequence after studying the Vedas.

sloka: parābhidhyānātu tirohitaṃ tato hyasya bandhaviparyayau
translation: The one who is not known through mere intellectual contemplation, then follows the reversal of his relationships (with those he used to be close to).

sloka: ata eva copamā sūryakādivat
translation: Hence, (there is) a comparison to the sun and so on.

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six auxiliary limbs of the Vedas are as follows: phonetics, grammar, etymology, metrics, prosody, and astrology.

sloka: atha śikṣāṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | varṇaḥ svaraḥ | mātrā balam | sāma santāna| ityuktaḥ śikṣādhyāyaḥ ||
translation: Now we will explain the lesson, which includes syllable, pitch, length, and strength, as well as sandhi (sequence of sounds). This is known as the chapter on phonetics.

sloka: mantro hīnaḥ svarato varṇato vā mithyā prayukto na tamarthamāha | sa vāgvajro yajamānaṃ hinasti yathendraśatruḥ svarato'parādhāt ||
translation: A spell, incorrectly or inappropriately used due to lack of knowledge or understanding, does not accomplish its purpose. Instead, it becomes a weapon of speech that can harm the patron, just as an enemy of Indra causes harm to him.

sloka: tattvaṣṭāhavanīyamupa prāvartayatsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti yadavartayattadvṛtrasya vṛtratvaṃ yadabravītsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti tasmādasyendraḥ śatrurabhavat
translation: Indra, by performing the ritual of austerity for the true essence (of the sacrifice), caused his enemy, Vrtra, to arise; only then did he declare, "I have vanquished my enemy, Vrtra." Therefore, Indra became known as the slayer of his enemy.

sloka: vyākriyante śabdāḥ anena iti vyākaraṇam | vyākriyante vyutpādyante sādhuśabdā asmin aneneti vā iti durgādāsaḥ
translation: This is called linguistic analysis, i.e., vyākaraṇa, where words are composed, evolved, and determined as 'sādhu' (correct) or 'asādhu' (incorrect) through this means.

sloka: indraścandraḥ kāśakṛtsnāpiśalī śākaṭāyanaḥ | pāṇinyamarajainendrāḥ jayantyaṣṭau ca śābdikāḥ ||
translation: Indra, Chandra, Kaasha, Krsna, Paisali, Sakatayana, Panini, Apastamba, Jayanti, and eight other grammarians.

sloka: arthāvabodhe nirapekṣatayā padajātaṃ yatroktaṃ tanniruktam |
translation: In the pursuit of understanding meaning, that which is expressed without bias at the time of the word's origin, is called its definition.

sloka: samāmnāyaḥ samāmnātaḥ sa vyākhyātavyaḥ | idamantareṇa mantreṣvarthapratyayo na vidyate iti |
translation: The appointed ritual, after being announced and explained, is to be performed without the use of this mantra, as its meaning is not understood by anyone else.

sloka: udāharaṇasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ|| {hetulakṣaṇam} tathā vaidharmyāt|| {hetulakṣaṇam}
translation: The reason for a similar example being an aid to understanding is due to its having the same characteristics; similarly, a dissimilar example is a reason for understanding because of its differing characteristics.

sloka: udāharaṇena sāmānyātsādhyasya dharmasya sādhanaṃ prajñāpanaṃ hetuḥ | sādhye pratisaṃdhāya dharmamudāharaṇe ca pratisaṃdhāya tasya sādhanatāvacanaṃ hetuḥ utpattidharmakatvāditi | utpattidharmakamanityaṃ dṛṣṭamiti | udāharaṇavaidharmyācca sādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ | katham anityaḥ śabdaḥ utpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ yathā ātmādidravyaniti ||
translation: The means of establishing a general rule or principle is explanation; the reason is its being an established practice. When establishing both the rule and its means, it is called stating its practicability. This is because of its nature as a property arising from establishment. It has been observed that "anitya" (non-eternal) is used in the sense of "utpattidharma" (property arising from establishment). Also, the exception to this general rule is the means of establishing the non-eternal in relation to the eternal, such as the soul and other substances.

sloka: sādhyasādharmyāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta udāharaṇam || {udāharaṇalakṣaṇam} tadviparyayādvā viparītam||{udāharaṇalakṣaṇam}
translation: A comparable example is seen where something that ought to be (sādhya) becomes the basis for determining what is appropriate (sādharma). Likewise, its opposite could also be the case.

sloka: sādhyena sādharmyaṃ samānadharmatā sādhyasādharmyātkāraṇāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta iti | tasya dharmastaddharmaḥ | tasya sādhyasya | sādhyaṃ ca dvividhaṃ dharmiviśiṣṭo vā dharmaḥ śabdasyānityatvaṃ dharmaviśiṣṭo vā dharmī anityaḥ śabda iti| ihettaraṃ tadgrahaṇena gṛhyate|
translation: The similar characteristic of the Sādhya is called sādharmya. The reason for the emergence of this sādharmya is the cause. That very thing which is the cause is his dharma (essential nature). This Sādhya has two types of dharma: one is that which is characterized by the word 'dharma,' and the other is the one who possesses dharma. The other one is grasped through the apprehension of it.

sloka: udāharaṇāpekṣaḥ tathā iti upasaṃhāraḥ na tathā iti vā sādhyasya upanayaḥ || {upanayalakṣaṇam}
translation: The standard of comparison and the summary statement are, respectively, the basis of proof and presentation of the thesis, or not. (Axiom of proof and presentation)

sloka: sādhyāsādharmyayukte udāharaṇe sthālyādi dravyamutyatidharmakatvamupasaṃhriyate sādhyavaidarmyayukte punarudāharaṇe ātmādi dravyamanutpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ na ca tathā śabda iti anutpattidharmakatvasyopasaṃhārapratiṣedhena utpattidharmakatvamupasaṃhiyate |
translation: In an example analogous to the inherent nature of the sādhya (goal), the properties of the illustrative material like a clay and such are subsumed; but in an example unrelated to the inherent nature of the sādhya, the eternal emergent property of the self and other things is always observed, and by negating the non-emergent property's subsumption, the emergent property is established.

sloka: hetvapadeśātpratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ nigamanam||{nigamanalakṣaṇam}
translation: The subsequent utterance, after making a statement and indicating a reason, is called the conclusion or proof.

sloka: sādharmyokte vaidharmyokte vā yathodāharaṇamupasaṃhriyate tasmādutpattidharmakatvādanityaḥ śabda iti nigamanam |
translation: The meaning of the Sanskrit verse is: "Hence, the term 'anitya' is used to signify the characteristics of arising in relation to either sameness or difference , just as it is illustrated through examples."

sloka: brahma vai mantraḥ | ḥ saptākṣaraṃ vai brahmargityekamakṣaraṃ yajuritidve sāmeti dve atha yadato'nyadbrahmaiva taddvyakṣaraṃ vai brahma tadetatsarvaṃsaptākṣaraṃ brahma |
translation: The mantra is indeed Brahman. The seven-syllabled [Gayatri mantra] is also called Brahman. Among the two, Yajur and Rig, each syllable of them is Brahman; indeed, anything other than that is not Brahman. All of this is the seven-syllabled Brahman.

sloka: mantrabrāhmaṇe yajñasya pramāṇam mantrabrāhmaṇayorvedanāmadheyam karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The standard of the ritual is the Brāhmaṇa mantra, and the Brāhmaṇa mantras are the basis of the Veda's knowledge. The Brāhmaṇas inspire and guide (in) action.

sloka: śeṣe brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ
translation: The word "Brāhmaṇa" remains at the end (of a sacrifice).

sloka: dvividham brāhmaṇam vidhiḥ arthavādaśca
translation: The classification of a Brahmin and the praise of it are twofold.

sloka: heturnirvacanaṃ nindā praśaṃsā saṃśayo vidhiḥ| parakriyā purākalpo vyavadhāraṇakalpanā|| upamānaṃ daśaite tu vidhayo brāhmaṇasya tu| etadvai sarvavedeṣu niyataṃ vidhilakṣaṇam||
translation: The definition of a priest includes the following characteristics in all the Vedas: making gifts, speaking words that are pleasing, criticizing, praising, entertaining doubts, performing rituals, and establishing rules.

sloka: itthaṃ vākyaistadarthānusandhānaṃ śravaṇaṃ bhavet yuktyā saṃbhāvitatvānusaṃdhānaṃ mannantu tat
translation: Understanding the meaning of sentences in this way involves listening and inferring their intended meaning based on context.

sloka: yat saṃbaddhaṃ sat tadākārollekhi vijñānaṃ tat pratyakṣaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: That knowledge which is directly ascertained when something is connected (with its cause), that is perceptual knowledge; Saankhya Suutra.

sloka: pratibandhadṛśaḥ pratibaddhajñānamanumānaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: A sign of being obstructed is the closing off of knowledge derived from inference, as per Sankhya Sutra.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: "The word is the authoritative teaching in the Sankhya system."

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and reliable testimony are the three established means of valid knowledge that establish the existence of an object of knowledge.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, and testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: āptena dṛṣṭo'numitaḥ vā arthaḥ paratra svabodhasaṅkrāntaye śabdenopadiśyate | śabdāttadarthaviṣayā vṛttiḥ śroturāgamaḥ | yasyāśraddheyārtho vaktā na dṛṣṭānumitārthaḥ sa āgamaḥ plavate |
translation: The meaning of the term "artha" (referring to an object or goal) is described through a reliable source, either seen or heard, for the sake of self-realization. The usage of this term indicates its specific reference, and it is through sound that its associated meaning arises in the listener. If the speaker lacks faith in such a denoted meaning, then that "agama" (scriptural tradition) becomes unstable.

sloka: tadvacanādāmnāyasya prāmāṇyam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: The authority of the Vaiśeṣika system is established by its own statements.

sloka: asyedaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃyogi virodhi samavāyi ceti laiṅgikam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This is the unique characteristic of causation in the Vaiśeṣika system: an effect, along with being dependent on a cause, also has opposition from obstacles and combination with accessories.

sloka: asyedaṃ kārya kāraṇasambandhaścāvayavādbhavati | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This (the relation of cause and effect) is not established separately from the components (of an object); it is a characteristic of Vaiseshika philosophy.

sloka: etena śābdaṃ vyākhyātam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This term "etena śābda" has been explained according to the Vaiśeṣika school of thought.

sloka: heturapadeśo liṅgaṃ pramāṇaṃ karaṇamityanarthāntaram | vaiśeṣika |
translation: The meaning of the Vaisheshika sutra is: "Cause, contact, quality, inherence, and perception are, in this context, understood to be the meaning of 'hetu' (cause), 'apadesh' (designation), 'linga' (distinguishing mark), 'pramana' (means of knowledge), and 'karanam' (instrument/cause), respectively."

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, and reliable testimony are the means of valid knowledge. // Pramana Sutra

sloka: indriyārthasannikarṣotpannaṃ jñānaṃ avyapadeśyaṃ avyabhicāri vyavasāyātmakaṃ pratyakṣam|||| {pratyakṣalakṣaṇam} atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavatśeṣavatsāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca|||| {anumānalakṣaṇam} prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam |||| {upamānalakṣaṇam} āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ |||| {śabdalakṣaṇam}
translation: Knowledge arising from the contact of the senses with their objects is unprescribed, unfailing, and definitive; it is direct perception (pratyaksa). Prior to this, there exists threefold inference: inference based on past observations, inference based on what has been previously stated, and inference based on similarity (upamana). Testimony or verbal communication (aptopadesa) is also a means of knowledge.

sloka: satsaṃprayoge puruṣasyendriyāṇāṃ buddhijanma tatpratyakṣam
translation: The true nature of a person becomes apparent in their interactions and associations, as it is through these experiences that their intellect and senses are revealed.

sloka: autpattikas tu śabdasyārthena saṃbandhas tasya jñānam upadeśo'vyatirekaś cārthe'nupalabdhe tatpramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt
translation: Knowledge of the inherent connection between a word and its meaning is the means of cognition regarding it, according to Badarayana, independent of any other pramana (means of valid knowledge), in the absence of direct apprehension of the meaning.

sloka: api vā kartṛsāmānyāt pramāṇam anumānaṃ syāt
translation: Or perhaps, inference is the means of valid knowledge for all agents (i.e., beings capable of action).

sloka: anumānaṃ jñātasambandhasyaikadeśadarśanādekadeśāntare'sannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhiḥ| tattu dvividhaṃ pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandham ca| pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā dhūmākṛtidarśanādagnyākṛtivijñānam| sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā devadattasya gatipūrvikāṃ deśāntaraprāptimupalabhyādityagatismaraṇam|
translation: Inference is the understanding of a connection between something known and something else known through direct observation, which can be of two types: specifically observed connections, such as smoke and fire; and generally observed connections, such as inferring Devadatta's arrival in a distant place based on the knowledge of his previous travel patterns.

sloka: śāstraṃ śabdavijñānādasannikṛṣṭe'rthe vijñānam||
translation: Knowledge in the subject matter of scriptures, especially related to sound and its meaning.

sloka: upamānamapi sādṛśyam asannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhimutpādayati| yathā gavayadarśanaṃ gosmaraṇasya|
translation: Even a mere comparison prompts a similar understanding in a person who is not far from it, just as the sight of a gavaya (a type of wild animal) prompts the recognition of a cow.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā ||
translation: Even when a livelihood appears to be seen or heard about, it is not appropriate to assume that it applies in the case of Devadatta, who is living as an ascetic without a home, based on the mere absence of its observation.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇābhāvo nāsti ityasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasya||
translation: The meaning of "abhāva" (non-existence) is not separate from that which is closely related to a means of correct knowledge.

sloka: śabdād eva pramitaḥ |
translation: Known only through word(s) (i.e., known by hearing).

sloka: api saṃrādhanepratyakṣānumānābhyām |
translation: Even through perception and inference.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: And (it) is evident through direct perception.

sloka: phalamata upapatteḥ |
translation: The result is indeed appropriate/deserved.

sloka: athocyeta mā bhūtkarmānantaraṃ phalotpādaḥ karmakāryādapūrvātphalamutpatsyata iti tadapi nopapadyate apūrvasyācetanasya kāṣṭhaloṣṭasamasya cetanenāpravartitasya pravṛttyanupapatteḥ tadastitve eva pramāṇābhāvāt arthāpattiḥ pramāṇamiti cet na īśvarasiddherarthāpattikṣayāt||
translation: "It should not be argued that the result arises immediately after the action, because the unprecendented and insentient object cannot initiate any activity, nor is it logical for a result to occur before the activity has begun. This inference becomes valid only in the absence of other pramana (means of knowledge). However, this inference cannot disprove the existence of an independent entity like Ishvara, because the destruction of one argument does not necessarily lead to the acceptance of another."

sloka: idānīmarthāpattirnirūpyate| tatropapadyajñānenopapādakakalpanamarthāpattiḥ| tatropapadyajñānaṃ karaṇam upapādakajñānaṃ phalam|
translation: The determination of a means for accomplishment is currently being discussed. In this context, knowledge that serves as the basis for the means is called "upapadya-jnana," and the result brought about by such a means is known as "phala."

sloka: samyagarthe ca saṃśabdo duṣprayoganivāraṇaḥ | prayoga indriyāṇāṃ ca vyāpāro'rtheṣu kaththate ||duṣṭatvācchuktikāyogo vāryate rajatekṣaṇāt | evaṃ satyanuvādatvaṃ lakṣaṇasyāpi saṃbhavet ||
translation: The term "samyag" denotes appropriateness and is used to restrict misapplication; it applies to the use of senses for proper purposes, preventing unwholesome and trivial usage. Similarly, truthful speech becomes a characteristic when impurity is avoided, just as attachment to impurities is rejected in the case of a piece of gold.

sloka: pramāṇaṣaṭkavijñāto yatrā'rtho nā'nyathā bhavet | adṛṣṭaṃ kalpayedanyaṃ sā 'rthāpattirudāhṛtā ||
translation: Where evidence-sixfold-known is, there the meaning does not become otherwise; unseen, one should infer something else - this is called meaning-establishment-withdrawal.

sloka: ānumānikam apy ekeṣām iti cen na śarīrarūpakavinyastagṛhīterdarśayati ca |
translation: Even to some, who claim to have understood the subtle arrangements of the physical body, it is not clearly visible.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: May (the acts of) serving the mother, father, teacher, elder relative, friend, and one who seeks help become fruitful (for me).

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: Given to a deceitful person, a flatterer, a dullard, a cheat, or to those who are engaged in lowly and unrighteous activities, it becomes fruitless.

sloka: ārūḍhapatite dattamanyāyopahṛtaṃ ca yat| vyarthaṃ tu patite dānaṃ brāhmaṇe taskare tathā||
translation: Given to one who has ascended (the vehicle) or taken away through proper procedure, but useless when given to a fallen Brahmin or one who steals; this is the established rule.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: All manifest things arise from the unmanifest in the cycle of day and night, and into the same unmanifest they merge; there exists beyond this neither the transient nor the imperishable unmanifest, which is also known as the supreme goal.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: Likewise, addressed by his beloved wife.

sloka: sattvasaktamatiḥ kṛṣṇe dahyamano mahārogaiḥ na vivedātmano gatram tartatyalhada saṃstitaḥ
translation: With all his consciousness absorbed in Krishna, being consumed by great flames, he does not realize the separation of his self from his body.

sloka: pañcaiva mahāyajñāḥ| tānyeva mahāsattrāṇi bhūtayajño manuṣyayajñaḥ pitṛyajño devayajño brahmayajña iti
translation: The five great sacrifices are indeed the five great rituals: the ritual for elements, the ritual for humans, the ritual for ancestors, the ritual for gods, and the ritual for Brahma.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: Five are the ornaments of a householder: a young wife, a maidservant, a cow, a vehicle, and a pot for holding water. These are encumbered by one who is bound by debt.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti
translation: Then, the five great sacrifices: the worship of God , the nourishment of creatures , offerings to ancestors , the study and recitation of Vedas , and the hospitality to guests .

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: Performs the fifth of the great sacrifices (Panchamahayajna) with devotion to prescribed duties.

sloka: pitṛyajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatpitṛbhyaḥ svadhā karotyapyapastatpitṛyajñaḥ saṃtiṣṭhateiti | tatra piṇḍadānāsaṃbhave jalamātramapi pitṛbhyaḥ svadhā'stviti svadhāśabdena yaddadāti so'yaṃ pitṛyajñaḥ
translation: The characteristic of the ritual for the ancestors is described as that which offers oblations to the ancestors, causing them to receive their due, even if only with water; hence, this ritual is called "svadha" (oblation to the ancestors).

sloka: vaiśvadevānuṣṭhānādūrdhvaṃ bahirdeśe vāyasādibhyo bhūtebhyo yadbalipradānaṃ so'yaṃ bhūtayajña:
translation: The act of offering the Vaishvadeva oblation to the fire, which is performed after the daily duties or in a distant place, is what is called the Bhutayajna, the sacrifice to all beings, since it involves the giving of grains and other substances to them.

sloka: yajñaḥ kasmāt | prakhyātaṃ yajatikarma iti nairuktāḥ | yācñaḥ bhavati iti vā | yajurunnaḥ bhavati iti vā | bahukṛṣṇājinaḥ iti aupamanyavaḥ | yajūṃṣi enaṃ nayanti iti vā |
translation: "Why is he called Yajña? Because he performs the ritual , begs for alms , studies the Yajurveda , is rich in black deer skins , or because he leads the Yajus hymns."

sloka: yajati codanādravyadevatākriyaṃ samudāye kṛtārthatvāt
translation: Offering made to a collection of materials and actions meant for deity worship, since it fulfills the purpose.

sloka: yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ| yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ dravyaṃ devatā tyāgaḥ
translation: We will explain the sacrifice (yajña); sacrifice consists of three elements: the things offered (dravya), the deity to whom it is offered (devatā), and the act of offering (tyāgaḥ).

sloka: yajñaḥ |
translation: A sacrifice or ritual performance.

sloka: suvṛttasya śarīrantu vyadhamanmukhavāyunā | svayameva jagatmraṣṭā dakṣiṇāgnistato'bhavat ||kanakasya śarīrantu dhmāpayāmāsa keśavaḥ | tato'bhūdgārhapatyāgniḥ pañcavaitānabhojanaḥ ||ghorasya tu vapuḥ śambhurdhmāpayāmāsa vai svayam | tata āhavanīyo'gnistatkṣaṇāt samajāyata ||etaistribhirjagat vyāptaṃ trimūlaṃ sakalaṃ jagat | etat yatra trayaṃ nityaṃ tiṣṭhati dbijasattamāḥ |
translation: The self of one who has performed virtuous deeds is freed from old age by itself; then, Keśava became the fire of the household. When Śambhu himself made the dreadful body disappear, the Āhavanīya fire arose instantly. Thus, the whole world is pervaded by these three: the fire of the household, the Āhavanīya fire, and the fire of self-mortification; when all three reside eternally in the best of the seeds (i.e., the virtuous person), the entire creation exists.

sloka: evaṃ yajñavarāhasya śarīraṃ yajñatāmagāt | yajñarūpeṇa sakalamāpyāyitumidaṃ jagat ||
translation: In this way, the physical form of Yajñavaraha (Lord Vishnu) has attained the nature of yajna (sacrifice); indeed, through its form as a yajna, it pervades and nourishes the entire world.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: Sacrifice, according to the scriptures, is the relinquishment of belongings. It is called "agnihotra" when those belongings are offered into the fire as they are being abandoned.

sloka: upaviṣṭahomā svāhākārapradānā juhotayaḥ
translation: Seated and performing a fire ritual, he offers oblations with the syllable "svāhā" as the auspicious exclamation.

sloka: savaṣaṭkārāsu tiṣṭhandakṣiṇata udaṅprāṅ vaṣaṭkṛte
translation: During the recitation of the Savashtakara formulas, standing to the south or to the west of the altar at the time of the Udanka and Pragvasathkreta.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four priests named Darshapurnamasas, Adhvaryu, Brahma, Hotr, and Agnidhra.

sloka: pākayajñānyajennityaṃ haviryajñāṃśca nityaśaḥ | somāṃśca vidhipūrveṇa ya iccheddharmamavyayam|
translation: One who regularly performs the new-moon and full-moon sacrificial rituals, the periodic fire-sacrifices, and follows the established rules for offering soma juice, seeks to establish an unchanging (eternal) righteousness.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛksāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The union of sacrificial ingredients, the priest's fee, and the senses (of the animal being sacrificed), is called a sacrifice.

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: This is surely an unblemished one who has performed his duties towards the wife.

sloka: vrīhīnyavānvā haviṣi
translation: Made of unbroken grains of barley is the havis (offering).

sloka: pāṇigrahaṇādiragnistamaupāsanamityācakṣate tasmingṛhyāṇi karmāṇi kriyante tasyaupāsanenāhitāgnitvaṃ
translation: The ritual acts such as taking hold of the hand (during marriage ceremony) are called preliminary worship; when performed with that (worship), they say, arises the state of being free from residual effects of actions.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: Included in that are the seven domestic sacrifices: Aupasana, Homo, Vaisvadeva, Parvana, Masika, Pitramedha, Sarpa and Rishabha offerings.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: Now, the five great sacrifices: the sacrifice to the gods is what one offers in the fire; the sacrifice to beings is what one portions out as alms; the sacrifice to ancestors is what one gives to the forefathers; the sacrifice through study is what one studies and mentally recites; the sacrifice to men is what one gives to human society. Thus, let one perform these constituent sacrifices.

sloka: vidārite varāhasya kāye bhargeṇa tatkṣaṇāt | brahmaviṣṇuśivā devāḥ sarvaiśca pramathaiḥ saha | ninyurjalāt samuddhṛtya tat śarīraṃ nabhaḥ prati | tadvibhejuḥ śarīrantu viṣṇoścakreṇa khaṇḍaśaḥ | tasyāṅga sandhito yajñājātāste vai pṛthakpṛthak | yasmād yasmācca ye yajñāstat śṛṇvantu maharṣayaḥ| bhrūnāsāsandhinā jāto jyotiṣṭomo mahādhvaraḥ | hanuśravaṇasandhyostu vahniṣṭomo vyajāyata | cakṣurbhruvoḥ sandhinā tu vrātyastomo vyajāyata | āyuḥ paugarbhavastomastasya potroṣṭha sandhinā | vṛddhastoma vṛhatstomau jihvāmūlādvyajāyata | atirātraṃ savairājamadhojihvāntarādabhūt | adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pidvayajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo valibhauto nṛyajño'tidhipajatam | snānaṃ tarpaṇaparvyantaṃ nityayajñāśca sāṃśaḥ | kaṇṭhasandheḥ samutpannā jihvāto vidhayastathā | yavājimedho mahāmedho naramedhastathaiva ca | prāṇihiṃsākarā ye'nye te kṣātāḥ pādasandhitaḥ | rājasūyo'tha kārīrī vājapeyastathaivaca | pṛṣṭhasandhau samutpannā grahayajñāstathaiva ca |
translation: When Varaha's body was lifted from the water by Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva along with all the ghosts, they divided his limbs. From different parts of his body arose various sacrifices such as Jyotishtoma, Vahniṣṭoma, Vrātyastoma, Ayus, Paugarbha, Vṛddhastoma, Vṛhatstoma, Atirātra, Savani, Brahmayajña, Pidvayajña, Tarpaṇa, Homa, Daiva, Valibhauta, Nṛyajna, Snāna, Grahayajña, and others. Some were situated in the throat, some in the head, some in the arms, some in the chest, some in the legs, some in the waist, some in the feet, some in the back, and so on.

sloka: evaṃ yaḥ sarvabhūtāni brāhmaṇo nityaṃ arcati | sa gacchati paraṃ sthānaṃ tejomūrtiḥ pathā rjunā | | | |
translation: One who, as a brahmin, continually worships all beings, goes to the abode of light.

sloka: agnau gurāvātmani ca sarvabhūteṣvadhokṣajam | bhūtaiḥ svadhāmabhiḥ paśyedapraviṣṭaṃ praviṣṭavat || || evaṃ vidho brahmacārī vānaprastho yatirgṛhī | caran viditavijñānaḥ paraṃ brahmādhigacchati || ||
translation: The student who, in the fire, the teacher, and all beings sees the unchanging Atman; who perceives it as present and past in relation to the elements' inherent nature – such a knower of distinct knowledge, having gone through the stages of student, forest-dweller, and renunciate, attains the supreme Brahman.

sloka: ya॒masya̭ mā ya॒myaṃ kāma॒ āga̭ntsamā॒ne yonaṷ saha॒śeyyā̭ya | jā॒yeva॒ patyḙ ta॒nva̭ṃ riricyā॒ṃ vi ci̭dvṛheva॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: The one who should be mounted on the chariot in a battle, as well as at the time of procreation for the purpose of producing worthy offspring; indeed, he is the protector and enjoyer of wealth.

sloka: na ti̭ṣṭhanti॒ na ni mi̭ṣantye॒te de॒vānā॒ṃ spaśa̭ i॒ha ye cara̭nti | a॒nyena॒ madā̭hano yāhi॒ tūya॒ṃ tena॒ vi vṛ̭ha॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: Those who do not worship nor praise the gods here, nor do they touch (respect) them; go to meet them with a single resolve, through which you will both prosper and win.

sloka: ā ghā॒ tā ga̭cchā॒nutta̭rā yu॒gāni॒ yatra̭ jā॒maya̭: kṛ॒ṇava॒nnajā̭mi | upa̭ barbṛhi vṛṣa॒bhāya̭ bā॒huma॒nyami̭cchasva subhage॒ pati॒ṃ mat ||
translation: Oh gâtâ, go to the yugas where Kṛṇavannajâmi resides; with Vṛṣabhāya's permission, eagerly seek out the husband, the fortunate one.

sloka: na vā ṷ te ta॒nvā̭ ta॒nvaṃ saṃ pa̭pṛcyāṃ pā॒pamā̭hu॒ryaḥ svasā̭raṃ ni॒gacchā̭t | a॒nyena॒ matpra॒muda̭: kalpayasva॒ na te॒ bhrātā̭ subhage vaṣṭye॒tat ||
translation: Indeed, he should not hastily seek to protect himself with your help, dear friend. Rather, arrange for him a suitable marriage using someone else's daughter, not your own sister.

sloka: ayane viṣuve caiva ṣaḍaśītimukheṣu ca| candrasūryoparāge ca dattamakṣayamucyate||
translation: On the solstices, at the six-month intervals, and at the junctions of the sun and moon, it is said to be given and imperishable.

sloka: śatamindukṣaye dānaṃ sahasrantu dinakṣaye | viṣuve śatasahasraṃ vyatīpātetvantakam ||
translation: A hundred coins in a battle of wits, a thousand during the day's end, in times of calamity a hundred thousand, such is the fee to ward off danger.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Quenching the Brahmins' thirst with payasam, she (Arundhati) satisfied them and then went on to attain the highest world.

sloka: āhāraṃ maithunaṃ nidrāṃ sandhyākāle tu varjjayet | karma cādhyayanañcaiva tathā dānapratigrahau |
translation: In the twilight, one should avoid eating, sexual activity, sleeping, and also studying and accepting or giving gifts.

sloka: tato'bhūttrivṛdaoṃkāro yo'vyaktaprabhavaḥ svarāṭyattalliṅgaṃ bhagavato brahmaṇaḥ paramātmanaḥ ||
translation: Then arose the creation of the three worlds, which has its origin in the unmanifest and is self-existent, from the subtle form of the divine Lord Brahman.

sloka: svadhāmno brāhmaṇaḥ sākṣādvācakaḥ paramātmanaḥ sa sarvamantropaniṣadvedabījaṃ sanātanam ||
translation: The brahmin is the manifestation of the eternal seed of all mantras and knowledge, being the authentic speaker of the supreme self's truth.

sloka: tenāsau caturo vedāṃścaturbhirvadanairvibhuḥ savyāhṛtikānsaoṃkārāṃścāturhotravivakṣayā || ||
translation: By that powerful one, the four Vedas are fully grasped with the help of four mouths; and also, the various ritual gestures and the four fire-related rituals.

sloka: te paramparayā prāptāstattacchiṣyairdhṛtavrataiḥ caturyugeṣvatha vyastā dvāparādau maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: These [te] sacred texts (vidyas) were passed down through succession (paramparayaa praptaah), and in the four ages they were distributed by great sages with steadfast vows (dhrita-vrataih caturyugeshu athava). In the second age (dvaparaadau maha-rshibhih), specifically.

sloka: parāśarātsatyavatyāmaṃśāṃśakalayā vibhuḥ avatīrṇo mahābhāga vedaṃ cakre caturvidham || asmin yuge kṛto vyāsaḥ pārāśaryaḥ parantapaḥ| dvaipāyana iti khyāto viṣṇoraṃśaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||
translation: Born from Atri and Anasuya, the all-powerful Parashara descended and divided the Vedas into four parts. In this age, he who is known as Vyasa, the scion of the Parashara lineage and an avatar of Vishnu, composed the Vedas in their current form.

sloka: tatrargvedadharaḥ pailaḥ sāmago jaiminiḥ kaviḥ | vaiśaṃpāyana evaiko niṣṇāto yajuṣāmuta || || atharvāṅ‌girasāmāsīt sumanturdāruṇo muniḥ |
translation: There, Paila is the bearer of the Rigveda, Jaimini the sage knowledgeable in Sama Veda; Vaisampayana alone is proficient in Yajur Veda; Sumantu and Daruṇo are the merged selves of Atharva and Angirasa.

sloka: pādenārthena copetā vṛttabaddhā mantrā ṛcaḥ| gītirūpā mantrāḥ sāmāni| vṛttagītivarjitatvena praśliṣṭapaṭhitā mantrā yajūṃṣi|
translation: Consisting of verses and chants, the mantras are to be recited with meaning and in accordance with their designated rules. The Samans are melodic mantras, while the Yajuses are those mantras that are devoid of melodious elements and are purely functional in nature.

sloka: śabdātirikta śabdopajīvipramāṇātiriktaṃ ca yatpramāṇaṃ tajjanyapramitiviṣayānatiriktārthako yo yastadanyatve sati āmuṣmikasukhajanakoccāraṇakatve sati janyajñānājanyo yo pramāṇaśabdastattvaṃ vedatvam iti ca prācīnastallakṣaṇamuktam |
translation: That which serves as a means of knowledge, independent of words and their referents, and is concerned with the determination of the class of a particular object - that is called "jnyapramiti." This term "jnyapramiti" was defined in such a way by ancient scholars.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: You, who nourishes the ṛcas (Vedic hymns), are being praised as you bloom in all directions. Brahmā speaks of you in the assembly, and you have measured out the measure of the yajña.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda ātharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśirdaivo
translation: The names are Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, Atharvanangirasas, and the fifth Veda is Itihasa-Purana (epics and ancient tales).

sloka: purāṇaṃ pañcamo veda iti brahmānuśāsanam
translation: The fifth Veda is the ancient Purana, as instructed by Brahma.

sloka: ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvākhyā vedāścatvāra uddhṛtāḥ | itihāsapurāṇaṃ ca pañcamo veda ucyate || ||
translation: The four Vedas, namely Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda, and the fifth one, Itihasa-Purana, are thus known.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca | taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭamaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇam | viṣīdantamidaṃ vākyamuvāca madhusūdanaḥ || ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Seeing him (Duryodhana) with tear-filled eyes, filled with compassion, Madhusudana (Krishna) spoke this words.

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | kutastvā kaśmalamidaṃ viṣame samupasthitam | anāryajuṣṭamasvargyamakīrtikaramarjuna || ||
translation: The Blessed One said: Where has this meanness befallen you, O Arjuna, at a time like this, which is unbefitting of a nobleman and brings disrepute?

sloka: kla‍aibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate | kṣudraṃ hṛdayadaurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa || ||
translation: Don't succumb to cowardice, O Partha! This small-hearted weakness does not become you. Cast it off and arise, scorcher of foes!

sloka: arjuna uvāca | kathaṃ bhīṣmamahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ prati yotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana || ||
translation: Arjuna said: "How, O Madhusudana, should I fight in battle against Bhishma and Drona, both worthy of worship, with arrows?"

sloka: gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyamapīha loke | hatvārthakāmāṃstu gurūnihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhirapradigdhān || ||
translation: To enjoy great prosperity, it is better to beg from the great-souled teachers than to rob ordinary persons in this world. But after killing the covetous teachers themselves, one may enjoy tainted pleasures with their wealth.

sloka: na caitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo yadvā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ || ||
translation: Indeed, we do not know whether these (the Kauravas) are superior or we are. Whether we will conquer them or they will conquer us, in either case, those who are standing firm in front of us, the Dhartarastras, after killing whom we do not wish to live.

sloka: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ | yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṃ brūhi tanme śiṣyaste'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam || ||
translation: Afflicted by the flaw of miserliness, I ask you, O Dharma-deluded one, please tell me decisively what is beneficial for me. I am your disciple; teach me, I have sought refuge in you.

sloka: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyādya cchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāvasapatnamṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇāmapi cādhipatyam || ||
translation: I do not see any enjoyment in the senses that could immediately delight me; only after attaining a powerful kingdom on earth and sovereignty over the gods does it appear.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca evamuktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa | na yotsya iti govindamuktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha || ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the scorcher of foes, Gudakesa remained silent after saying "I will not fight" to Govinda.

sloka: tamuvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasanniva bhārata | senayorubhayormadhye viṣīdantamidaṃ vacaḥ || ||
translation: Then Hṛṣīkeśa (Lord Kṛṣṇa) spoke up, smilingly, in the midst of both armies, to the downhearted Bhārata (Arjuna).

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | aśocyānanvaśocastvaṃ prajñāvādāṃśca bhāṣase | gatāsūnagatāsūṃśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ || ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: Do not lament for the deceased or the yet to be born, and wise ones do not mourn such things.

sloka: na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param || ||
translation: Neither have I ever not existed, nor have you, nor these kings; none of us had a beginning, we all exist perpetually.

sloka: dehino'sminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā | tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati || ||
translation: The embodied one within this body experiences childhood, youth, and old age; and even after reaching another body, the wise one is not confused.

sloka: mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ | āgamāpāyino'nityāstāṃstitikṣasva bhārata || ||
translation: The fleeting sensations of touch, O Kaunteya, caused by cold, heat, pleasure, and pain - enduring them steadfastly, is your duty, Bharata.

sloka: yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha | samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so'mṛtatvāya kalpate || ||
translation: The wise one who is not troubled by these (bodily) beings, O best among men, who considers pleasure and pain equally, is considered to be eligible for immortality.

sloka: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayorapi dṛṣṭo'ntastvanayostattvadarśibhiḥ || ||
translation: For the wise who truly see, there is no existence of the unreal, nor of the real's non-existence. Both are clearly seen to be negated by those who truly perceive the nature of things.

sloka: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino'prameyasya tasmādyudhyasva bhārata || ||
translation: These bodies are said to be perishable, but the one who dwells in the body is indestructible and immeasurable. Therefore, strive for yoga, O Bharata.

sloka: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate || ||
translation: One who knows the killer, and one who thinks it has been killed – both do not understand. It does not kill nor is it killed.

sloka: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācinnāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato'yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre || ||
translation: It is never born nor dies, it does not come into being or cease to be; ancient, primeval, unchanging, infinite - it does not perish when the body is destroyed.

sloka: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam |kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam || ||
translation: How, O Partha, can someone harm or destroy that which is eternal and indestructible - the imperishable Veda?

sloka: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇānyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī || ||
translation: Just as a person discards old clothes and puts on new ones, similarly the embodied soul casts off old bodies and enters into new ones.

sloka: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṃ kledayantyāpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ || || acchedyo'yamadāhyo'yamakledyo'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo'yaṃ sanātanaḥ || ||
translation:
This is not severed by weapons, not burned by fire,
Not wet by water, nor dried by wind. It is unbreakable and immutable,
Ever present, all-pervading, steadfast and ancient.

sloka: avyakto'yamacintyo'yamavikāryo'yamucyate | tasmādevaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitumarhasi || ||
translation: This unmanifested, unthinkable, and unchanging entity is said to be inexplicable. Therefore, having known it, you should not grieve.

sloka: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyurdhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmādaparihārye'rthe na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: Surely, death is inevitable for the one who has taken birth, and birth is certain for the one who has died. Therefore, you should not grieve over something that is unavoidable.

sloka: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata | avyaktanidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā || ||
translation: What is the reason for lamentation, O Bharata, when all created things in their manifest and unmanifest forms ultimately rest in the unmanifest?

sloka: āścaryavatpaśyati kaścidena māścaryavadvadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścaryavaccainamanyaḥ śa‍ṛṇoti śrutvāpyenaṃ veda na caiva kaścit || ||
translation: Some perceive the wondrous, others speak of it, some hear of it as astonishing, but after hearing it, no one truly understands.

sloka: dehī nityamavadhyo'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata| tasmātsarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: The indweller, O Bharata, is forever invulnerable in every body. Therefore, you should not grieve over any being.

sloka: svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi | dharmyāddhi yuddhācchreyo'nyatkṣatriyasya na vidyate || ||
translation: Having considered one's own duty, you should not hesitate. For a warrior, there is nothing superior to righteous warfare.

sloka: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddhamīdṛśam || ||
translation: O Partha, fortunate Kshatriyas obtain such a battle, which has spontaneously presented itself and is like the gateway to heaven.

sloka: atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: If you do not carry out this righteous battle, then abandoning your duty and honor, you will incur sin.

sloka: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtirmaraṇādatiricyate || ||
translation: Even the immortal beings will speak ill of you, while good reputation is considered to be the ornament of one who is well-behaved, even after death.

sloka: bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ | yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam || ||
translation: Feared by the great charioteers due to your courage, you will be considered worthy of respect by those who regard you highly and follow you without delay.

sloka: avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantastava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim || ||
translation: Many will utter unacceptable words against you, criticizing your abilities; what could be more distressing than this?

sloka: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmāduttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ || ||
translation: Slain, you will attain heaven; victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, O Kaunteya, stand up and resolvedly engage in battle.

sloka: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, and victory and defeat as equal, prepare for battle in this way, you will not incur sin.

sloka: eṣā te'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi || ||
translation: This is the understanding that I have explained to you in the context of Sankhya philosophy; now listen, O Partha, to the understanding that is relevant for yoga: with this understanding, you can shake off the bondage of actions.

sloka: nehābhikramanāśo'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpamapyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt || ||
translation: There is no failure here, nor any loss; even a little advancement in this duty saves one from great fear.

sloka: vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana | bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo'vyavasāyinām || ||
translation: Only a few have a resolute intellect among the Kurus, O son of the king, for the minds of those who lack decisiveness are many-branched and endless.

sloka: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām | kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati || || bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate || ||
translation: For those who are devoted to desires and focused on attaining heavenly pleasures, and for whom the results of actions are dominant; for those who are engrossed in and attached to enjoying material prosperity and sense gratification, a one-pointed decision-making faculty does not arise in spiritual contemplation.

sloka: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān || || yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake | tāvānsarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ || || karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karmaphalaheturbhūrmā te saṅgo'stvakarmaṇi || ||
translation: The Vedas deal with the three gunas, but become transcendent, O Arjuna. Be free from opposites, ever established in pure being, and free from concern for gain and loss. For the enlightened one, knowledge is the sole authority in all matters; never be attached to the results of actions. Do not let the fruit of action be your motive, nor let yourself become identified with action, nor allow motivations to taint your actions.

sloka: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim‌ || ||
translation: Arjuna said: "What is the language of a person established in wisdom and focused in meditation, O Keshava? How does such a steadfast person speak, and how do they behave?"

sloka: bhagavañjāyate tīvraṃ cintayānasya suvrata || karmapākaphalaṃ yasminmānuṣairupabhujyate|||| ñāē īṁ ā || āṁ āṣē||||
translation: The fruit of actions is experienced by humans in extreme contemplation of which the blessed one is born.

sloka: ṛṣiruddālakirdīkṣāmupagamya tataḥ sutam| tvaṃ māmupacarasveti nāciketamabhāṣata||
translation: After initiating the sacrificial student (by performing upanayana), the revered sage then approached his son Naciketa. He said to him, "Now, serve me."

sloka: tadā kṣamasveti prārthayamānasyaiva tasya nāciketasya deho gatasatvo bhūmau nyapatat patitaṃ sutaṃ dṛṣṭvā pitāpi kiṃ mayānuṣṭhitaṃ pāpeneti bruvan bhūmau nipapāta
translation: Upon seeing his dead son, Naciketas, fallen to the ground, after praying for his forgiveness, the father questioned himself, "What sin have I committed?"

sloka: na dṛṣyate mānuṣaṃ te vapuḥ
translation: Your human form is not visible.

sloka: yasminvṛkṣe supalāśe devaiḥ sampibate yamaḥ | atrā no viśpati: pitā purāṇā~ anu venati ||
translation: In which sacred fig tree Vruksha, Yama dwells with the gods; there our ancient father, the protector, pays his respects.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: The one known as Vṛtra, referred to as Megha in etymology and Twāṣṭra among the Āsuras; the mixing of water and light creates the function of rain-making, which results in war-indicating omens through that very agency.

sloka: jaṭādhīstīvratapā brahmavādisabhāpatiḥ aṅkīkṛtya sriyaṃ cāste gatahrīḥ prākṛte yathā prāyaśaḥ prākṛtāścāpi sriyaṃ rahasi bibhrati | ayaṃ mahāvratadharo bibhrarti sadasi sriyam
translation: Just as ordinary people typically display their wealth in public, so too does the revered Brahmanavadisabhpati, who is adorned with matted hair and observes ascetic vows, publicly display his prosperity. Even those who are ordinary possess wealth, but they usually keep it concealed in private. This great upholder of austere vows also displays his prosperity openly.

sloka: nāyamarhati vaikuṇṭha pādamūlopasarpaṇam sambhāvitamatiḥ stabdhaḥ sādhubhiḥ paryupāsitam ataḥ pāpīyasīṃ yonimāsurīṃ yāhi durmate yatheha bhūyo na kartā putra kilbiṣamjajñe tvaṣṭurdakṣiṇādnau dānavīṃ yonimāśritaḥ vṛtra ityabhivikhyāto jñānavijñānasaṃyutaḥ
translation: A resolute and self-confident person, who considers reaching the abode of Vaikuṇṭha as possible, should not approach the sinful womb of the demoniac *asuri* race. Go, O wicked one, to the womb of the *danava* race that you have taken refuge in, for you are the one known as Vṛtra, endowed with knowledge and realization.

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Perceiving the unblinking one (Indra) spreading out in the sky, illuminating while being illuminated by the seven rays, we strike it with our thunderbolt, but it remains unbroken.

sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: May the waters, which are the best on earth and flow expansively in the middle of salilas (fluids), along with Indra who hurls lightning and the bull-like Vrishabha, assume their divine form for our benefit.

sloka: i॒damasmi॒ tatte॒ pra dāsyā॒mīti॒ tvī
translation: I am present here, ready to give (it) to you.

sloka: āhāranidrābhayamaithunaṃ ca samānametatpaśubhirnarāṇām | dharmo hi teṣāmadhiko viśeṣo dharmeṇa hīnāḥ paśubhiḥ samānāḥ ||
translation: The four pursuits - eating, sleeping, fearing, and mating - are common to both humans and animals. What distinguishes humans from animals is their adherence to dharma (duty/ethics), for without it, they are no better than animals.

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, cleanliness, and control of the senses; these are summarized as dharma (righteousness) by Manu in the four varnas (castes).

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: Patience, forgiveness, self-control, honesty, cleanliness, sense restraint, wisdom, knowledge, truthfulness, and absence of anger - these are the ten characteristics of righteousness.

sloka: na rājyaṃ na rājā'sīnna daṇḍayo na ca dāṇḍika: dharmeṇaiva prajāssarvā rakṣanti sma parasparam
translation: Neither the kingdom nor the king, nor the wielder of the rod nor the executioner; they all protect people only through dharma.

sloka: prajanārthaṃ striyaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ saṃtānārthaṃ ca mānavaḥ | tasmātsādhāraṇo dharmaḥ śrutau patnyā sahoditaḥ | | | |
translation: Women were created for the welfare of the world and men for the purpose of continuing the lineage; hence, monogamy is the common duty laid down in scriptures.

sloka: dharme cārthe ca kāme ca nāticaritavyā tvayeyam |
translation: In duty, interest, and desire, you should not deviate from this (path).

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Tranquility, self-control, austerity, purity, forbearance, and uprightness, as well as knowledge, wisdom, and natural duty towards Brahman, are the qualities [that one should cultivate].

sloka: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Valor, brilliance, steadfastness, foresight, and not retreating in battle, as well as generosity and the inherent nature of ruling, are all characteristic of the kshatriya duty.

sloka: kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: The occupation of farming, tending cows, and trade is the innate duty of a Vaishya; service and labor are the innate duties of a Shudra.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucaṃ indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyaṃ akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten characteristics of dharma are: courage, forbearance, self-control, honesty, purity, restraint of the senses, wisdom, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: īśā vāsyamidaṃ sarvaṃ yatkiṃ ca jagatyāṃ jagat | tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam || ||
translation: Everything in the moving and non-moving world is owned by the Supreme Lord. Therefore, having taken only what is necessary, should one enjoy. Do not covet anyone's wealth.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation: Trees bear fruit for the benefit of others, rivers flow for the benefit of others, and cows yield milk for the benefit of others. This body too should be used for the welfare of others. Speak the truth, follow dharma, do not be negligent in your studies, give respect and wealth to the teacher, do not harm any being, do not be negligent in speaking the truth or following dharma, and do not be neglectful in doing what is beneficial or in your studies and teachings.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: One should not be negligent towards the duties of worshiping gods and ancestors. Consider your teacher and guest as gods. Perform only those actions that are admirable, and nothing else. Whatever good deeds we have, you should take care of those, and nothing else. For someone seeking happiness, there is no knowledge; for someone seeking knowledge, there is no happiness. The one pursuing happiness should give up knowledge; the one pursuing knowledge should give up happiness.

sloka: vivītasthalakedāraṣaṇḍakhalaveśmavāhanakoṣṭhānāṃ pūrvaṃpūrvaṃ ābādhaṃ saheta || || samāhartṛvannāgariko nagaraṃ cintayet || || daśakulīṃ gopo viṃśatikulīṃ catvāriṃśatkulīṃ vā || || sa tasyāṃ strīpuruṣāṇāṃ jātigotranāmakarmabhiḥ jaṅghaagraṃ āyavyayau ca vidyāt || || evaṃ durgacaturbhāgaṃ sthānikaścintayet || ||
translation: The supervisor of the treasury, while regularly examining the variously arranged boxes and chests containing coins, should mentally consider: whether there have been any previous irregularities; a group of ten, twenty, or thirty such containers; and in each of them, at the top of the stack, he should note the names and gotras of the men and women involved in their handling. Similarly, when examining a fortified city, one should also take into account its fourfold defensive measures.

sloka: bhūtapūrvaṃ abhūtapūrvaṃ vā janapadaṃ paradeśaapavāhanena svadeśaabhiṣyandavamanena vā niveśayet || ||
translation: Either by bringing something unprecedented or by causing harm to the people of a foreign land or one's own country, none should settle/establish (themselves).

sloka: anyonyaārakṣaṃ niveśayet || ||
translation: Should place protective care towards each other.

sloka: aṣṭaśatagrāmyā madhye sthānīyam | catuhśatagrāmyā droṇamukham | dviśatagrāmyāḥ kārvaṭikam | daśagrāmīsaṃgraheṇa saṃgrahaṃ sthāpayet || ||
translation: In a group of 180, the one who stands out; in a group of 400, the one who resembles Droṇa; in a group of 200, the one hailing from Kārvaṭa; should assume leadership in an assembly of ten.

sloka: niveśasamakālaṃ yathāāgatakaṃ vā parihāraṃ dadyāt || ||
translation: At the time of settling, one should give back what was received, as due or at the proper time.

sloka: hradasya vā aviśoṣasyāṅke |
translation: On the surface of the undried, unmoving water.

sloka: vṛttaṃ dīrghaṃ caturaśraṃ vā
translation: A square or long rectangle (in shape).

sloka: ṣaḍdaṇḍaucchritaṃ avaruddhaṃ taddviguṇaviṣkambham |
translation: Supported by six pillars, unobstructed, and twice its height - this is the description. (The context of this verse is not provided, so I am assuming it describes some physical structure.)

sloka: tasya parikhāstisro daṇḍaantarāḥ kārayetcaturdaśa dvādaśa daśaiti daṇḍānvistīrṇāḥ |
translation: The girth of its post is measured by three hand-spans, with a height of fourteen, twelve, or ten hand-spans.

sloka: trayaḥ prācīnā rājamārgāstraya udīcīnā iti vāstuvibhāgaḥ || ||
translation: The three royal paths to the east and three to the north, this is what is meant by the division of the verse.

sloka: daśakulīvāṭaṃ kūpasthānaṃ || ||
translation: A toilet located at the foot of a ten-pillared bower.

sloka: pitṝṇāṃ māsikaṃ śrāddhaṃ anvāhāryaṃ vidurbudhāḥ || ||
translation: A monthly shraddha ceremony performed for ancestors, the wise and learned know this to be the follow-up rite.

sloka: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā bhūtānyatithayastathā | āśāsate kuṭumbibhyastebhyaḥ kāryaṃ vijānatā || ||
translation: The seers, forefathers, and gods, as well as the departed ancestors, expect hospitality from the family members who are aware of their duties.

sloka: daivakāryāddvijātīnāṃ pitṛkāryaṃ viśiṣyate | daivaṃ hi pitṛkāryasya pūrvaṃ āpyāyanaṃ smṛtam
translation: The primary duty of a dvija (twice-born) is to perform daiva duties, while the performance of pitr duties is considered superior. Indeed, the successful completion of pitr duties is remembered as preceding the daiva duties.

sloka: pitṛyajñaṃ tu nirvartya vipraścandrakṣaye'gnimān | piṇḍānvāhāryakaṃ śrāddhaṃ kuryānmāsānumāsikam || ||
translation: Having performed the shraddha ritual for the pitryajna, and offered oblations with rice-balls and sesame to the fire during the waning moon, one should perform the monthly rituals.

sloka: kṛṣṇapakṣe daśamyādau varjayitvā caturdaśīm | śrāddhe praśastāstithayo yathaitā na tathetarāḥ
translation: On the eleventh day in the dark fortnight, having excluded the fourteenth day, those who are performing the Śrāddha ritual should be seated and offered the Pindas in this manner, not otherwise.

sloka: yukṣu kurvandinarkṣeṣu sarvānkāmānsamaśnute | ayukṣu tu pitṝnsarvānprajāṃ prāpnoti puṣkalām
translation: A fertile farmer enjoys all desired fruits in this and the next world, while an infertile one leaves behind all his offspring wealthy.

sloka: yathā caivāparaḥ pakṣaḥ pūrvapakṣādviśiṣyate | tathā śrāddhasya pūrvāhṇādaparāhṇo viśiṣyate
translation: Just as one side prevails over the other in a debate, similarly, the pre- and post-death rites of shraddha are distinguished.

sloka: rātrau śrāddhaṃ na kurvīta rākṣasī kīrtitā hi sā | sandhyayorubhayoścaiva sūrye caivācirodite
translation: One should not perform the Śrāddha ritual at night, for it is known as Rākṣasī. Also, it should not be performed during the sandhyas (dawn and dusk) or directly after sunrise.

sloka: anena vidhinā śrāddhaṃ trirabdasyeha nirvapet | hemantagrīṣmavarṣāsu pāñcayajñikamanvaham
translation: With this procedure, the Sraddha ceremony should be performed three times in the rainy season and in both the summer and winter seasons, along with the five daily fire-sacrifices.

sloka: kuryād āparapakṣīyaṃ māsi prauṣṭhapade dvijaḥ | śrāddhaṃ pitroryathāvittaṃ tad‍bandhūnāṃ ca vittavān || ||
translation: A twice-born person should perform secondary duties, such as offering obligations with rice cakes to the fire during the second half of the month and giving wealth to acquaintances.

sloka: saṃskārakālo jāyāyā apatyasyātmanastathā | pretasaṃsthā mṛtāhaśca karmaṇyabhyudaye nṛpa || ||
translation: The time for rituals is also the birth of one's own offspring, as well as the arrangement during the death rites of both the living and the deceased, O king.

sloka: kuryādaharahaḥ śrāddhaṃ annādyenodakena vā | payomūlaphalairvāpi pitṛbhyaḥ prītimāvahan || ||
translation: One should offer oblations to the ancestors daily, either with water, or with sesame seeds, or with rice, seeking their pleasure.

sloka: tilairvrīhiyavairmāṣairadbhirmūlaphalena vā | dattena māsaṃ tṛpyanti vidhivatpitaro nṛnām
translation: With sesame seeds, rice, beans, and superior fruits, as well as gifts given in accordance with ritual, parents of people are satisfied for a month.

sloka: yadeva tarpayatyadbhiḥ pitṝnsnātvā dvijottamaḥ | tenaiva kṛtsnaṃ āpnoti pitṛyajñakriyāphalam rājatairbhājanaireṣāṃ atho vā rajatānvitaiḥ | vāryapi śraddhayā dattaṃ akṣayāyopakalpate
translation: By offering oblations to the ancestors, the best of the twice-born one indeed obtains all the benefits of the sacrifice to the ancestors. Either with silver vessels or with those adorned with silver, even if offered only a small amount with faith, it becomes inexhaustible.

sloka: aparāhṇastathā darbhā vāstusaṃpādanaṃ tilāḥ | sṛṣṭirmṛṣṭirdvijāścāgryāḥ śrāddhakarmasu saṃpadaḥ
translation: At dusk, and also the preparation of grass and sesame seeds for dwellings; indeed, the most excellent twice-borns are engaged in funeral rites.

sloka: api naḥ sa kule bhūyādyo no dadyāttrayodaśīm | pāyasaṃ madhusarpirbhyāṃ prākchāye kuñjarasya ca yatkiṃ cinmadhunā miśraṃ pradadyāttu trayodaśīm | tadapyakṣayaṃ eva syādvarṣāsu ca maghāsu ca
translation: May he who is in our lineage and can bestow upon us the triodashi (eleventh day of the lunar fortnight) pāyasa (rice pudding) and madhusarpi (sweetmeat), mixed with honey, before the mahotsava (festival) of Kuñjara (an elephant), also give us a portion of that which is mixed with milk on that day; even that, if bestowed, would only amount to a temporary benefit during the Magha (lunar month) seasons.

sloka: yadyaddadāti vidhivatsamyakśraddhāsamanvitaḥ | tattatpitṝṇāṃ bhavati paratrānantamakṣayam
translation: If one gives properly, with full faith and devotion, then it becomes an infinite and imperishable gift to the ancestors.

sloka: teṣāmārakṣabhūtaṃ tu pūrvaṃ daivaṃ niyojayet | rakṣāṃsi hi vipralumpanti śrāddhamārakṣavarjitam daivādyantaṃ tadīheta pitrādyantaṃ na tadbhavet | pitrādyantaṃ tvīhamānaḥ kṣipraṃ naśyati sānvayaḥ
translation: The divine (daiva) should be established as the protector for them in the first place. Indeed, the protection (raksha) disappears if the shraddha ceremony is abandoned. One who neglects the rituals for ancestors will quickly suffer loss of lineage.

sloka: śuciṃ deśaṃ viviktaṃ ca gomayenopalepayet | dakṣināpravaṇaṃ caiva prayatnenopapādayet avakāśeṣu cokṣeṣu jalatīreṣu caiva hi | vivikteṣu ca tuṣyanti dattena pitaraḥ sadā
translation: He should smear a clean and secluded place with cow dung, and carefully make arrangements for the southern flow of water. He will always be pleased in solitary and pure places by giving gifts.

sloka: āsaneṣūpaklpteṣu barhiṣmatsu pṛthakpṛthak | upaspṛṣṭodakānsamyagviprāṃstānupaveśayet upaveśya tu tānviprānāsaneṣvajugupsitān | gandhamālyaiḥ surabhibhirarcayeddaivapūrvakam
translation: On separate deer skins, properly cleaned and arranged on uneven surfaces, the officiating priests should be seated. After they have been seated, unacceptable spots on the skins should be avoided. They should be respectfully decorated with fragrant garlands and offerings, in accordance with established tradition.

sloka: yeṣāmudakamānīya sapavitrāṃstilānapi | agnau kuryādanujñāto brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaiḥ saha
translation: For those (whose) water-purified sacrificial vessels and fires, even in the wilderness, are authorized by brahmanas together with a brahmana.

sloka: agneḥ somayamābhyāṃ ca kṛtvāpyāyanamāditaḥ | havirdānena vidhivatpaścātsaṃtarpayetpitṝn agnyabhāve tu viprasya pāṇāvevopapādayet | yo hyagniḥ sa dvijo viprairmantradarśibhirucyate na paitṛyajñiyo homo laukike'gnau vidhīyate | na darśena vinā śrāddhamāhitāgnerdvijanmanaḥ
translation: After performing the Agnistoma sacrifice along with the Soma sacrifice, one should offer oblations to the ancestors as prescribed. If there is no agnihotra ritual, then the pinda offering becomes necessary for the Brahmin. The fire that is referred to as agni by the Brahmins who are familiar with mantras is not meant for domestic use but for ancestral rituals. A Brahmin's pinda offering is incomplete without the presence of agni.

sloka: apasavyamagnau kṛtvā sarvamāvṛtya vikramam | apasavyena hastena nirvapedudakaṃ bhuvi trīṃstu tasmāddhaviḥśeṣātpiṇḍānkṛtvā samāhitaḥ | audakenaiva vidhinā nirvapeddakṣiṇāmukhaḥ
translation: Having offered oblations to the fire on the left side, having covered all action, and being firmly established; with the left hand should one donate water to the earth three times, then, after that, offerings should be made from the remainder of the rice ball according to the prescribed method, while facing the direction of the sunrise, having sipped water.

sloka: nyupya piṇḍāṃstatastāṃstu prayato vidhipūrvakam | teṣu darbheṣu taṃ hastaṃ nirmṛjyāllepabhāginām
translation: Placing the offering, he should approach those [fire altars] in order, as prescribed. After cleaning his hands, he should place his hand on the darbha grass [for the offering].

sloka: ācamyodakparāvṛtya trirāyamya śanairasūn | ṣaḍṛtūṃśca namaskuryātpitṝneva ca mantravat
translation: Having sipped water and thrice mentally purifying oneself, one should respectfully pay obeisance to the ancestors as if with a mantra.

sloka: udakaṃ ninayeccheṣaṃ śanaiḥ piṇḍāntike punaḥ | avajighrecca tānpiṇḍānyathānyuptānsamāhitaḥ piṇḍebhyastvalpikāṃ mātrāṃ samādāyānupūrvaśaḥ | tāneva viprānāsīnānvidhivatpūrvamāśayet
translation: Carefully squeezing out the water from the washed rice grains, one should repeatedly put them back into the water, then take them up grain by grain and place them aside in a measured quantity, following the traditional method; only then should they be offered to the Brahmins.

sloka: dhriyamāṇe tu pitari pūrveṣāṃ eva nirvapet | vipravadvāpi taṃ śrāddhe svakaṃ pitaramāśayet pitā yasya nivṛttaḥ syājjīveccāpi pitāmahaḥ | pituḥ sa nāma saṅkīrtya kīrtayetprapitāmaham pitāmaho vā tacchrāddhaṃ bhuñjītetyabravīnmanuḥ | kāmaṃ vā samanujñātaḥ svayaṃ eva samācaret
translation: "While performing the śrāddha ritual for the father, one should offer the oblations to the ancestors who have passed away before him. Having offered the oblations, he should then consider that father as one of the ancestors and partake in the ritual himself. Manu said: 'He should mention the name of his father or grandfather and offer them the oblations, saying "Let my father/grandfather partake in this śrāddha."' He may also perform the ritual on his own accord, as he sees fit."

sloka: teṣāṃ dattvā tu hasteṣu sapavitraṃ tilodakam | tatpiṇḍāgraṃ prayaccheta svadhaiṣāmastviti bruvan
translation: Having given the lump of sesame seed with a twisted thread held in their hands, one should place it at the forefront while saying "svadhā" for them.

sloka: pāṇibhyāṃ tūpasaṃgṛhya svayamannasya vardhitam | viprāntike pitṝndhyāyanśanakairupanikṣipet ubhayorhastayormuktaṃ yadannamupanīyate | tadvipralumpantyasurāḥ sahasā duṣṭacetasaḥ
translation: By personally receiving [food] with joined hands and offering it at the feet of the Brahmin during the sandhyavandana, what is eaten becomes spiritually uplifting; but if arrogant asuras fail to do so, their minds become impure.

sloka: guṇāṃśca sūpaśākādyānpayo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu | vinyasetprayataḥ pūrvaṃ bhūmāveva samāhitaḥ
translation: One should first and foremost set out, with a focused mind, the staples such as grains, vegetables, and fruits, as well as milk, ghee, and honey.

sloka: upanīya tu tatsarvaṃ śanakaiḥ susamāhitaḥ | pariveṣayeta prayato guṇānsarvānpracodayan
translation: Having properly taken in all those teachings, one should diligently put them into practice and stimulate the development of all virtues.

sloka: nāsramāpātayejjātu na kupyennānṛtaṃ vadet | na pādena spṛśedannaṃ na caitadavadhūnayet asraṃ gamayati pretānkopo'rīnanṛtaṃ śunaḥ | pādasparśastu rakṣāṃsi duṣkṛtīnavadhūnanam
translation: Let there be no downfall of the religious order, nor any anger, untruthful speech, touching undesirable things, or causing harm to creatures. The agitation of the departed ones is not caused by contact with the feet, but rather by wicked deeds and sinful actions.

sloka: yadyadroceta viprebhyastattaddadyādamatsaraḥ | brahmodyāśca kathāḥ kuryātpitṝṇāṃ etadīpsitam svādhyāyaṃ śrāvayetpitrye dharmaśāstrāṇi caiva hi | ākhyānānītihāsāṃśca purāṇāni khilāni ca harṣayedbrāhmaṇāṃstuṣṭo bhojayecca śanaiḥśanaiḥ | annādyenāsakṛccaitānguṇaiśca paricodayet
translation: Whatever is seen by a scholar that should be spoken of immediately to the wise; discussions about brahman should also be carried out. This is desired by the ancestors: to recite sacred texts, Vedas, and dharmaśāstras daily. He should gladden the brahmins by narrating tales, epics, puranas, and itihasas; keeping them satisfied, he should feed them slowly. He should cultivate these qualities and habits gradually, without a break.

sloka: vratasthamapi dauhitraṃ śrāddhe yatnena bhojayet | kutapaṃ cāsanaṃ dadyāttilaiśca vikirenmahīm trīṇi śrāddhe pavitrāṇi dauhitraḥ kutapastilāḥ | trīṇi cātra praśaṃsanti śaucamakrodhamatvarām
translation: Even if a son is observing a vow, he should diligently feed him during the shraddha ceremony; what a pity it would be if he does not offer a seat and water to the guests, as these three things are considered pure in the shraddha ceremony - the son, the seat, and the water. Here, they also praise someone who is calm, pure, and quick in action.

sloka: brāhmaṇaṃ bhikṣukaṃ vāpi bhojanārthamupasthitam | brāhmaṇairabhyanujñātaḥ śaktitaḥ pratipūjayet
translation: A brahmin or a mendicant, who has come for food, should be respectfully honored and offered food with the permission of brahmins, if one is capable.

sloka: sārvavarṇikamannādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā | samutsṛjedbhuktavatāmagrato vikiranbhuvi
translation: Washing off with water and then casting aside the impurities, one should make use of the cleaning property of all-color garments (i.e., washable clothes) first in the world.
