sloka: āsapiṇḍakriyākarma dvijāteḥ saṃsthitasya tu | adaivaṃ bhojayecchrāddhaṃ piṇḍam ekaṃ ca nirvapet sahapiṇḍakriyāyāṃ tu kṛtāyāmasya dharmataḥ | anayaivāvṛtā kāryaṃ piṇḍanirvapanaṃ sutaiḥ
translation: For a Brahmin who is established in his duties, feeding a guest and offering funeral oblations with a single pinda (ball of rice) is appropriate according to the rules of pindakriya. The duty of offering pinda should be performed by the son himself.

sloka: pṛṣṭvā svaditam ityevaṃ tṛptānācāmayettataḥ | ācāntāṃścānujānīyādabhito ramyatam iti
translation: Having tasted what was asked for and being satisfied, one should respectfully allow [them] to enjoy in peace, saying "please enjoy fully."

sloka: svadhāstvityeva taṃ brūyurbrāhmaṇāstadanantaram | svadhākāraḥ parā hyāṣīḥ sarveṣu pitṛkarmasu
translation: They should declare "svadhā" only, say the brāhmaṇas next; for 'svadhā' is the form of the rite applicable to all ancestral duties.

sloka: tato bhuktavatāṃ teṣāmannaśeṣaṃ nivedayet | yathā brūyustathā kuryādanujñātastato dvijaiḥ
translation: Having partaken, one should offer the remainder as instructed; that is how it should be done, following the instructions of the twice-born.

sloka: pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi
translation: In sacrificial rites, what is declared as "approved by the ancestors" is actually called "well-known in the world." Similarly, in auspicious ceremonies, what is referred to as "divinely pleasing" is actually known as "complete."

sloka: visṛjya brāhmaṇāṃstāṃstu niyato vāgyataḥ śuciḥ | dakṣiṇāṃ diśamākāṅkṣanyācetemānvarānpitṝn dātāro no'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatireva ca | śraddhā ca no mā vyagamadbahudeyaṃ ca no'stviti
translation: Having abandoned, with a firm resolve and pure heart, the traditional fees for the Brahmins, those who desire to give (dakṣiṇā) should aspire to donate in the southern direction. May our teachers and ritual fires constantly increase through this. Let our faith not diminish, and let abundance also be with us.

sloka: evaṃ nirvapaṇaṃ kṛtvā piṇḍāṃstāṃstadanantaram | gāṃ vipramajamagniṃ vā prāśayedapsu vā kṣipet piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ ke citparastādeva kurvate | vayobhiḥ khādayantyanye prakṣipantyanale'psu vā
translation: After preparing the offering, one should offer this handful of rice or give it to a brahmin, abandon it in the fire, or throw it in water. Some pious people actually prepare the offering; others may consume (the rice) with their companions or discard it in the fire or in water.

sloka: pativratā dharmapatnī pitṛpūjanatatparā | madhyamaṃ tu tataḥ piṇḍamadyātsamyaksutārthinī āyuṣmantaṃ sutaṃ sūte yaśomedhāsamanvitam | dhanavantaṃ prajāvantaṃ sāttvikaṃ dhārmikaṃ tathā prakṣālya hastāvācāmya jñātiprāyaṃ prakalpayet | jñātibhyaḥ satkṛtaṃ dattvā bāndhavānapi bhojayet
translation: A chaste wife, devoted to her husband, always engaged in the worship of her ancestors, moderation in eating, and fulfilling her duties, who is long-lived, has a son, is endowed with virtue, righteousness, wealth, progeny, and pure conduct; having thus ascertained through examination with hand and speech, one should establish such a one as a preceptor, after honoring the relatives and feeding the guests.

sloka: uccheṣaṇaṃ tu tattiṣṭhedyāvadviprā visarjitāḥ | tato gṛhabaliṃ kuryāditi dharmo vyavasthitaḥ
translation: Performing the final rites is the duty; after renouncing the world, the priests (brahmins) should conduct the ritual of establishing the sacred fire. This is the established rule of dharma.

sloka: prācīnāvītinā samyagapasavyamatandriṇā | pitryam ā nidhanātkāryaṃ vidhivaddarbhapāṇinā
translation: Performed correctly and without distraction by a careful follower of proper procedure, the ancestral duty is not to be abandoned.

sloka: dvau daive pitṛkārye trīnekaikamubhayatra vā | bhojayetsusamṛddho'pi na prasajjeta vistare || || satkriyāṃ deśakālau ca śaucaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃpadaḥ | pañcaitānvistaro hanti tasmānneheta vistaram || ||
translation: In performing divine and parental duties, one should give in two, three or at least one way in both. The prosperous one also should not decline when asked (for gifts). However, he should not elaborate (on the reasons for denial). Devotion, cleanliness, and following the conduct of a Brahmin are the five essentials; neglecting them is harmful, so one must not be overly ceremonious.

sloka: ekamapyāśayedvipraṃ pitrarthe pāñcayajñike || ||
translation: Even a single learned priest, attending to (his duties) in the five daily fire-sacrifices for the sake of his ancestors, is sufficient.

sloka: atyuṣṇaṃ sarvamannaṃ syādbhuñjīraṃste ca vāgyatāḥ | na ca dvijātayo brūyurdātrā pṛṣṭā havirguṇān yāvaduṣmā bhavatyannaṃ yāvadaśnanti vāgyatāḥ | pitarastāvadaśnanti yāvannoktā havirguṇāḥ yadveṣṭitaśirā bhuṅkte yadbhuṅkte dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ | sopānatkaśca yadbhuṅkte tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate | | | |
translation: Let the eager eat only that food which is extremely hot, until informed of its qualities and unfit for consumption. Let not the twice-born speak of the flaws of the offered food until the eaters have eaten their fill or declined it, eating with the right side of the mouth, or when they are sipping a drink.

sloka: jñānotkṛṣṭāya deyāni kavyāni ca havīṃṣi ca || || sahasraṃ hi sahasrāṇāmanṛcāṃ yatra bhuñjate | ekastānmantravitprītaḥ sarvānarhati dharmataḥ || || yatnena bhojayecchrāddhe bahvṛcaṃ vedapāragam | śākhāntagamathādhvaryuṃ chandogaṃ tu samāptikam || || eṣāmanyatamo yasya bhuñjīta śrāddhamarcitaḥ | pitṝṇāṃ tasya tṛptiḥ syācchāśvatī sāptapauruṣī || ||
translation: Poetic works and oblations should be offered to the one who is superior in knowledge. For, he who is well-versed in the Vedas partakes in thousands of hymns therein and enjoys them alone, being content. With effort, he should be fed and honored in a grand sacrificial ritual. This is the most concise form of the ritual for him, and through this, the satisfaction of his ancestors becomes eternal.

sloka: mātāmahaṃ mātulaṃ ca svasrīyaṃ śvaśuraṃ gurum | dauhitraṃ viṭpatiṃ bandhuṃ ṛtvigyājyau ca bhojayet || ||
translation: One should offer food to the mother, maternal uncle, sister, father-in-law, teacher, son-in-law, guest, friend, and the officiating priests during rituals.

sloka: jñānaniṣṭhā dvijāḥ ke cittaponiṣṭhāstathāpare | tapaḥsvādhyāyaniṣṭhāśca karmaniṣṭhāstathāpare || || jñānaniṣṭheṣu kavyāni pratiṣṭhāpyāni yatnataḥ | havyāni tu yathānyāyaṃ sarveṣveva caturṣvapi || || dūrādeva parīkṣeta brāhmaṇaṃ vedapāragam | tīrthaṃ taddhavyakavyānāṃ pradāne so'tithiḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation: Among the twice-born, some are steadfast in knowledge, while others are steadfast in meditation, austerity, and action. For those steadfast in knowledge, one should carefully establish scriptures; for those who perform rituals, one should do so as appropriate in all four cases. A brahmin who is an expert in the Vedas should be considered a sacred site for offerings of water, rituals, hymns, and scriptural studies. This is remembered as their observance on the occasion of such gifts.

sloka: na brāhmaṇaṃ parīkṣeta daive karmaṇi dharmavit | pitrye karmaṇi tu prāpte parīkṣeta prayatnataḥ || || aśrotriyaḥ pitā yasya putraḥ syādvedapāragaḥ | aśrotriyo vā putraḥ syātpitā syādvedapāragaḥ || || jyāyāṃsamanayorvidyādyasya syācchrotriyaḥ pitā | mantrasaṃpūjanārthaṃ tu satkāram itaro'rhati || ||
translation: In religious rituals, one shouldn't examine a Brahmin's competence; but in ancestral rites, one should carefully assess. If a father is unlearned in Vedas, his son becomes a non-Veda follower, or if the son is unlearned, the father becomes a non-Veda follower. In the matter of higher and lower knowledge, the one who is learned in Vedas is superior for the purpose of performing ritual worship with respect.

sloka: na śrāddhe bhojayenmitraṃ dhanaiḥ kāryo'sya saṃgrahaḥ | nāriṃ na mitraṃ yaṃ vidyāttaṃ śrāddhe bhojayeddvijam || || yasya mitrapradhānāni śrāddhāni ca havīṃṣi ca | tasya pretya phalaṃ nāsti śrāddheṣu ca haviḥṣu ca || || yaḥ saṃgatāni kurute mohācchrāddhena mānavaḥ | sa svargāccyavate lokācchrāddhamitro dvijādhamaḥ || || saṃbhojāni sābhihitā paiśācī dakṣiṇā dvijaiḥ | ihaivāste tu sā loke gaurandhevaikaveśmani || ||
translation: One should not invite a friend to a śrāddha ceremony with wealth; it is his duty to do so. One should never invite a woman or a friend to a śrāddha ceremony whom one has already invited as a dvija (twice-born). For him who invites such persons, there is no religious merit in the śrāddha ceremonies and sacrifices. A foolish person who conducts such a śrāddha inviting others becomes lowly and goes to a dark hell. The offerings made by non- dvijas (non-twice born) at a śrāddha are considered impure and are only meant for the lower realms; here in this very world, they are of no use.

sloka: etānvigarhitācārānapāṅkteyāndvijādhamān | dvijātipravaro vidvānubhayatra vivarjayet brāhmaṇo tvanadhīyānastṛṇāgniriva śāmyati | tasmai havyaṃ na dātavyaṃ na hi bhasmani hūyate
translation: The brāhmaṇa, who is the best among dvijas and knows better, should avoid these wicked people and keep away from them in both places. He should not give oblations to such a person, for offerings are not made to ashes.

sloka: avratairyaddvijairbhuktaṃ parivetrādibhistathā | apāṅkteyairyadanyaiśca tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate
translation: By non-observant dvijas, as well as by thieves and others, what is enjoyed is indeed consumed by protectionism.

sloka: somavikrayiṇe viṣṭhā bhiṣaje pūyaśoṇitam | naṣṭaṃ devalake dattamapratiṣṭhaṃ tu vārdhuṣau
translation: In the moon sacrifice, when staying at the physician's house, the holy healing substance that was given to the god's treasury is lost or not properly established; this is what I am asking about.

sloka: yattu vāṇijake dattaṃ neha nāmutra tadbhavet |
translation: That which is given in charity to merchants does not bear fruit here or hereafter.

sloka: prathitā pretakṛtyaiṣā pitryaṃ nāma vidhukṣaye | tasminyuktasyaiti nityaṃ pretakṛtyaiva laukikī || ||
translation: This is a well-known funeral rite called "pitrya" that is performed to extinguish the debt to the ancestors. It must always be performed as a worldly duty in such cases.

sloka: śrotriyāyaiva deyāni havyakavyāni dātṛbhiḥ | arhattamāya viprāya tasmai dattaṃ mahāphalam || || ekaikamapi vidvāṃsaṃ daive pitrye ca bhojayet | puṣkalaṃ phalamapnoti nāmantrajñānbahūnapi || || yatheriṇe bījamuptvā na vaptā labhate phalam | tathānṛce havirdattvā na dātā labhate phalam || || dātṝnpratigrahītṝṃśca kurute phalabhāginaḥ | viduṣe dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā vidhivatpretya ceha ca || ||
translation: Sacrificial offerings should be given to the one who is learned in the Vedas, for he is the most deserving of all. Such a gift bears great fruits. Even if only one learned person is fed, along with those who officiate and receive the offering, they will reap copious rewards, not just the giver. Just as a seed, when sown, does not yield fruit without cultivation, so too, one who has not studied the Vedas gains no reward from making sacrificial offerings. The givers and recipients of sacrificial offerings, by acting according to rule, share in the fruits thereof; by giving a fee to a knowledgeable teacher, as prescribed, they also partake in the rewards, both here and hereafter.

sloka: kāmaṃ śrāddhe'rcayenmitraṃ nābhirūpamapi tvarim | dviṣatā hi havirbhuktaṃ bhavati pretya niṣphalam || ||
translation: One should offer funerary oblations to a friend as if they were a loved one, even if they don't appear attractive or quick [in performing the ritual], for if an enemy partakes of the offering after the person's death, it becomes fruitless.

sloka: ta ete śreyasaḥ kālā nṝṇāṃ śreyovivardhanāḥ | kuryāt sarvātmanaiteṣu śreyo'moghaṃ tadāyuṣaḥ || || eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram || ||
translation: These are the auspicious moments for people, promoting their welfare and growth. One should make use of them to one's fullest capacity to attain success in life. Among these, (one should regularly perform) bathing, recitation of mantras, fire-offerings, vows, and worship of gods, brahmins, and pitrs (ancestors). Whatever is given (in charity) to them becomes fixed (as a source of merit) for eternity.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: Living either by truth or falsehood, one should always choose the path of truth over untruth. The pure and absolute truth, when pursued and consumed like nectar, brings about immortality. On the other hand, accepting alms (bhaikṣaṃ) through falsehood is considered impure and transient (mṛtaṃ). Trade (vāṇijyam) based on half-truths or deception is also to be shunned. Hence, one must avoid the livelihood of deceit and adopt service (sevā) as their way of life.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: A brahmin should always avoid evil, as should a king; a brahmin is one who is versed in all the Vedas, and a king is one who is devoted to all the gods.

sloka: vṛttiḥ saṅkarajātīnāṃ tattatkulakṛtā bhavet | acaurāṇāmapāpānāmantyajāntevasāyinām || ||
translation: The occupation (vrtti) of those born from mixed caste (sankara-jatinam) is determined by their ancestral lineage (tattat-kula); for those who are thieves and sinners (acauranam apapanam), their occupations (evasayinam) become inescapable.

sloka: vṛttyā svabhāvakṛtayā vartamānaḥ svakarmakṛt | hitvā svabhāvajaṃ karma śanairnirguṇatāmiyāt || ||
translation: Acting according to one's innate nature, engaged in one's own duties, and giving up inherent actions, he gradually attains to the state of being devoid of qualities.

sloka: jaghanyo nottamāṃ vṛttimanāpadi bhajennaraḥ | ṛte rājanyamāpatsu sarveṣāmapi sarvaśaḥ || ||
translation: Except in the case of inheriting a kingdom, no one should adopt the behavior of a lowly person, even if they are of a lower status.

sloka: kuśūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyām ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati
translation: Whether he possesses Kusha grass and grains or a water pot, whether he is engaged in the three sacred fires or is firmly established in the domestic ritual, among these four Brahmins performing the domestic sacrifice, one who excels in righteousness, known as the six-fold action, is considered the foremost. Some live with just two of them, while a few even with only the sacrificial ladle and Brahman.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ
translation: A householder brahmin should not invite a family member for meals, as the wise call it a blameworthy act of indulgence.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam
translation: A scholar should conduct themselves, with the primary aim of sustaining life, by adopting a lifestyle that is either completely harmless or minimizes harm to other beings. They should also accumulate wealth without causing any trouble to their body.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ
translation: Engaged in performing the agnihotra ritual, always offering oblations solely to the extended parvayana fire rituals, how can one who is focused and intent on their own duties not follow the ways of the world? They should lead a pure, simple, and self-satisfied brahminical way of life, seeking happiness through contentment, for contentment is the root of happiness, while its opposite is the root of unhappiness.

sloka: edhodakaṃ mūlaphalaṃ annaṃ abhyudyataṃ ca yat | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānmadhvathābhayadakṣiṇām āhṛtābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastādapracoditām | mene prajāpatirgrāhyāṃ api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ nāśnanti pitarastasya daśavarṣāṇi pañca ca | na ca havyaṃ vahatyagniryastāṃ abhyavamanyate
translation: "Prajapati considers it appropriate to accept alms that are offered with sincerity, free from evil deeds, along with the root fruits and water; even though he is competent to consume them, he does not partake of them for ten or five years, nor does fire carry the oblation that has been thus accepted."

sloka: śayyāṃ gṛhānkuśāngandhānapaḥ puṣpaṃ maṇīndadhi | dhānā matsyānpayo māṃsaṃ śākaṃ caiva na nirṇudet
translation: The mattress, household articles, cotton garments, and sandalwood paste, the offerings of water, flowers, and jewels, grains, fish, meat, and vegetables should not be withheld.

sloka: gurūnbhṛtyāṃścojjihīrṣannarciṣyandevatātithīn | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānna tu tṛpyetsvayaṃ tataḥ guruṣu tvabhyatīteṣu vinā vā tairgṛhe vasan | ātmano vṛttiṃ anvicchangṛhṇīyātsādhutaḥ sadā
translation: Eager to seek the company of teachers, one should respectfully welcome guests and gods from all directions. Never being content, one should not reside in their house without serving the guru and his followers. Instead, one should always adopt the behavior of a mendicant, except when attending to their own duties or those of their teacher.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I have, in the past, taught this unchanging yoga to Vivasvan; Vivasvan passed it on to Manu; and Manu imparted it to Ikshvaku.

sloka: bhagavo kasmin vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati
translation: By knowing whom, O Lord, everything else becomes known.

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: The wise perceive the imperceptible, incomprehensible, unborn, colorless, odorless, tasteless, touchless, eternal, all-pervading, extremely subtle, and changeless as the source of all beings.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: That which is unseen in darkness becomes visible, what is unheard turns audible, the unknown becomes known, such is the power of that (source of light).

sloka: yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syātvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam”
translation: "Just as, O Somya, by knowing a single clay lump, everything made of clay can be known; the initial action is transformation, and the name is just 'clay' - this truly is so."

sloka: annamayaṃ hi mana āpomayaḥ prāṇaḥ tejomayī vāk
translation: The mind is made of food, while breath is composed of vital life force; speech is composed of fire element.

sloka: svaṃ apīto bhavati tasmāt enamsva pitītyācakṣate
translation: Therefore, one's own father becomes (one's) relative; thus they say, "this is your father."

sloka: sa ya eṣoഽṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: That which is this small and subtle self, indeed this entire reality is nothing but that self. This verily is the truth, O Śvetaketu.

sloka: ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyad bhavanti tadābhavanti’
translation: Here, whether (it's) a tiger, or a lion, or a wolf, or a boar, or a worm, or a bird, or a snake, or a deer - whatever exists, all of those come into being.

sloka: śṛṇu nāmāni lokānāṃ mātṝṇāṃ śaṅkarāṇi ca || atha kaśyapapatnīnāṃ yatprasūtamidaṃ jagat | aditirditirdanuḥ kāṣṭhā ariṣṭā surasā ilā || muniḥ krodhavaśā tāmrā surabhiḥ saramā timiḥ | timeryādogaṇā āsanśvāpadāḥ saramāsutāḥ
translation: Listen to the names of the consorts of Shankara (Lord Shiva) and that which was produced by Kashyapa's wives, what became this world. Aditi, Diti, Danu, Kaastha, Ariṣṭa, Surasa, and Ila - these are the names of Kashyapa's wives. Muni, Tāmrā, Surabhi, Saramā, Timi, and the offspring of Timeri - these were born from Saramā.

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: Only the wise and insightful brahmins know the four sacred words of limited syllables as the boat that ferries across to the beyond, not revealing their true meaning in everyday speech.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, and credible testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: indriyasyārthena sannikarṣād utpadyate yat jñānaṃ tat pratyakṣam ||
translation: Knowledge that arises from the direct interaction between the senses and their objects is called perception.

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation: The relationship between the marked and unmarked is understood through this very observation of the marked and unmarked. Through observing the marked, one becomes mindful of it. And through remembering the marked, an unobservable object is inferred.

sloka: pūrvavaditi yatra kāraṇena kāryyamanumīyate| yathā medhonnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Where the effect is inferred to occur due to a previous cause, just as it will rain after the ripening of the clouds.

sloka: athavā pūrvavaditi yatra yathā pūrvvaṃ pratyakṣabhūtayoḥ anyataradarśanena anyatarasya apratyakṣasya anumānam | yathā dhūmenāgniriti |
translation: Or, like before, it is inference where, when there is absence of direct perception of two things, the unperceived is inferred based on the perceived, just as fire is inferred from smoke.

sloka: śeṣavat yatra kāryyeṇa kāraṇamanumīyate | pūrvvodakaviparītamudakaṃ nadyāḥ pūrṇatvamaṃ śīdhratvañca dṛṣṭvā srotaso'numīyate bhūtā vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: When an effect is understood as deriving from a cause, and the flow of rivers is seen to be full, downward flowing, and agitated before rainfall, then it can be inferred that the natural elements have become them.

sloka: śeṣavat nāma pariśeṣaḥ sa ca prasaktapratiṣedhe'nyatra aprasāṅgāt śiṣyamāṇe sampratyayaḥ | yathā sadanityamityevamādinā dravyaguṇakarmaṇāmaviśeṣeṇa sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyebhyo vibhaktasya śabdasya tasmin dravyakarmaguṇasaṃśaye na dravyamekadravyatvāt na karma śabdāntarahetutvāt yastu śiṣyate so'yamiti śabdasya guṇatvapratipattiḥ |
translation: The name "sesavat" refers to the remainder; this remains unchanged even in the case of a strong denial, except when there is attachment. Understanding arises when there is doubt regarding the essential nature, qualities, and actions of substances. In the case of a word that denotes a substance, quality, or action, its grammatical form indicates its relationship with other substances, qualities, or actions. When there is uncertainty about the substance, etc., the word's function is to indicate which substance is being referred to. This is how the meaning (guṇatva) of the word "sesavat" is understood.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ vrajyāpūrvakam anyatra dṛṣṭasya anyatra darśanamiti tathā cā''dityasya | tasmāt asti apratyakṣā api āpyādityasya vrajyeti|
translation: Therefore, just as the previous dawns have been observed in their own place, so is there an unseen but perceivable rising of the sun elsewhere.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ nāma yatrāpratyakṣe liṅgaliṅginoḥ sambandhe kenacidarthena liṅgasya sāmānyādapratyakṣo liṅgī gamyate | yathecchādibhirātmā | icchādayo guṇāḥ | guṇāśca dravyasaṃsthānāḥ | tadyadeṣāṃ sthānaṃ sa ātmeti |
translation: The generally observed mark, which is not directly perceptible, is understood as a sign of the existence of something in a certain relationship through some evidence. Similarly, the self is recognized as the place of the powers such as desire, etc., and the qualities that reside in substances.

sloka: prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam || || {upamānalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established similarity (of two things) is the means for knowing (one through the other). (This is a definition of "upamana" in logic.)

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: The recognition of something comparable is the determination of the characteristics of a word's meaning through a similar entity. For example, when one understands that a cow and a gavaya (a type of wild animal) share common qualities, then the term "gavaya" denotes that specific meaning. Similarly, when something in this world shares the same characteristics as gaures (another term for a cow), then through the relationship between the signifier and the signified, it is recognized as an herbal medicine. In this way, any object in the world can be desirably understood through comparison.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ||||{śabdalakṣaṇam} saḥ dvividhaḥ dṛṣṭādṛṣṭārthatvāt||||{śabdabhedaḥ}
translation: Speech or word is of two types, based on the presence or absence of direct meaning. This has been classified as twofold due to the difference in their meanings.

sloka: yasyāmutra pratīyate so'dṛṣṭārthaḥ | evamṛṣi laukikavākyānāṃ vibhāga iti |
translation: "Whose intended meaning becomes clear after (they have) passed away, that is the distinguishing characteristic of mundane statements, according to the sage."

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and scriptural testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: tayā ca sarveṣāṃ vyavahārāḥ pravartanta iti | evamebhiḥ pramāṇairdevamanuṣyatiraśca vyavahārāḥ prakalpante nāto'nyatheti| arthāpattiḥ apramāṇaṃ anaikāntikatvāt ||||{arthāpattiprāmāṇyaparīkṣā}
translation: According to her, all interactions are conducted. Thus, both divine and human behaviors are established through these means, not otherwise. This is an instance of arthapatti (inference based on circumstances).

sloka: autpattikastu śabdasyārthena sambandhastasya jñānamupadeśo'vyatirekaścārthe'nupalabdhe tat pramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt sū
translation: Knowledge of the meaning of a word arising naturally is the means to understand it, and for that which cannot be directly perceived, there is no independent means of knowledge, according to Badarayana's stance.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā||
translation: The appearance of meaning is seen or heard; otherwise, a meaning that is not directly evident should not be assumed. For instance, Devadatta is considered to be alive, based on the perception of his home's existence, even when he himself is not directly visible.

sloka: arthāpattilakṣaṇam| vinā kalpanayā'rthena dṛṣṭenā'nupapannatām| nayatā'dṛṣṭamarthaṃ yā sā'rthāpattistu kalpanā || | dṛṣṭenā'rthenā'dṛṣṭasyā'rthasyā'rthāntarakalpanāyāmasatyāmanupapattimāpādayatā yā'rthāntarakalpanā sā'rthāpatti:| yathā jīvato devadattasya gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyā'dṛṣṭasya kalpanā|
translation: The determination of the meaning of a word through context, without arbitrary assumption, and devoid of established meaning when not applicable, is called "arthapatti" (inferring the meaning). When an unseen object is inferred from a seen one, such as inferring Devadatta's absence based on observing his empty house while he is alive, it is also an example of "arthapatti" (inference).

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇabhāvo nāstītyasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasyeti|
translation: The established meaning of "there is no existence without the proof of existence" holds true.

sloka: pramāṇapañcakaṃ yatra vasturūpe na jāyate| vastusattāvabodhārthaṃ tatrābhāvapramāṇatā|||| vasttvasaṅkarasiddhiśca tatprāmāṇyasamāśrayā|
translation: Where the five means of valid knowledge do not arise in relation to an object's form, their purpose being to understand the true nature of existence. The absence of this as a means of valid knowledge is also established there.

sloka: kṣīre dadhyādi yannāsti prāgabhāvassa ucyate||||
translation: That which exists before the formation of milk, curd, etc., is called prāgabhāva.

sloka: nāstitā payaso dadhni pradhvaṃsābhāva iṣyate| ||||
translation: The churning of milk that hasn't been obtained doesn't make sense.

sloka: gavi yo'śvādyabhāvastu so'nyonyābhāva ucyate||||
translation: The one who is unlike a cow (i.e., not giving or sharing) in relation to a horse, is said to be the one who lacks mutuality (or reciprocity).

sloka: śiraso'vayavā ninmā vṛddhikāṭhinyavarjitāḥ| śaśaśrṛṅgādirūpeṇa so'tyantābhāva ucyate||||
translation: Those who are free from degeneration of body parts, even in old age, are said to be completely free from decay, like Shashishrunga.

sloka: śaraṇāgatasya kartavyamātithyaṃ hi prayatnataḥ| pañcayajñapravṛttena gṛhasthena viśeṣataḥ|| pañcayajñāṃstu yo mohānna karoti gṛhāśrame| tasya nāyaṃ na ca paro loko bhavati dharmataḥ||
translation: It is the duty of a householder, through sincere effort, to show hospitality to those who seek refuge and to perform the five daily sacrifices especially. A householder who foolishly neglects these five sacred duties does not attain either this world or the next, according to dharma.

sloka: sa tu śītahatairgātrairna jagāma na tasthivān| dadarśa patitāṃ bhūmau kapotīṃ śītavihvalām||
translation: With cold, shivering body, he did not approach or stay there. He saw a quail fallen to the ground, itself overcome by the cold.

sloka: dharmārthakāmakāleṣu bhāryā puṃsaḥ sahāyinī| videśagamane cāsya saiva viśvāsakārikā|| nāsti bhāryāsamo bandhurnāsti bhāryāsamā gatiḥ| nāsti bhāryāsamo loke sahāyo dharmasaṅgrahe|| yasya bhāryā gṛhe nāsti sādhvī ca priyavādinī| araṇyaṃ tena gantavyaṃ yathāraṇyaṃ tathā gṛham||
translation: In matters of dharma, artha, and kama, a wife is her husband's helper. She is his confidante during travel abroad. There is no friend equal to a wife, nor is there a path equal to hers. There is no one in this world equal to a wife in helping to uphold dharma. If a wife, who is virtuous and speaks kindly, is not present in the home, then it is as if it were an uninhabited forest.

sloka: arāvapyucitaṃ kāryamātithyaṃ gṛhamāgate| chettumapyāgate chāyāṃ nopasaṃharate drumaḥ||
translation: A task that should be done for a guest arriving at one's home, as well as when they depart, and even their shade, is not to be withdrawn - this is referred to as arāvapyucitaṃ. The verse gives the example of a tree, which does not withdraw its shade even when the time comes for it to depart (i.e., when the sun sets).

sloka: niścitā khalu me buddhiratithipratipūjayane|| tataḥ kṛtapratijño vai sa pakṣī prahasanniva| tamagniṃ triḥparikramya praviveśa mahāmatiḥ||
translation: Undoubtedly, my resolution is steady and my mind set on worshipping the goddess. Thus, having offered salutations to the fire three times, the great-minded one entered it, as if laughing (in delight).

sloka: mitaṃ dadāti hi pitā mitaṃ bhrātā mitaṃ sutaḥ|| amitasya hi dātāraṃ bhartāraṃ kā na pūjayet| nāsti bhartṛsamo nātho nāsti bhartṛsamaṃ sukham||
translation: A father who gives little, so does a brother and a son; but who should honor the one who doesn't give? There is no equal to a protector, nor is there happiness comparable to a protector.

sloka: tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti |
translation: The latter one is the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda, along with Śikṣā, Kalpa, Vyākaraṇa, Nirukta, Chandas, and Jyotiṣam.

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six ancillary sciences of the Vedas are: phonetics, grammar, etymology, prosody, sacrificial rituals, and calendar calculations.

sloka: chandaḥ pādau tu vedasya hastau kalpo'tha ucyate | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ cakṣurniruktaṃ śrotramucyate || śikṣā ghrāṇaṃ tu vedasya mukhaṃ vyākaraṇaṃ smṛtam | tasmāt sāṅgamadhītyaiva brahmaloke mahīyate ||
translation: The meter is considered the feet of the Vedas, the tradition its hands. The luminous is said to be its eyes, and the unspoken its ears. The phonetics is its nose, and grammar its face. Therefore, by understanding this combination, one becomes exalted in the world of Brahma.

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstraṃ caturthaṃ tu vidyā hyaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharva Veda; the eighth is Arthashastra, and the nineteenth is education (knowledge) altogether.

sloka: aṣṭādaśa purāṇāni purāṇajñāḥ pracakṣate| brāhmaṃ pādmaṃ vaiṣṇavañca śaivaṃ bhāgavataṃ tathā|
translation: The eighteen Puranas are classified as Brahma, Padma, Vaishnava, Saiva, and Bhagavata by those knowledgeable in Puranas.

sloka: varṇādidharmasmaraṇaṃ yatra vedāvirodhakam | kīrtanaṃ cārthaśāstrāṇāṃ smṛtiḥ sā ca prakīrtitā |
translation: The recollection of the duties associated with caste, etc., that does not contradict the Vedas, as well as the exposition of the meanings of the treatises on duties, is known as Smriti.

sloka: manvatriviṣṇuhārīta yājñavalkyośano'ṅgirāḥ | yamāpastambasaṃvartāḥ kātyāyanabṛhaspatī | | | |
translation: The teachers Manu, Vishnu, Harita, Yajnavalkya, Angira, Yamah, Atri, and Brihaspati.

sloka: vitathasya sutān manyoḥ bṛhatkṣatro jayastataḥ | mahāvīryo naro gargaḥ saṅkṛtistu narātmajaḥ || ||guruśca rantidevaśca saṅ‌kṛteḥ pāṇḍunandana |
translation: The sons of the mighty Bhratarajan are indeed victorious; Garga is a great hero, and Sankriti is a man of prowess. And you too, descendant of Pandu, are a revered guru and Rantideva.

sloka: yasya dviśatasāhasrā āsansūdā mahātmanaḥ|| gṛhānabhyāgatānviprānatithīnpariveṣakāḥ| pakvāpakvaṃ divārātraṃ aparyāptaṃ dhanaṃ tadā[varānnamamṛtopamam|| nyāyenādhigataṃ vittaṃ brāhmaṇebhyo hyamanyata| vedānadhītya dharmeṇa yaścakre dviṣato vaśe||
translation: Of the magnanimous one, whose dwelling is visited by two thousand invited and respected guests daily, who partakes of ripe and unripe food day and night, who has amassed wealth that is beyond measure, and who has acquired riches legitimately but distributes it to the brahmins, and who has studied the Vedas and adheres to religious practices, or has subjugated enemies - who is this person?

sloka: vyatīyuḥ aṣṭacatvāriṃśat ahani apibataḥ kila | ghṛtapāyasasaṃyāvaṃ toyaṃ prātarupasthitam || ||
translation: Thirty-eight days and nights have passed since they drank (the Soma juice), and in the morning, clarified butter, milk, and water are ready.

sloka: na kāmaye'haṃ gatimīśvarātparāṃ aṣṭarddhiyuktāmapunarbhavaṃ vā | ārtiṃ prapadye'khiladehabhājāṃ antaḥsthito yena bhavantyaduḥkhāḥ || ||
translation: I do not desire a higher destiny than that of the Lord, nor do I desire to be united with the eightfold divine powers and to be reborn. I seek refuge in That which resides within all bodies, by which all pains of beings are removed.

sloka: puruṣabahutvaṃ vyavasthātaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nādvaitamātmano liṅgāt tadbhedapratīteḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nānātmāpi pratyakṣabādhāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | nobhābhyāṃ tenaiva | sāṃkhyasūtra | anyaparatvamavivekānāṃ tatra | sāṃkhyasūtra | nātmāvidyā nobhayaṃ jagadupādānakāraṇaṃ nissaṅgatvāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | naikasyānandacidrūpatve dvayorbhedāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | duḥkhanivṛttergauṇaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | vimuktipraśaṃsā mandānāṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra | jananamaraṇakaraṇānāṃ pratiniyamādayugapatpravṛtteśca | puruṣabahutvaṃ siddhaṃ traiguṇyaviparyayāccaiva || ||
translation: The multiplicity of the Purusha (conscious self) is established in the Sankhya aphorisms, and it does not stem from the non-dual Atman due to the perception of difference. The manifoldness is also not due to the duality of knowledge and ignorance, as neither of them is the cause of the world's creation. Happiness is not different from consciousness, nor can there be two separate realities. Suffering is merely an attribute. Liberation is praised for the ignorant. Birth, death, and causation occur simultaneously. The multiplicity of the Purusha becomes confirmed by the transformation of the three gunas (qualities).

sloka: kleśakarmavipākāśayairaparāmṛṣṭaḥ puruṣaviśeṣa īśvaraḥ ||
translation: The exceptional person, the Lord, who is untouched by the afflictions, actions, their consequences, and latent impressions.

sloka: niratiśayaṃ tatra sarvajñatvabījam ||
translation: There, supreme omniscience's seed is present in abundance.

sloka: sa pūrveṣāmapi guruḥ kālenānavacchedāta||
translation: Even the ancient teacher, due to the absence of a time limit, remained.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam||
translation: The Self, body, senses, objects, intellect, mind, and the nature of being, along with their defects, results, suffering, and liberation are to be investigated.

sloka: tatrā''tmā sarvasya draṣṭā sarvasya bhoktā sarvajñaḥ sarvānubhavakaḥ | tasya bhogā''yatanaṃ śarīram | bhogasādhanānīndriyāṇi |
translation: The self is the witness and enjoyer of all; omniscient and experiencing all. Its physical form is the basis for its experiences, and the senses are the means to obtain those experiences.

sloka: jagaduvyāpāravarjam prakaraṇāt asannihitatvācca ||
translation: Exempt from being all-pervading in the world, due to it not being separate from its locus.

sloka: jaṭā mālā śikhā lekhā dhvajo daṇḍo ratho ghanaḥ aṣṭau vikṛtayaḥ proktā kramapūrvā manīṣibhiḥ
translation: The eight distinctive marks, namely, braided hair, sacred thread, tuft of hair, flag, staff, chariot, and armor, have been described in order by sages.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ | saṃ | vadante | somena | saha | rājñā | yasmai | kṛṇoti | brāhmaṇaḥ | taṃ | rājan | pārayāmasi ||
translation: O king, we shall reach that ruler whom the brahmin honors with soma offerings together with plants (herbs).

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ | saṃ vadante | vadante somena | somena saha | saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti | kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ | brāhmaṇastaṃ | taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation: Plants are called so when combined with soma, together with the king, as "raja," for whom the brahmin performs the ritual. O king, we seek to reach that.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ sam | saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante | vadante somena somena vadante vadante somena | somena saha saha somena somena saha| saha rājñā rājñā saha saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti kṛṇoti yasmai yasmai kṛṇoti| kṛṇoti brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaḥ kṛṇoti kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ| brāhmaṇastaṃ taṃ brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇastam | taṃ rājan rājaṃstaṃ taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi pārayāmasi rājan rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation: Herbs are called herbs, they say, and also call them as such; some call them with the word "soma" (a plant in Vedic texts), together with "soma." Together with the king, they call it the king; they also call it "king of kings." To whom the brahmin (priest) dedicates, dedicates, and to whom the brahmin dedicates, that is the brahmin's goal. That is the king's objective, the "king of kings" objective. We strive for that, we strive for that, striving for the brahmin's goal, striving.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ saṃ vadante| saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante somena|
translation: Herbs are called herbs, they say; they also speak of them as "sam." They are called "sam" when compared to herbs, referring to a quality they all share.

sloka: brahmakṣatriyaviṭśūdrā varṇāstvādyāstrayo dvijāḥ | niṣekādyāḥ śmaśānāntāsteṣāṃ vai mantrataḥ kriyāḥ || ||
translation: The primary duties for a Brahmin, Kshatriya, and Vaishya are respectively: studying and teaching the Vedas, protecting people and land, and engaging in trade and agriculture. Their secondary duties, to be performed later in life, include officiating at weddings and performing funeral rites.

sloka: saṃskārā yadavicchinnāḥ sa dvijo'jo jagāda yam |
translation: The initiated person who spoke about the sacred rites, uninterrupted in their sequence.

sloka: viprasyādhyayanādīni ṣaḍanyasyāpratigrahaḥ |
translation: For a brahmin, acceptance of the six duties (such as studying and teaching) is not to be forsaken.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva dānaṃ pātre pratigrahaḥ| adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgṛjuḥ||
translation: Performing rituals, receiving sacrifices, giving donations, accepting gifts, teaching and learning are the six duties that constitute righteousness.

sloka: satyaṃ dānaṃ kṣamā śīlamānṛśaṃsyaṃ tapo ghṛṇā | dṛśyante yatranāgendrasa brāhmaṇa iti smṛtaḥ ||
translation: One who is truthful, charitable, forgiving, gentle, and without arrogance, who practices austerity and compassion, is recognized as a brahmin.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ santoṣaḥ kṣāntirārjavam | jñānaṃ dayācyutātmatvaṃ satyaṃ ca brahmalakṣaṇam || ||
translation: Serenity, self-control, austerity, purity, contentment, forbearance, honesty, knowledge, compassion, and realization of the self as Brahman, along with truthfulness, constitute the marks of Brahman.

sloka: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat || ||
translation: The assignment of teaching, learning, performing rituals, officiating at rituals, giving gifts, and accepting gifts was laid down for the Brahmins.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca | tasmādasminsadā yukto nityaṃ syādātmavāndvijaḥ || ||
translation: The ultimate duty is to follow the conduct, as declared in the Vedas and Smritis; therefore, a twice-born should always be engaged in self-control.

sloka: idaṃ śāstram adhīyāno brāhmaṇaḥ śaṃsitavrataḥ | manovāggehajairnityaṃ karmadoṣairna lipyate || || ācārādvicyuto vipro na vedaphalam aśnute | ācāreṇa tu saṃyuktaḥ sampūrṇaphalabhāgbhavet || ||
translation: A brahmin, who studies this scripture and is praised for his vows, remains unsullied by daily mental and vocal demerits. If the eligibility of a brahmin is lost due to misconduct, he does not partake in the fruit of vedic study. By conforming to proper conduct, however, he attains complete fruition.

sloka: ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam || || satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet || ||
translation: Righteousness is the excreta-free, undecaying, and sacred knowledge that is to be known; it is immortal and is obtained through begging. Its acquisition is remembered as nourishment. Trade is practiced through both truth and falsehood, but one should avoid the lowly occupation of a dog.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: A brahmin should always avoid what is reprehensible, as should a king; a brahmin is one who knows all the Vedas, and a king is one who knows all the gods.

sloka: kusūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā || || caturṇāṃ api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ || || ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyāṃ ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati || ||
translation: He may be a collector of Kushala woods or one who collects grains, or perhaps a Tryahaihika, or even an ascetic living on alms. Among these four types of married Brahmins, the one who is most superior in terms of righteousness and brings greatest fame to the world is the one who performs the six duties (shatkarma) - three for himself, one for others, and two with the help of a spiritual teacher.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi || ||
translation: By maintaining an attitude of non-harming, even minimal harm, towards all beings, a brahmin should live.

sloka: yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam || ||
translation: For the mere reputation of leading a journey, one should earn wealth through actions that do not cause bodily harm.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ || ||
translation: A householder brahmin should not invite a fellow clansman for a meal out of selfishness, as the wise call this behavior unworthy.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā || || na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām || || saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: Engaged in performing the agnihotra ritual, who should always offer oblations in the concluding parvayanistis, and never follow the ways of the world for the sake of livelihood. One should lead a pure, simple, and completely Brahminical life. By making contentment his ultimate goal, he should remain focused and become one who desires happiness; for contentment is the root of happiness, while unhappiness is its opposite.

sloka: dāti dāśati dāsati rāti rāsati pṛṇakṣi pṛṇāti śikṣati tuñjata maṃhate iti dānakarmāṇaḥ| |
translation: Those who give, protect, cause to serve, enjoy, relish, nourish, teach, and honor are known as performers of dana-karmas (charitable acts).

sloka: devabrāhmaṇādisampradānakadravyamocanam tatparyyāyaḥ tyāgaḥ vihāpitam utsarjanam visarjanam viśrāṇanam vitaraṇam sparśanam pratipādanam prādeśanam nirvvapaṇam apavarjanam aṃhatiḥ ityamaraḥ
translation: The abandonment of objects belonging to the brāhmaṇas and other revered ones, with the intention of giving up, is known as tyāga. This includes casting aside, discarding, relinquishing, distributing, touching, establishing, indicating, renouncing, and rejecting.

sloka: nākasya pṛṣṭhe adhi tiṣṭhati śrito yaḥ pṛṇāti sa ha deveṣu gacchati | tasmā āpo ghṛtamarṣanti sindhavastasmā iyaṃ dakṣiṇā pinvate sadā ||
translation: The one who drinks while resting on the back of the sky indeed goes to the gods after giving life to them. Hence, this southern flow is always nourished .

sloka: tapaḥ paraṃ kṛtayuge tretāyāṃ jñānaṃ ucyate | dvāpare yajñaṃ evāhurdānaṃ ekaṃ kalau yuge || ||
translation: In the Krta Yuga, austerity is considered supreme; in the Treta Yuga, knowledge is declared as such; in the Dvapara Yuga, sacrifice is praised; while in the Kali Yuga, charity alone is deemed important.

sloka: sa tu dānasya tattvārthī tepe varṣagaṇānbahūn|| || ā āī ēē ṣṇāū|| || tatastaṃ prāha khe vāṇī ślokamekaṃ nṛpa śrṛṇu|| dvihetu ṣaḍadhiṣṭhānaṃ ṣaḍaṃgaṃ ca dvipākayuk|| || catuḥprakāraṃ trividhaṃ trināśaṃ dānamucyate||
translation: He who is knowledgeable about the true nature of charity, indeed, toiled for many years. Now listen, O king, to this verse containing a sloka (couplet) spoken in the sky. The six supports and six causes, as well as the sixfold division, are said to be the triple nature of charity, which has four aspects and is threefold in its destruction.

sloka: śraddhā śaktiśca dānānāṃ vṛddhyakṣayakarehi te|| ||
translation: Faith and power (capacity) are, indeed, the causes of growth or decay in generosity.

sloka: dharmamarthaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca vrīḍāharṣabhayāni ca|| adhiṣṭhānāni dānānāṃ ṣaḍetāni pracakṣate|| ||
translation: The six bases of charity are dharma, artha, kama, shame, fear, and happiness.

sloka: dātā pratigrahītā ca śuddhirdeyaṃ ca dharmayuk|| || deśakālau ca dānānāmaṃgānyetāni ṣaḍviduḥ|| ||
translation: The giver and the acceptor, purity, honesty, and righteousness are the six forms of giving.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva tathā dānapratigrahau| adhyāpanaṃ cādhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgdvijaḥ||
translation: Performing rituals, receiving rituals, giving and accepting gifts, teaching, and studying are the six duties of a dvija (twice-born or learned person) according to dharma.

sloka: sadbhyo yaddīyate kiṃcittatparatropatiṣṭhati|| asatsu dīyate kiṃcittaddānamiha bhujyate|| ||
translation: Of the virtuous, whatever is given away takes him to higher realms; but what is given to the unvirtuous becomes a cause for his downfall here (in this world).

sloka: dhruvamāhustrikaṃ kāmyaṃ naimittikamiti kramāt|| || vaidiko dānamārgo'yaṃ caturdhā varṇyate dvijaiḥ||
translation: The gift-giving ritual, as described in the Vedas, is classified into three types: obligatory , occasional , and regular .

sloka: upānacchatrapātrādidadhimadhvāsanāni ca|| || āāāāā || || dīpakāṣṭhopalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam|| iti kānīyasānyāhurdānanāśatrayaṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: Listen, indeed, to the very valuable teachings about the three sacred fires and other matters, such as the water pot with a handle, the standard of a king's parasol, and the lamp post, which are used for a long time.

sloka: yaccākruśya dadātyaṃga dattvā vākrośati dvijam|| paiśācaṃ tadvṛthā dānaṃdānanāśāstrayastvamī|| ||
translation: What is given or spoken to a twice-born person after saying "beckon" (a form of address), and also given after uttering "please accept this," that alms is actually a curse, not a gift.

sloka: ye ke cāsmacchreyā~so brāhmaṇāḥ teṣāṃ tvayā''sanena praśvasitavyam | śraddhayā deyam | aśraddhayā'deyam | śriyā deyam | hriyā deyam | bhiyā deyam | saṃvidā deyam | atha yadi te karmavicikitsā vā vṛttavicikitsā vā syāt || ||
translation: Of the Brahmanas who are superior in this world, you should always be attentive towards them through respect and reverence. They should be given faith, wealth, fame, shyness, knowledge, and fear. If you have any doubts about your duty or conduct, then you should approach them for guidance.

sloka: gṛhe daśaguṇaṃ dānaṃ goṣṭhe caiva śatādhikam | puṇyatīrtheṣu sāhasramanantaṃ śivasannidhau ||
translation: At home, a donation that is ten times greater; in the cattle pen, hundred times more; at holy pilgrimages, thousands and in the presence of Shiva, countless.

sloka: devīpurāṇe sarve śivāśramāḥ puṇyāḥ sarvā nadyaḥ śubhapradāḥ |
translation: In Devi Purana, all ashrams of Shiva are auspicious and holy rivers that grant good fortune.

sloka: na hīyate yatra dharmmaścatuṣpāt sakalo dvija! | sa deśaḥ paramo nityaṃ sarvapuṇyatamo mataḥ |
translation: The land where dharma's four pillars always flourish, is considered the supreme and holiest of all.

sloka: gaṅgādvāre prayāge ca avimukte ca puṣkare | nagare cāṭṭahāse ca gaṅgāsāgarasaṅgame | kurukṣetre gayāyāñca tīrthe vā'marakaṇṭake | evamādiṣu tīrtheṣu dattamakṣayatāmiyāt | sarvatīrthamayī gaṅgā tatra dattaṃ mahāphalam |
translation: At Prayag near Ganga's shore, unseparated from Pushkara, in the city of Attahasa and at the confluence of Ganga and the sea, as well as at Kurukshetra, Gaya, and the Amarakantaka teerthas; offerings made at these and other such sacred teerthas are never destroyed, for the Ganga, who is herself the embodiment of all teerthas, bestows great fruit there.

sloka: kuṭumbabhaktavasanād deyaṃ yadatiricyate | anyathā dīyate yaddhi na tad dānaṃ phalapradam ||
translation: The gift that is given out of affection towards one's family, that donation is considered meritorious. Any other kind of donation, if not given with such affection, does not bear fruit.

sloka: na taddānaṃ praśaṃsanti yena vṛttirvipadyate | dānaṃ yajñastapaḥ karma loke vṛttimato yataḥ || ||
translation: They do not praise that gift which upsets one's conduct; a giver whose conduct is in accordance with the world is praised.

sloka: brahmaṇāstapasā yuktā yathāśakti pradāyinaḥ | sahasraśaktiśca śataṃ śataśaktirdaśāpi ca || dadyādpaśca yaḥ śaktyā sarve tulyaphalāḥ smṛtāḥ | rantidevo hi nṛpatirapaḥ prādādakiñcanaḥ ||
translation: Just as the brahmin endowed with austerities gives according to his ability - one hundred units of power, thousand units of power, ten units of power, and also with whatever power he has left; King Rantideva, however, is remembered as one who bestows all these powers equally (to everyone).

sloka: dharmāya yaśase'rthāya kāmāya svajanāya ca | pañcadhā vibhajan vittaṃ ihāmutra ca modate || ||
translation: One who distributes wealth in five ways - for the sake of dharma, fame, desire, relatives, and also hereafter (in charity) - takes delight.

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā|| sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: The faith of embodied beings is of three kinds, O Arjuna, and it is naturally so; it is of the nature of sattva, rajas, and tamas. Listen to their descriptions.

sloka: dātavyamiti yaddānaṃ dīyate'nupakāriṇe | deśe kāle ca pātre ca taddānaṃ sātvikaṃ smṛtam || yattu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalamuddiśya vā punaḥ | dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṃ taddānaṃ rājasaṃ smṛtam ||
translation: An action is considered satvik when it is given out of a sense of duty to an undeserving recipient, in terms of time, place, and object. On the other hand, an action is classified as rajasic when it is done with the expectation of receiving something in return or with difficulty.

sloka: adeśakāle yaddānamapātrebhyaśca dīyate | asatkṛtamavajñātaṃ tattāmasamudāhṛtam || dānaṃ trividhamityetatkaniṣṭhajyeṣṭhamadhyamam || tatra naiśreyasaṃ jyeṣṭhaṃ kaniṣṭhaṃ svārthasiddhaye || || kāruṇyātsarvabhūteṣu saṃvibhāgastu madhyamaḥ ||
translation: Giving is classified into three types: low, middling, and high. The lowest type of giving is that which is given at an inappropriate time or place to unworthy recipients; the middling type is that which is given without consideration of whether it will be misused; and the highest type is that which is given with compassion to all beings, at a proper time and place, to worthy recipients.

sloka: nityaṃ naimittikaṃ kāmyaṃ trividhaṃ dānamucyate | caturthaṃ vimalaṃ proktaṃ sarvadānottamottamam ||
translation: Charity is threefold, classified as obligatory, occasional, and voluntary; the fourth kind, pure and excellent, is giving at all times.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ yācitaṃ nyāsamādhirdārāśca darśanam|| anvāhitaṃ ca nikṣepaḥ sarvasvaṃ cānvaye sati|| || āpatsvapi na deyāni navavastūni paṃḍitaiḥ|| yo dadāti sa mūḍhātmā prāyāścittīyate naraḥ|| ||
translation: A request made in common, along with respect and observation, should be fulfilled; if not discarded. If one possesses all assets, they shouldn't give away new or necessary items, even to the wise. One who gives such things is considered foolish and will likely have to atone for it.

sloka: jīvanmukto nāma svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmajñānena tadajñānabādhanadvārā svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmaṇi sākṣātkṛte ajñāna tatkārya sañcitakarma saṃśaya viparyayādīnāmapi bādhitatvāt akhilabandharahito brahmaniṣṭhaḥ || ||
translation: A jivanmukta, one who has realized their true self as non-dual Brahman through knowledge, is liberated from all bonds by destroying ignorance and its effects, such as doubt and error, along with the residual karmas, at the very moment of directly realizing their true self as non-dual Brahman.

sloka: evaṃ ca vedāntavākyaiḥ sadgurūpadeśena ca sarveṣvapi bhūteṣu yeṣāṃ brahmabuddhirutpannā te jīvanmuktāḥ ityarthaḥ |
translation: Those whose understanding of Brahman has arisen through proper instruction in the teachings of Vedanta are themselves liberated while still alive.

sloka: sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim || ||
translation: What should be the speech of one established in wisdom and focused in meditation, O Keshava? What should such a firm-minded person speak, where should they go?

sloka: rāgadveṣavimuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran | ātmavaśyairvidheyātmā prasādamadhigacchati || ||
translation: By abandoning attachment and aversion, and moving through sense objects with the self as the master, one gains peace.

sloka: nanu jīvanmuktaḥ kaḥ ? yathā deho'haṃ puruṣo'haṃ brāhmaṇo'haṃ śūdro'hamasmīti dṛḍhaniścayastathā nāhaṃ brāhmaṇaḥ na śūdraḥ na puruṣaḥ kintu asaṃgaḥ saccidānanda svarūpaḥ prakāśarūpaḥ sarvāntaryāmī cidākāśarūpo'smīti dṛḍhaniścayarūpo'parokṣajñānavān jīvanmuktaḥ ||
translation: Is there anyone who is liberated while still alive, firm in the conviction that 'I am not a brahmin, not a shudra, not a man, but rather pure consciousness, existence-knowledge-bliss, pure awareness, and the indwelling witness of all'?

sloka: jñātibhirvā nopajan~ smarannida~ śarīra~ sa yathā prayogya ācaraṇe yukta evamevāyamasmiñcharīre prāṇo yuktaḥ || ||
translation: Just as the physical body is suitable for use by known people and not by strangers, similarly, the prana (vital life force) is properly engaged in this body.

sloka: dehaṃ ca naśvaramavasthitamutthitaṃ vā | siddho na paśyati yato'dhyagamat svarūpam | daivādapetamatha daivavaśād upetaṃ | vāso yathā parikṛtaṃ madirāmadāndhaḥ|| ||
translation: One who, under the influence of divine madness or due to being devoid of it, is unable to perceive the established or transient body as it truly is.

sloka: jñānabhūmiḥ śubhecchākhyā prathamā samudāhṛtā| vicāraṇā dvitīyā tu tṛtīyā tanumānasā|| satvāpattiścaturthī syāttato'saṃsaktināmikā| padārthābhāvanī ṣaṣṭhī saptamī turyagā smṛtā||
translation: The first aspect of the field of knowledge is called subheccha; reflection is the second, and the third is the physical self. The fourth is referred to as satvapatti, leading to detachment for those who are still attached; the sixth is object cognition. The seventh is known as turyagati, the state of ultimate realization.

sloka: yaṃ pravrajantamanupetamapetakṛtyaṃ dvaipāyano virahakātara ājuhāva | putreti tanmayatayā taravo'bhineduḥ taṃ sarvabhūtahṛdayaṃ munimānato'smi || || yaḥ svānubhāvamakhila śrutisāramekaṃ adhyātmadīpaṃ atititīrṣatāṃ tamo'ndham | saṃsāriṇāṃ karuṇayā''ha purāṇaguhyaṃ taṃ vyāsasūnumupayāmi guruṃ munīnām || ||
translation: I, as a disciple, approach that guru Vyasa's son, who has crossed beyond the darkness of ignorance through his own experience, the sole lamp in the cave of all scriptures, and who out of compassion for those caught in samsara, reveals the ancient hidden secret to the wise. Similarly, I approach that muni who, like the trees, responded to Dvaipayana when he set off on his renunciation, abandoning all duties, with "O Father!" and whose heart is dear to all beings.

sloka: aho kaṣṭaṃ bhraṣṭo'hamātmavatāmanupathādyadvimuktasamastasaṅgasya viviktapuṇyāraṇyaśaraṇasyātmavata ātmani sarveṣāmātmanāṃ bhagavati vāsudeve tadanuśravaṇamananasaṅkīrtanārādhanānusmaraṇābhiyogenāśūnyasakalayāmena kālena samāveśitaṃ samāhitaṃ kārtsnyena manastattu punarmamābudhasyārānmṛgasutamanu parisusrāva
translation: Alas, what a great difficulty I face, having abandoned the path of self-control and being liberated from all attachments, taking shelter in the forest of solitary virtues, and established in the Self. Through hearing about, constantly glorifying, worshiping, and contemplating with full concentration and devotion on Lord Vāsudeva, who is the Self of all selves, I have become free from all impurities over time; but this mind slips back into its old ways again.

sloka: tatrāpi svajanasaṅgācca bhṛśamudvijamāno bhagavataḥ karmabandhavidhvaṃsanaśravaṇasmaraṇaguṇavivaraṇacaraṇāravindayugalaṃ manasā vidadhadātmanaḥ pratighātamāśaṅkamāno bhagavadanugraheṇānusmṛtasvapūrvajanmāvalirātmānamunmattajaḍāndhabadhirasvarūpeṇa darśayāmāsa lokasya
translation: Even though greatly anxious and disturbed by the thought of his own family ties, the humble Bhagavata, with his mind fixed on the means of destroying the bonds of karma, attentively listened to and recollected the descriptions and qualities of the lotus feet of the Lord. Thus, he revealed his true self, which was previously covered by ignorance, dullness, and delusion, as a result of the grace of the Lord.

sloka: tanoti vipulānarthān tatvamantrasamanvitān trāṇaṃ ca kurute yasmāt tantramityabhidhīyate
translation: The one who reveals profound meanings and provides safety, that is why it is called Tantra.

sloka: yujyante saṅklpyante sambadhyante parasparamarthāḥ samyaktayā prākaraṇike'bhimate'rthe virodhavyāghātādidoṣamapāsyānayā iti yuktiḥ yuj yojane tasmin yaktiriti rūpaṃ bhavati
translation: The arrangement, combination, and mutual compatibility of principles, in the proper sequence and with the rejection of contradictions and conflicts due to the absence of inherent defects, is called "yukti" (reasoning) when applied to "yojana" (connection or integration).

sloka: yathā'mbujavanasyārkaḥ pradīpo veśmano yathā || prabodha prakāśārthāstathā tantrasya yuktayaḥ | ekasminnapi yasyeha śāstre labdāspadā matiḥ|| sa śāstramanyadapyāśu yuktijñatvāt prabudhyate |
translation: Just as the sun is the illuminator for a lotus and a lamp for a house, in the same way, the understanding of the principles of a scripture illuminates it. The one who first understands the principle of any scripture from among many becomes enlightened about all scriptures due to understanding their underlying logic.

sloka: dharmamūlaṃ vedamāhuḥ grantharāśimakṛtrimam| tadvidāṃ smṛtiśīle ca sādhvācāraṃ manaḥpriyam ||
translation: The root of dharma is considered to be the Vedas, characterized by a collection of texts and carefully composed. For those who know it, proper conduct that is pleasing to the mind is based on scriptural memory.

sloka: śrautastretāgnisaṃbandhāt smārttaḥ pūrvaṃ mayoditaḥ | śreyaskaratamaḥ śrautastasmācchrautaṃ samācaret ||
translation: Having been previously taught the sacred tradition related to the fire ritual, one should perform the Smarta (non-vedic) rituals. For, the smarta rituals, when performed after the vedic rituals, yield the greatest benefit.

sloka: ubhāvabhihitau dharmau vedavedaviniḥsṛtau | śiṣṭācārastṛtīyaḥ syācchratismṛtyoralābhataḥ ||
translation: The two dharmas (righteousness) publicly proclaimed, namely the study and teaching of the Vedas, should be the primary and secondary behaviors of an honorable person; this practice leads to both the maintenance of life and the attainment of wealth.

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇāḥ proktā nityamātmaguṇānvitāḥ ||
translation: The Vedas combined with additional rituals, when properly understood through the path of dharma, refer to those Brahmins who are consistently endowed with their own saṃskāras (good qualities and habits).

sloka: teṣāmabhimato yaḥ syāccetasā nityameva hi | sa dharmaḥ kathitaḥ sadbhirnānyeṣāmiti dhāraṇā ||
translation: That which is constantly and unanimously agreed upon by their intellect is referred to as the proper dharma (duty or righteousness). Nothing else.

sloka: śiṣṭāḥ khalu vigatamatsarā nirahaṃkārāḥ kumbhīdhānyā alolupā dambhadarpalobhamohakrodhavivarjitāḥ || dharmeṇādhigato yeṣāṃ vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | śiṣṭās tadanumānajñāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ || iti ||
translation: The virtuous, indeed, are free from selfishness, pride, and desire; they have discarded greed, pretense, delusion, anger, and attachment. For those who have attained excellence in dharma, the Vedas expand through understanding based on scripture and direct perception. Thus, the wise ones are known by such qualities and actions.

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇā jñeyāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ | | |
translation: Those who have fully mastered the Vedas in accordance with dharma are to be considered as accomplished brahmins, known through scriptural and direct evidence.

sloka: dṛṣṭo dharmavyatikramaḥ sāhasaṃ ca mahatāṃ || ̥ṣṭō ḥ āṁ āṁ || iti| sāhasaṃ paraśurāmādeḥ mātuḥ śirachedādi|
translation: Observed as one who oversteps the boundaries of dharma, and displays great courage against the mighty. Parashurama, for instance, beheaded his mother.

sloka: kuśalācaritenaiṣāṃ iha svārtho na vidyate | viparyayeṇa vānartho nirahaṅkāriṇāṃ prabho || ||
translation: The personal goal of those who act skillfully does not exist in this world, O Lord; or rather, for the selfless, there is no adverse consequence.

sloka: dharmajñasamayaḥ pramāṇaṃ vedāśca| vedāśca
translation: The authority (pramana) for those who know their duty (dharmajna) is the Vedas. Indeed, the Vedas are such (also).

sloka: anānmāteṣu dharmeṣu kathaṃ syāditi cedbhavet | yaṃ śiṣṭā brāhṇā bhrūyuḥ sa dharmassyādaśāṅketaḥ|| | |
translation: If among unrighteous deeds, there arises a doubt, "How could this be a righteous act?" - that marks the beginning of dharma as understood by the learned brahmins.

sloka: tadabhāve daśāvarā pariṣat|
translation: In its absence, the group is in a miserable state.

sloka: catvāro vedadharmajñāḥ pariṣatraividyameva vā| sā brūte yaṃ sa dharmassyādeko vā'dhyātmavittamaḥ||
translation: The four are known as experts in the duties of the Vedas; they either alone or together declare what is that supreme self-knowledge that constitutes one's own duty.

sloka: vedāḥ pramāṇaṃ smṛtayaḥ pramāṇaṃ dharmārthayuktaṃ vacanaṃ pramāṇam| yasya pramāṇaṃ na bhavetpramāṇaṃ na tasya kuryādvacanaṃ pramāṇam||
translation: The Vedas are the means of correct knowledge, as are the Smritis when they are in accordance with the Dharma and Artha. Words are a means of correct knowledge only for those for whom it is so; for one who does not consider it as such, words do not become a means of correct knowledge.

sloka: tathā sampradāyo'pi kacitpramāṇamityāha manuḥ| svakulaparamparāyāta ācāraḥ sampradāyaḥ| so'pi śāstravipratipattau draṣṭavyaḥ|
translation: Even the tradition (sampradaya), passed down from one's own family, is considered authoritative only if it conforms to the scriptures (shastras).

sloka: na me'nyatra kṣatriyāyā mano jātu pravartate| ṛṣiputrīṣu cānyāsu nāvarāsu parāsu ca||
translation: My mind never turns away from the Kshatriya (to someone else); nor does it become attached to other Rishis' daughters, horses, or cattle.

sloka: tasmātpraṇihitātmānaṃ viddi māṃ kalabhāṣiṇi| yasyāṃ me tvayi bhāvo'sti kṣatriyā hyasi kā vadā||
translation: Therefore, recognize me as your inmost self, O garrulous one, for my nature exists in you. What then can be your words as a Kshatriya?

sloka: smṛtiḥ pratyakṣamaitihyam | anumānaścatuṣṭayam |
translation: Memory, perception, tradition, and inference are the four means of right knowledge.

sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā | sa yenārthaṃ pramiṇoti tatpramāṇaṃ | yo'rthaḥ pratīyate tatprameyaṃ | yadarthavijñānaṃ sā pramitiḥ | catasṛṣu caivaṃvidhāsvārthatatvaṃ parisamāpyate |
translation: There, the one whose actions are associated with that speech which is conducive to right knowledge, they are the knower. The object which is known through it, is the means of valid knowledge. That object which is perceived is the knowable. The cognition of that object is true knowledge. Similarly, this fourfold relationship between the means of valid knowledge, the knowable, knowledge, and the object of knowledge is accomplished in all branches of knowledge.

sloka: yathā rajate idaṃ rajatamiti jñānam| saiva pramecyute ||||
translation: Just as silver is recognized when it is polished, so too is it acknowledged.

sloka: pramāṇamanubhūtiḥ sā smṛteranyā na sā smṛtiḥ | na pramāṇaṃ smṛtiḥ pūrvapratipattivyapekṣaṇāt|
translation: The experience that accords with valid means of knowledge is called memory (smriti), not any other kind of memory; memory is not a valid means of knowledge because it depends on prior experiences.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects of the senses, intellect, mind, and the inherent tendencies, along with their faults, results, suffering, and liberation – these are to be investigated. ({Prameya Udesasutra})

sloka: pramāṇato'rthapratipattau pravṛttisāmarththadarthavat pramāṇam | tasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya samīhā pravṛttirityucyate | dvayorekatarasya cāpi asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ pramā tatsādhakatamaṃ yattattrividhaṃ pramāṇaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The means of comprehending a correct understanding through direct perception or inference is called pramana. The capacity for such action is also referred to as pramana. Furthermore, the discernment of one from the other when they are closely related is also considered a type of pramana. These three types - perception, inference, and discernment - constitute the best means of establishing correct knowledge, according to Samkhya Sutra.

sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā |
translation: There, whoever's conduct is associated with that person's speech, they are the knower.

sloka: agne samidhamāhārṣaṃ bṛhate jātavedase | sa me śraddhāṃ ca medhāṃ ca jātavedāḥ pra yacchatu ||
translation: O seer, let us offer oblations to Agni, the all-knowing. May Jatavedas grant me faith and intelligence.

sloka: atha sapta pālāśīḥ samidha ārdrā apracchinnāgrāḥ prādeśamātrā ghṛtāktā abhyādhāpayati |
translation: Then, he arranges seven thinly chopped, unbroken, and anointed wood pieces, each of the size of a finger joint, as kindling.

sloka: agniṃ parisamūhya brahmacārī tūṣṇīṃ samidhamādadhyāt tūṣṇīṃ vai prājāpatyaṃ prājāpatyo brahmacārī bhavatīti vijñāyate
translation: After properly preparing the fire, the celibate student silently offers the oblations; it is thus known that the celibate student becomes a Brahmachari in the lineage of Prajapati.

sloka: sa idbhojo yo gṛhave dadātyannakāmāya carate kṛśāya | aramasmai bhavati yāmahūtā utāparīṣu kṛṇute sakhāyam || balaṃ balavato naśyedannahīnasya dehinaḥ| tasmādannaṃ viśeṣeṇa śraddhayāśraddhayāpi vā|| ādatte hi rasaṃ sarvamādityaḥ svagabhastibhiḥ| vāyustasmātsamādāya rasaṃ megheṣu dhārayet|| tattu meghagataṃ bhūmau śakro varṣati tādṛśam| tena digdhā bhaveddevī mahī prītā ca bhārata|| tasyāṃ sasyāni rohanti yairjīvantyakhilāḥ prajāḥ| māṃsamedo'sthimajjānāṃ sambhavastebhya eva hi||
translation: The one who selflessly gives wealth to the needy, behaves kindly towards the lean, and treats friends with hospitality; strength does not overcome the weak at his hands. Therefore, one should accept food, either with or without devotion. For, the sun extracts all juices from plants with its rays, then the wind carries them to the clouds. When Indra showers these juices on earth, the earth becomes fertile and nourishes all living beings - plants, animals, and humans alike - through them.

sloka: nīrajātaśca bhagavānsomo grahagaṇeśvaraḥ| amṛtaṃ ca sudhā caiva svāhā caiva svadhā tathā|| annauṣadhyo mahārāja vīrudhaśca jalodbhavāḥ| yataḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ prāṇāḥ sambhavanti viśāmpate|| devānāmamṛtaṃ hyannaṃ nāgānāṃ ca sudhā tathā| pitṝṇāṃ ca svadhā proktā paśūnāṃ cāpi vīrudhaḥ||
translation: The Lord, born from Nila, is the ruler of the planetary system and the controller of the grahas (astrological bodies). Immortality, nectar, svaha, and svadha indeed. O King, all vitality of living beings arises from the water-born, great one, which is also inedible. The nectar of the gods, not that of the serpents; svadha for the ancestors, and vīrudha for the animals.

sloka: tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ | ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī | pṛthivyā oṣadhayaḥ | oṣadhībhyo'nnam | annātpuruṣaḥ |
translation: Therefore, from this self, space has arisen; from space, air; from air, fire; from fire, water; from water, earth; from earth, plants; from plants, food; and from food, the person.

sloka: sa vā eṣa puruṣo'nnarasamayaḥ | tasyedameva śiraḥ | ayaṃ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamuttaraḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamātmā | idaṃ pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā | tadapyeṣa śloko bhavati ||
translation: Indeed, this person is not an ordinary one. This is the head, this is the right wing, and this is the left wing; this is the self and this is the tail, serving as a support. Still, this verse describes him thus.

sloka: ahamasmi prathamajā ṛtasya | pūrvaṃ devebhyo amṛtasya nābhiḥ | yo mā dadāti sa ideva mā''vāḥ | ahamannamannamadantamadmi |
translation: I am the first-born of truth and from the navel of the immortals. The one who gives me food, indeed, he is the god. I am the eater of food, the consumer of everything.

sloka: annaṃ prāṇamannamapānamāhuḥ | annaṃ mṛtyuṃ tamu jīvātumāhuḥ | annaṃ brahmāṇo jarasaṃ vadanti | annamāhuḥ prajananaṃ prajānām |
translation: Food, life, sustenance, the overcoming of death, and the solidifying force are called Anna. It is also referred to as the procreation of all creatures.

sloka: bhojayecchvabhyaḥ śvapacebhyaśca vayobhyaścāvapedbhūmāviti nānavattamaśnīyānnaiko na pūrvaṃ | tadapyetadṛcoktaṃ moghamannaṃ vindate apracetā iti
translation: "One should not consider eating food that has been offered to dogs, crows, or young men as the most delicious or superior to other foods. Even this is declared to be pointless and without merit for one lacking in discrimination."

sloka: moghamannaṃ vindate apracetāḥ satyaṃ bravīmi vadha itsa tasya | nāryamaṇaṃ puṣyati no sakhāyaṃ kevalāgho bhavati kevalādī ||
translation: The foolish one gains only vain effort, I indeed speak the truth: his wife does not thrive, nor do friends stay, he becomes solely a burden to others.

sloka: abhyāgato jñātapūrvo hyajñāto'tithirucyate|
translation: The one who has not studied is considered as stranger, even if he is a relative.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | |
translation: The sun sets in the evening, bringing an end to the daytime, whether it is due or premature. One should not remain at home during that time, regardless of the circumstances.

sloka: sarveṣvevājasrā agnayaḥ syuḥ agnipūjā ca nityā yathā gṛhamedhe āvasathe śrotriyāvarārdhyānatithīnvāsayet teṣāṃ yathāguṇamāvasathāḥ śayyānnapānaṃ ca videyam
translation: All household fires should always be present, and fire worship should be performed daily, just like at the time of the horse sacrifice. The host should honor the learned Brahmin as is appropriate according to their merits, providing them with a place to sleep, food, and drink.

sloka: abhṛtānāṃ bhavedbhartā bhṛtānāmanvavekṣakaḥ|
translation: Among those who are carried (by others), he becomes the bearer; among those who have awareness, he is the examiner.

sloka: saṃvibhāgo hi bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāmeva dṛśyate| tathaivāpacamānebhyaḥ pradeyaṃ gṛhamedhinā||
translation: The distribution of objects among all beings is visible. Similarly, offerings should be made to the undesirable ones also by the host of the sacrificial ceremony.

sloka: dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ yudhiṣṭhira ||
translation: Offer (your) food, O Yudhisthira, offer (your) food, offer (your) food.

sloka: yanna prāpyaṃ tadaprāpyaṃ vidyayā pauruṣeṇa vā | satyo lokapravādo'yaṃ nādattamupatiṣṭhati ||
translation: Without attaining which nothing can be achieved, either through knowledge or effort; this is the established saying in the world - it cannot be given up.

sloka: annaṃ dehi sadā rājan sarvakālasukhāvaham || annena caiva dattena kiṃ na dattaṃ mahītale |||| sarveṣāmeva dānānāmannadānaṃ viśiṣyate || annādbhavanti bhūtāni annenaiva ca varddhate ||||
translation: Grant food, O king, at all times, for it is the giver of all temporal happiness. What has not been given on this earth after being nourished by it? Of all forms of giving, the gift of food is considered the most excellent. It is through food that beings are born and grow.

sloka: na kañcana vasatau pratyācakṣīta | tadvratam | tasmādyayā kayā ca vidhayā bahvannaṃ prāpnuyāt | arādhyasmā annamityācakṣate | | edadvā antato'nna~rāddham | antato'smā anna~rādhyate || ||
translation: One should not turn away anyone who comes to one's door seeking shelter, for that is the established rule. Therefore, one should not fail to provide food and hospitality to others, as one seeks the same for oneself.

sloka: na tasmātparamaṃ dānaṃ kiñcidastīti me manaḥ| annātprāṇabhṛtastāta pravardhante hi sarvaśaḥ|| tasmādannaṃ paraṃ loke sarvalokeṣu kathyate| annādbalaṃ ca tejaśca prāṇināṃ vardhate sadā||
translation: "There is nothing superior to charity, I think. Indeed, from food, all beings derive life; through food alone, their strength and luster increase continuously. Therefore, food is said to be the foremost in the world, being the source of strength and luster for all living entities."

sloka: annena dhāryate sarvaṃ jagadetaccarācaram| annātprabhavati prāṇaḥ pratyakṣaṃ nāsti saṃśayaḥ||
translation: The entire moving and non-moving world is supported by this (substance); there is no doubt that life originates from it.

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstra caturthantu vidyā hmaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three branches are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharvaveda, and the eighth one is Arthaśāstra; indeed, these total to eighteen.

sloka: iha khalvāyurvedaṃ nāmopāṅgamatharvavedasyānutpādyaivaprajāḥ ślokaśata sahasramadhyāyasahasraṃ ca kṛtavān svayambhūḥ tato'lpāyuṣṭvamalpamedha stvaṃ cālokya narāṇāṃ bhūyo'ṣṭadhā praṇītavān vidhātātharvvasarvasvamāyurvedaṃ prakāśayan| svanāmnā saṃhitāṃ cakre lakṣaślokamayīmṛjum” iti bhāvaprakāśokteḥ |
translation: Here, in the beginning, the Self-existent one, without being taught by another, after creating the Veda of longevity consisting of a hundred thousand verses and a thousand prose passages, observed its brevity and limited efficacy. Therefore, he has again manifested for the people a renewed Veda of longevity, named "Self-existent" (Svayambhu), which is a collection of a hundred thousand verses, revealing the means of extending life.

sloka: caraṇavyūhamate ṛgvedasyopavedaḥ āyurvedaḥ
translation: The limb-wise explanation of the Rigveda is the upaveda called Ayurveda.

sloka: kimicchantī saramā predamānaḍdūre hyadhvā jaguriḥ parācaiḥ | kāsmehitiḥ kā paritakmyāsītkathaṃ rasāyā ataraḥ payāṃsi ||
translation: What did Sarama declare to the pack of dogs that had gathered far and wide, and what was the conversation between her and them about the exhilarating taste of the pressed soma juice?

sloka: kīdṛṅṅindraḥ sarame kā dṛśīkā yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraḥ parākāt | ā ca gacchānmitramenā dadhāmāthā gavāṃ gopatirno bhavāti || nāhaṃ taṃ veda dabhyaṃ dabhatsa yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraṃ parākāt | na taṃ gūhanti sravato gabhīrā hatā indreṇa paṇayaḥ śayadhve ||
translation: Who is Indra, the lord of the senses, whose behests are promptly and unquestioningly carried out even by those across the seas? And who is the protector of cows that never becomes non-existent, even when given away to others? I do not know him who can subdue this Indra, nor do the divine seers keep him hidden from those who have sharp intellect and listen attentively.

sloka: imā gāvaḥ sarame yā aicchaḥ pari divo antānsubhage patantī | kasta enā ava sṛjādayudhvyutāsmākamāyudhā santi tigmā || asenyā vaḥ paṇayo vacāṃsyaniṣavyāstanvaḥ santu pāpīḥ | adhṛṣṭo va etavā astu panthā bṛhaspatirva ubhayā na mṛl̤āt ||
translation: These cows, wishing to ascend to the heavens, are falling towards the edge of the sky. What power could produce such an occurrence for our sharp weapons?
