May your retinue be free from untruthful speech and sinful behavior. May this path be undisturbed by anyone; may Brihaspati (the god of prayer and sacred knowledge) ensure this on both sides.

sloka: ayaṃ nidhiḥ sarame adribudhno gobhiraśvebhirvasubhirnyṛṣṭaḥ | rakṣanti taṃ paṇayo ye sugopā reku padamalakamā jagantha || eha gamannṛṣayaḥ somaśitā ayāsyo aṅgiraso navagvāḥ | ta etamūrvaṃ vi bhajanta gonāmathaitadvacaḥ paṇayo vamannit || evā ca tvaṃ sarama ājagantha prabādhitā sahasā daivyena | svasāraṃ tvā kṛṇavai mā punargā apa te gavāṃ subhage bhajāma || nāhaṃ veda bhrātṛtvaṃ no svasṛtvamindro viduraṅgirasaśca ghorāḥ | gokāmā me acchadayanyadāyamapāta ita paṇayo varīyaḥ || dūramita paṇayo varīya udgāvo yantu minatīrṛtena | bṛhaspatiryā avindannigūl̤hāḥ somo grāvāṇa ṛṣayaśca viprāḥ ||
translation: This treasure, hidden and unearthed by gods, cows, and horses, is protected by the pure-hearted cowherds. Those who are devoted to it as their ultimate goal, they partake in its essence. Even you, O Sarama, should join them and not turn away from these blessed cows again. I do not know if you are our sister or Indra's. Keep my identity concealed, for these cowherds are superior to even the terrifying ones like Indra and Angiras. May the worthy cowherds, who are far-removed and pure, come here with their udders full through Vayu's path. Brihaspati, Soma, and other revered rishis cannot comprehend them.

sloka: asurāḥ paṇayo nāma rasāpāranivāsinaḥ | piveyaṃ tu payastāsāṃ gavāṃ yāstā niguhatha | asurāstāṃ tathetyuktvā tadājahuḥ payastataḥ sā svabhāvācca laulyācca pātvā tat paya āsuram |
translation: The Asuras, named Pani, dwellers of the world of liquor, should abstain from drinking that liquid. At that time, they said "we will not drink that milk," but due to their nature and desire, they ended up consuming that Asura-like milk.

sloka: tāṃ jaghāna tadā kruddha udgirantau payastataḥ jagāma sā bhayodvignā punareva paṇān prati
translation: Then, enraged, he struck her down and fled, going to the cowshed; she, frightened, returned to her father again.

sloka: atha ha vai paṇayo nāmāsurā devānāṃ gorakṣā āsuḥ| tābhir ahāpātasthuḥ| tā ha rasāyāṃ nirudhya valenāpidadhuḥ| te devā aliklavam ūcus suparṇemā no gā anviccheti| te saramām abruvan sarama imā nas tvaṃ gā anviccheti|
translation: Then, indeed, the Pañcaśikha priests served as protectors of the gods' cattle. They caused those (priests) to stand near the sacrificial altar. Having bound them in the ritual grass, they made them drink (the soma). Those gods then said to Suparna, "Come, drink these waters." They said to Sarama, "Sarama, you drink these waters."

sloka: aitareyabrāhmaṇe'sti kāṇḍamāraṇyakābhidham | araṇya aiva pāṭhyatvādāraṇyakamitīryate || satraprakaraṇe'nuktiraraṇyādhyayanāya hi | mahāvratasya tasyātra hautra karma vivicyate ||
translation: The book in the Aitareya Brahmana known as "Aranyaka" is so named because it is meant to be studied in the forest. This is mentioned in the section on the "Satra Prakarana." The significance of this Aranyaka study lies in the fact that it forms a major part of the "Mahavrata" ritual.

sloka: araṇyādhyayanādetad āraṇyakamitīryate | araṇaye tadadhīyītetyevaṃ vākyaṃ pracakṣyate ||
translation: The term "study in the forest" is referred to as "Aranyaka" because it is heard (learned) in the forest.

sloka: tasyā bharturabhicāra uktaṃ prāyaścittaṃ rahasyeṣu
translation: The usual penance prescribed for a wife's secret transgressions is mentioned (as a secret) to him (the husband).

sloka: eṣa vai somo rājā devānāmannaṃ yaccandramāḥ|
translation: This is surely the king of the moon among the gods, known as Soman.

sloka: yat idaṃ asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharoഽsmin antarākāśaḥ tasmin yadantaḥ tadanveṣṭavyaṃ tad vāva vijijñāsitavym … …
translation: In this Brahma-city, the small and lotus-like interior space should be searched for, as well as the inner expanse; that indeed must be known.

sloka: śataṃ caikā hṛdasya nāḍyaḥ tāsāṃ mūrdhānamabhiniḥsṛtaikā tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti viṣvaṅṅanyā utkramaṇe bhavanti
translation: A hundred and one are the blood vessels of the heart, from one of them arises the one that leads up to the brain; those that leave the body attain immortality.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmin is to be known by birth, and is called a dvija by the performance of samskaras. Through learning, he attains the status of a vipra. The ability to distinguish between appropriate and inappropriate expiatory acts is referred to as a mark of scholarship.

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate || ||
translation: The one who performs agnyadheya and other rituals such as pakayajnas, agniṣṭomas, etc., is considered the religious officiant (ritvij) of that person.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation: Just as from the navel (of the Lord) the universe is created and sustained, and just as herbs grow from the earth and hair from the body of a living being, so also does this entire universe originate from the imperishable.

sloka: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavidyasya jñānamayaṃ tāpaḥ | tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyāte || ||
translation: The one who is all-knowing and is made of knowledge and heat, from him arises the named Brahman, along with its form and sustenance.

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The meters, sacrifices, and rituals, as well as what has been and will be, which the Vedas declare - from me, transformed by Maya, this entire universe originates, and in this one, another is enveloped by Maya.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyavayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: Illusion is to be understood as nature, and Maheshwara (Shiva) as the magician. This entire world is pervaded by its constituents which are manifestations of that illusion.

sloka: mayā'dhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram|
translation: Under my supervision, nature brings forth both moving and non-moving (beings).

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ| nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam||||
translation: The qualities born of nature, namely goodness, passion, and darkness, bind the imperishable soul in the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: mūlaprakṛtiravikṛtirmahadādyā: prakṛtivikṛtaya: sapta | ṣoḍaśakastu vikāro na prakṛtirna vikṛti: puruṣa: || ||
translation: The original, unchanging nature is the basis; the seven constituents are products of nature and transformations. The number sixteen refers to transformations, not to nature or transformation; it is the Purusha (consciousness).

sloka: tasmātprakṛtirutpannā puruṣeṇa samanvitā || tābhyāntapaḥ kṛtaṃ tatra mūlasthe ca jale sudhīḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, nature has arisen combined with the Purusha (the cosmic being or soul); from them, heat is produced in the core and pure water at the source.

sloka: saṃbhāvya māyayā yuktastatra supto harissa vai || nārāyaṇeti vikhyātaḥ prakṛtirnārāyaṇī matā || ||
translation: Assumed to be united with maya, there lies the sleeping Lord Hari, known as Narayana, while the natural power, Narayani, is considered.

sloka: parātmanastathā śaktestayoraikyaṃ sadaiva hi | abhinnaṃ tadvapurjñātvā mucyate sarvadoṣataḥ || ||
translation: Upon realizing the non-duality of the Supreme Self (paramatman) and the individual self (shakti), one is forever liberated from all afflictions.

sloka: tasya cecchāsmyahaṃ daitya sṛjāmi sakalaṃ jagat | sa māṃ paśyati viśvātmā tasyāhaṃ prakṛtiḥ śivā || ||
translation: If I, the creator of the universe, am pleased with him, I create all desires for that sage-like selfless individual. He, in turn, recognizes me as his auspicious nature.

sloka: rāma māyā dvidhā bhāti vidyā'vidyeti te sadā |
translation: Rāma's majesty shines in two forms, as knowledge and ignorance.

sloka: dvividhā tu khalu tadvidyasaṃbhāṣā bhavati sandhāyasaṃbhāṣā vigṛhyasaṃbhāṣā ca |
translation: The speech of the learned, indeed, is of two kinds - that which is grammatically correct and that which is casually used.

sloka: prāgeva ca jalpājjalpāntaraṃ parāvarāntaraṃ pariṣadviśeṣāṃśca samyak parīkṣet parīkṣamāṇastu khalu parāvarāntaramimān jalpakaguṇān śreyaskarān doṣavataśca parīkṣeta samyak
translation: In the past, thoroughly examining the qualities of disputes between others and differences among special assemblies, one should similarly examine the meritorious and faulty speech-related qualities of oneself.

sloka: tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninastattvadarśinaḥ ||
translation: Learn that knowledge by approaching (the wise), questioning and serving them; the enlightened ones will impart that knowledge to you.

sloka: jñānagrahaṇābhyāsastadvidyaiśca saha saṃvādaḥ || ||| taṃ śiṣyagurusabrahmacāriviśiṣṭaśreyo'rthibhiranasūyubhirabhyupeyāt || || pratipakṣahīnamapi vā prayojanārthamarthitve || ||
translation: The practice of acquiring knowledge through association with the wise, as well as conversation with them; this is what should be sought after by a worthy and unprejudiced disciple living with a guru, even if it goes against one's own interests.

sloka: jñāyate'neneti jñānamātmavidyāśāstram | tasya grahaṇamadhyayanadhāraṇe abhyāsaḥ satatakriyā'dhyayanaśravaṇacintanāni tadvidyaiśca | saha saṃvāda iti prajñāparipākārthe paripākastu saṃśayacchedanamavijñātārthabodho'dhyavasitābhyanujñānamiti | samāpavādaḥ saṃvādaḥ | vābhā |
translation: Knowledge is considered to be self-knowledge and the study of scriptures; its acquisition involves listening, memorizing, contemplating, and discussing. Complete understanding for the purpose of gaining wisdom is achieved through the resolution of doubts, understanding previously unrecognized meanings, and obtaining the approval of knowledgeable authorities. Dialogue and agreement are the means to this end.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||||
translation: The argument that is based on reliable evidence, consistent, consists of five limbs, and takes into account both sides.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ
translation: A disputant who has acquired the means to establish a firm stance and refute the arguments of their opponents.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyotkarṣāpakarṣavarṇyāvarṇyavikalpasādhyaprāptyaprāptiprasaṅgapratidṛṣṭāntānutpattisaṃśayaprakaraṇahetvarthāpattyaviśeṣopapattyupalabdhyanupalabdhinityānityakāryasamāḥ || ||
translation: The distinction between what is in harmony and in discord, what is superior or inferior, pure or impure, can be ascertained through valid means of knowledge, leading to the attainment or non-attainment of their respective objects, causing doubt or certainty, subject matter of arguments, and based on examples and reasons, free from contradiction and pertaining to actions that are transient.

sloka: pratijñāhāniḥ pratijñāntaraṃ pratijñāvirodhaḥ pratijñāsaṃnyāso hetvantaramarthāntaraṃ nirarthakamavijñātārthamapārthakamaprāptakālaṃ nyūnamadhikaṃ punaruktamananubhāṣaṇamajñānamapratibhā vikṣepo matānujñā paryanuyojyopekṣaṇaṃ niranuyojyānuyogo'pasiddhānto hetvābhāsāśca nigrahasthānāni || ||
translation: Statements that are contradictory, inconsistent with prior statements, or unrelated to the topic at hand; unnecessary repetition, irrelevant knowledge, and failure to understand the matter; distraction, lack of focus, and inattentiveness; unwarranted assumptions, ignoring one's responsibilities, and false justifications; these are all considered faults.

sloka: aviśeṣābhihite arthe vaktuḥ abhiprāyātarthāntarakalpanā vākchalam ||||
translation: The speaker, in discussing a matter devoid of particulars, has the ability to convey an intended meaning or a different meaning through the use of ambiguous language.

sloka: sambhavataḥ arthasya atisāmānyayogātasambhūtārthakalpanā sāmānyacchalam ||||
translation: The concept of a spontaneously generated meaning is illogical and contrary to the principle that meanings must come from established significations.

sloka: dharmavikalpanirdeśe arthasadbhāvapratiṣedhaḥ upacāracchalam ||||
translation: In the exposition of dharma's (duty's) principles, the denial of the real nature of wealth.

sloka: yadā vādī parasya sādhanaṃ sādhviti manyate lābhapūjākhyātikāmaśca bhavati tadā jātiṃ prayuṅkte kadācidayaṃ jātyuttareṇākulīkṛto nottaraṃ pratipadyate uttarāpratipattyā ca nigṛhyate | anabhidhāne ca jātirekāntajayaḥ parasyetyaikāntikātparājayādvaramastu saṃdeha iti yukto jāteḥ prayogaḥ || nyāvā ||
translation: When one considers the means of another to be proper and seeks gains and honor from it, then they join a different caste. Sometimes, even when born in a higher caste, they get absorbed into a lower caste due to their behavior. Through this, any victory or defeat is determined by their actions alone, leaving no room for doubt. This is the appropriate application of caste.

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||||
translation: He who does not set up counter-measures and is always aggressive.

sloka: svapakṣarāgeṇa caike nyāyamativartante taca | tattvādhyavasāyasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ jalpavitaṇḍe bījaprarohasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ kaṇṭakaśākhāvaraṇavat || ||
translation: Some adhere to justice within their own group, for the sake of protecting the establishment of their own philosophical conviction and debate; this is like providing shelter to the shoot of a planted seed or covering the thorny branches.

sloka: vidyānirvedādibhiśca pareṇāvajñāyamānasya | tābhyāṃ vigṛhya kathanam || || vigṛhyeti vijigīṣayā na tattvabubhutsayeti | tadetadvidyāpālanārthaṃ na lābhapūjākhyātyarthamiti |
translation: Of one who, despite being superior, does not look down upon learning, renunciation and other such virtues, but instead embraces them; what should be the discourse? The term "vigṛhyeta" here means to strive for or aspire to understand the truth, not merely to acquire wealth or fame. This is emphasized for the purpose of promoting proper education.

sloka: budhajanairvādaḥ parityajyatām || ||
translation: Reject the company of the foolish and associate with the wise.

sloka: pakṣābhyāṃ ca mayā gupto jaṭāyurna pradahyate| pramādāttatra nirdagdhaḥ patanvāyupathādaham||||
translation: My protected Jakusa will not be consumed by either side; if negligent, he would be destroyed himself through his own actions and the force of the wind.

sloka: purā vṛtravadhe vṛtte parasparajayaiṣiṇau| ādityamupayātau svo jvalantaṃ raśmimālinam||||
translation: In the past, during the battle of Vritra's destruction, they approached (each other) for mutual victory. They moved towards the radiant Aditya, who is adorned with his own shining rays.

sloka: taṃ māmevaṃ gataṃ putrassupārśvonāma nāmataḥ| āhāreṇa yathākālaṃ bibharti patatāṃ varaḥ||||
translation: The excellent son supports/serves me, who has come near, by the name of "Suaparsva," at proper times through food.

sloka: sampātirnāma nāmnā tu cirañjīvī vihaṅgamaḥ| bhrātā jaṭāyuṣaḥ śrīmānvikhyātabalapauruṣaḥ||||
translation: The bird named Sampati is well-known to be long-lived and possesses remarkable strength, who is the brother of Jatayu.

sloka: ahaṃ tāta yathākālamāmiṣārthī khamāplutaḥ| mahendrasya girerdvāramāvṛtya susamāsthitaḥ|||| eva muktastato'haṃ taissiddhai: paramaśobhanaiḥ| sa ca me rāvaṇo rājā rakṣasāṃ prativeditaḥ|||| harandāśaratherbhāryāṃ rāmasya janakātmajām| bhraṣṭābharaṇakauśeyāṃ śokavegaparājitām|||| rāmalakṣmaṇayornāma krośantīṃ muktamūrdhajām|
translation:
Just as I, dear one, at the right time, have become detached from desire for wealth, having ascended the peak of Mount Meru, firmly established; thus, now I am liberated by those supremely auspicious sacred formulas. And this King Ravana of the rakshasas is well-known as my devotee.

The daughter of Janaka, the wife of Rama, whose ornaments and garments have been displaced, overwhelmed by the force of grief, appears to be lamenting, calling out the names of Ramah and Lakshmana, her hair disheveled.

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yannu ma iyaṃ bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te jīvitaṃ syāt amṛtatvasya tu nā''śā'sti vitteneti
translation: Maitreyi asked, "Even if this whole earth were filled with wealth, how would that make me immortal?", to which Yajnavalkya replied, "Just as the continuation of your life depends on the necessary means, so also there is no eternal life through wealth."

sloka: yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ jighrati taditara itaraṃ paśyati taditara itara śṛṇoti taditara itaramabhivadati taditara itaraṃ manute taditara itaraṃ vijānāti | yatra vā asya sarvamātmaivābhūt tatkena kaṃ jighret tatkena kaṃ paśyet tatkena ka śṛṇuyāt tatkena kamabhivadet tatkena kaṃ manvīta tatkena kaṃ vijānīyāt | yeneda sarvaṃ vijānāti taṃ kena vijānīyād vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāditi || ||
translation: Where duality arises, there one thing is smelled as different, seen as different, heard as different, spoken to as different, thought of as different, and known as different. But where all things have become one's own self, then who is to be smelled by whom, who is to be seen by whom, who is to be heard by whom, who is to be spoken to, who is to be thought of, who is to be known? Where one knows everything, then who is to know that knower, and by whom is the knower to be known?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ śraddhāṃ juhoti taseyā āhuteḥ somo rājā saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer their faith; from that oblation, Soma, the king, is produced.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ somā~ rājānaṃ juhoti tasyā āhutervarṣa saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer oblations to the king of the moon (Soma); from that offering there arises a shower of rain.

sloka: dhūmaḥ jyotiḥsalilamarutāṃ sannipātaḥ kva meghaḥ
translation: Where is the convergence of smoke, light, water, and wind?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ varṣaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteranna~ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very same fire, the gods offer a rain sacrifice; from that sacrificial offering, fire is not produced.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ annaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteretaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, gods offer oblations, from which smoke arises.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ reto juhoti tasyā āhutergarbhaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer semen, from which is born Agni's offspring.

sloka: sūrasuryāryamādityadvādaśātmadivākarāḥ | bhāskarāhaskarabradhnaprabhākaradivākarāḥ bhāsvadvisvatsaptāśvaharidaśvoṣṇaraśmayaḥ | vikartanārkamārtaṇḍamihirāruṇapūṣaṇaḥ dyumaṇistaraṇirmitrascitrabhānurvirocanaḥ | vibhāvasurgrahapatistviṣāṃpatiraharpatiḥ bhānurhaṃsaḥ sahasrāṃśustapanaḥ savitā raviḥ | māṭharaḥ piṅlo daṇḍaścaṇḍāṃśoḥ pāripārśvikāḥ
translation: The twelve sun-gods, led by Aditya, are the radiant dawn-makers, illuminating all directions with their effulgence. They are Mitra, the friend of all; Arka, the life-giver; Bhaskara, the cause of illumination; Dhinatha, the nourisher; Prabhakara, the shining one; Visvaksena, the protector of all; Surya, the guider; Hiranyagarbha, the golden womb; Marici, the ray-emitter; Savitra, the impeller; and Dandasena, the discipliner. Surrounding them are Pushan, the nourisher; Aryaman, the honorable one; Bhaga, the fortunate giver; and Tvasta, the fashioner.

sloka: svīryateḥ vā | suvateḥ vā | sūryaḥ sarteḥ vā |
translation: Of the valiant, the wealthy, or the wise born in the star constellation of Sartuga?

sloka: sūryasya patnī saṃjñābhūttanayā viśvakarmaṇaḥ | manuryamo yamī caiva tadūpatyāni vai mune || || saṃjñayamityathārkaśva chāyāyāmātmajatrayama | śanaiśvaraṃ manuñcanyaṃ tapatīñcapyajījanat || || tato vivasvānākhyāte tayaivāraṇyasaṃsthitām | samādhidṛṣṭayā dadṛśe tāmaśvāṃ tapasi svitāma || || vājirūpadharaḥ so'tha tasyāṃ devāvathāśvinau | janayāmāsa revantaṃ retaso'nte ca bhāskaraḥ || ||
translation: The consort of Surya is named Sanjña, born to the creator Visvakarma. Vamana, Yama, and the river Yamuna are her offspring. O sage, she, as the sun's consort, gave birth to Vasistha's twin sons - the Asvin brothers, after beholding herself in a meditative state, while existing in the form of darkness in the forest. Additionally, she, who is known as Vasistha's wife, gave birth to Revanta and the radiant Bhaskara through Vasistha's semen.

sloka: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tanmahitvaṃ madhyā kartorvitataṃ saṃ jabhāra yadedayukta haritaḥ sadhasthādādrātrī vāsastanute simasmai
translation: The divinity of the sun, its greatness, and the midpoint of its course, as well as its fervor and brilliance while abiding in its own place, all this is praised as belonging to Him (the deity being worshipped).

sloka: tatsaviturvareṇyaṃ bhargo devasya dhīmahi | dhiyo yo naḥ pracodayāt ||
translation: We meditate on the brilliance of the divine God Savita; may he stimulate our intellectual illumination.

sloka: oṃ bhūrbhuvaḥ svaḥ | tatsa̭vi॒turvareṇya॒ṃ bhargo̭ de॒vasya̭dhīmahi | dhiyo॒ yo na̭ḥ praco॒dayā̭t ||
translation:
We meditate on the brilliance of God,
may our intellect be illumined.

sloka: ṛgbhiḥ pūrvāhṇe divi deva īyate | yajurvede tiṣṭhati | madhye ahnaḥ | sāmavedenāstamaye mahīyate | vedairaśūnyastribhireti sūryaḥ |
translation: In the early morning, the sun illuminates the sky through its rays; it resides in the Yajurveda at noon; in the afternoon, it is established in the Sāmaveda; and in the evening, it becomes dominant in the world by means of the three Vedas devoid of any discrepancies.

sloka: suṣumno harikeśaśca viśvakarmā tathaiva ca | viśvaśravāḥ punaścānyaḥ saṃyadvasurataḥ paraḥ || arvāvasuriti khyātaḥ svarakaḥ sapta kīrtitāḥ | suṣumnaḥ sūryaraśmistu puṣṇāti śiśiradyutim ||
translation: Susumna, Harikeśa, Viśvakarma, and the one known as Samyadvasurata are the four; there is also another one named Arvavasuri. They are all seven times praised and illuminate the cool light of the sun.

sloka: saṃsthitenaikacakreṇa paṃcāreṇa trinābhinā || hiraṇmayena bhagavāṃstathaiva haridarvaṇā || ||
translation: With a single chakra (discus) established, similarly with three; O Bhagavan, adorned with a golden discus and a sudarshana (another type of discus).

sloka: ete tapanti varṣanti bhānti vānti sṛjanti ca | bhūtānāmaśubhaṃ karma vyapohantīha kīrttitāḥ || ete sahaiva sūryeṇa bhramanti divi bhānugāḥ | vimāne ca sthito nityaṃ kāmage vātaraṃhasi ||
translation: These (celestial bodies) radiate, rain, shine, and generate; they are known to dispel the evil deeds of living beings. Together with the sun, they move in the sky, eternally stationed in the wind's vehicle (air); (and) in a flying machine.

sloka: saratho'dhiṣṭhito devairādityairmunibhistathā || gaṃdharvairapsarobhiśca grāmaṇīsarparākṣasaiḥ || ||
translation: Seated on the chariot and commanded by the gods, including Adityas, Munis, Gandharvas, Apsaras, Gramaṇīs, and Rākṣasas.

sloka: sūryeṇa viṣuvaṃ vidyā tkālaṃ somena lakṣayet || samā rātrirahaścaiva yadā tadviṣuvaṃ bhavet || ||
translation: The correct time for learning (vidyatam) is divided by the sun; similarly, the day and night are also equally divided by it.

sloka: devaliṅ‌gapraticchannaḥ svarbhānurdevasaṃsadi | praviṣṭaḥ somamapibat candrārkābhyāṃ ca sūcitaḥ || ||
translation: Veiled by the disguise of a devotee, Swarbhanu has entered the assembly of devas and is made known by drinking Soma. He is also illuminated by the moon and the sun.

sloka: pramāṇaprameyasaṃśayaprayojanadṛṣṭāntasiddhāntāvayavatarkanirṇayavādajalpavitaṇḍāhetvābhāsacchalajātinigrahasthānānāṃ tatvajñānānniḥśreyasādhigamaḥ || {padārthoddeśasūtram}
translation: The attainment of ultimate good is through the knowledge of truth, which consists of means of valid knowledge , objects of knowledge , doubts , purposes , examples , established tenets , components , arguments , reasoning , discussion , fallacious reasonings , doubts about the existence and non-existence of a thing, and their negation. {padarthoddesasutram}

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, and credible testimony are the means of valid knowledge. (From Pramāṇa-uddesa Sutra)

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects of sense, intellect, mind, and the nature of being, with its causes, effects, aging, and cessation, are to be investigated.

sloka: samānānekadharmopapatteḥ vipratipatteḥ upalabdhyanupalabdhyavyavasthātaḥ ca viśeṣāpekṣaḥ vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ || {saṃśayalakṣaṇam}
translation: Inquiry into distinction, based on the presence or absence, occurrence or non-occurrence, and the agreement or disagreement of various characteristics and properties – this is called saṃśaya (doubt).

sloka: yaṃ arthaṃ adhikṛtya pravartate tatprayojanam ||{prayojanalakṣaṇam}
translation: The purpose of an action is that for which it is performed.

sloka: laukikaparīkṣakāṇāṃ yasminarthe buddhisāmyaṃ saḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ || {dṛṣṭāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: In the matter that is agreed upon by ordinary examiners, he is the example.

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established doctrine is the acceptance of the authority in a given context regarding the principles of tantra. {This defines the marks of established doctrine and acceptance in tantra.}

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ || {avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The constituents of a promise are stating the promise, giving a reason, presenting evidence, drawing a conclusion, and indicating the means to achieve it. (avayavauddesasutra)

sloka: avijñātatatve arthe kāraṇopapattitaḥ tattvajñānārthaṃ uhaḥ tarkaḥ||
translation: Inference has arisen as a means to understand the true nature (of things) due to the occurrence of causes in the realm of ignorance about reality.

sloka: vimṛśya pakṣapratipakṣābhyāṃ arthāvadhāraṇaṃ nirṇayaḥ||
translation: Reflection on both sides (pros and cons) leads to the understanding and determination of the meaning (of a situation or issue).

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||
translation: A debate that is supported by proofs, based on logical reasoning, free from contradiction, established in the five members, and taking into account both sides of the argument.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ ||
translation: A debater who has acquired (learned) the means to establish a firm seat by overpowering the unsteady opinions of their opponents.

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||
translation: He who is not established in setting up counter-measures (to negative thoughts) and is quarrelsome.

sloka: savyabhicāraviruddhaprakaraṇasamasādhyasamakālātītāḥ hetvābhāsāḥ ||
translation: Illusions of causes that are incompatible, co-occurrent, and simultaneous with the effect, having already occurred.

sloka: vacanavighātaḥ arthavikalpopapattyā chalam ||
translation: The speech devoid of obstacles, and not unstable due to the emergence of doubts about the meaning.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyābhyāṃ pratyavasthānaṃ jātiḥ||
translation: The determination of both similarity and dissimilarity is the definition (jati) of an object.

sloka: vipratipattiḥ apratipattiḥ ca nigrahasthānam || tadvikalpātjātinigrahasthānabahutvam ||
translation: The establishment and non-establishment of a counselor/advisor lead to their respective positions; due to the variety of choices, there arises multiplicity in the positions of those who establish counsels.

sloka: duḥkhajanmapravṛttidoṣamithyājñānānāṃ uttarottarāpāye tadanantarāpāyātapavargaḥ||
translation: The gradual destruction of the accumulated evils of birth and experience, arising from incorrect knowledge, is brought about by subsequent spiritual disciplines.

sloka: śvetā raktā ca pītā ca kṛṣṇā kāpotasannibhā | tiktā ca kaṭukā caiva kaṣāyalavaṇāmlakā || madhurā ṣaḍrasopetā sarvasampatkarī dharā |
translation: Fair, red, and yellow; black, resembling a crow; pungent, bitter, sour, salty, sweet, and astringent – all types of tastes are present in it (the earth).

sloka: vakṣye'haṃ grāmavinyāsaṃ śāstre saṃkṣepataḥ kramāt | daṇḍakaṃ sarvatobhadraṃ nandyāvartaṃ tu padmakam || svastikaṃ prastaraṃ caiva kārmukaṃ ca caturmukham | evaṃ cāṣṭavidhaṃ grāmaṃ tattadrūpeṇa saṃjñitam ||
translation: I will now explain the arrangement of a village according to scriptural digest in a succinct and step-by-step manner. The well-rounded Dandaka is in the shape of a staff, Nandyavarta is lotus-shaped, Svastika is cross-shaped, and Chaturmukha is quadrilateral. Thus, a village is classified into eight forms.

sloka: alpākṣaramasandigdhaṃ sāravadviśvato mukham| astobhamanavadhyañca sūtraṃ sūtravido viduḥ||
translation: The wise know it as a compact, clear, and all-encompassing statement, uninterrupted, invulnerable, and constituting the essence of teachings.

sloka: tac cakṣur devahitaṃ purastāc chukram uc carat | paśyema śaradaḥ śataṃ jīvema śaradaḥ śatam
translation: That divine eye, placed in front, swiftly moves. May we see for a hundred autumns, may we live for a hundred autumns.

sloka: tasmādyajñātsarvahuta ṛca: sāmāni jajñire | chandāṃsi jajñire tasmādyajustasmādajāyata ||
translation: Therefore, the Yajus, Samans, and chants were born from it; hence the sacrifice, hence the birth of offspring.

sloka: yad vai yajñasya sāmnā yajuṣā kriyate śithilaṃ tat | yad ṛcā tad dṛḍham |
translation: What is loose when performed with the sāman chants during a sacrifice, becomes firm when performed with the ṛc chants.

sloka: ekaṃ sadviprā bahudhā vadantyagniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānamāhuḥ ||
translation: They call by different names the one fire, such as Agni, Yama, and Mātariśvan.

sloka: saṃgaṭhana sūktam saṃvanana āṅgirasaḥ| agniḥ saṃjñānam| anuṣṭup triṣṭup| saṃsa॒midyṷvase vṛṣa॒nnagne॒ viśvā̭nya॒rya ā | i॒l̤aspa॒de sami̭dhyase॒ sa no॒ vasū॒nyā bha̭ra || saṃ ga̭cchadhva॒ṃ saṃ va̭dadhva॒ṃ saṃ vo॒ manā̭ṃsi jānatām | de॒vā bhā॒gaṃ yathā॒ pūrvḙ saṃjānā॒nā u॒pāsa̭te || sa॒mā॒no mantra॒: sami̭tiḥ samā॒nī sa̭mā॒naṃ mana̭: sa॒ha ci॒ttamḙṣām | sa॒mā॒naṃ mantra̭ma॒bhi ma̭ntraye vaḥ samā॒nena̭ vo ha॒viṣā̭ juhomi || sa॒mā॒nī va॒ ākṷ̄tiḥ samā॒nā hṛda̭yāni vaḥ | sa॒mā॒nama̭stu vo॒ mano॒ yathā̭ va॒: susa॒hāsa̭ti ||
translation: Gather together, engage in recitation, be of one mind; know this ritual formula, the steady and harmonious one. Likewise, the hymn is harmonious, the mind is harmonious, with the finest oblations we offer to you through the harmonious ritual formula. May your perception be harmonious, may your hearts be harmonious, may your minds be harmonious, just as it was in ancient times. Homage to you, the harmonious one; may your mind become harmonious for our benefit, as is desired.

sloka: sāmāni yo vetti sa veda tattvam |
translation: The one who understands equivalence (or sameness) knows the truth.

sloka: sāmna udgītho rasaḥ |
translation: The udgitha (a type of hymn in the Samaveda) is the essence (rasa).

sloka: jagrāha pāṭhyaṃ ṛgvedāt‌ sāmabhyo gītameva ca yajurvedādabhinayān rasamātharvaṇādapi||
translation: He took up the recitation of the Rigveda, mastered the Sama Veda by heart, studied the Yajurveda with depth, and even mastered the Atharvana Veda.

sloka: tata utkocakaṃ tīrthaṃ gatvā dhaumyāśramaṃ tu te| taṃ vavruḥ pāṇḍavā dhaumyaṃ paurohityāya bhārata||
translation: After reaching the sacred site named Tata, the Pāndavas then went to Dhaumya's hermitage. They approached Dhaumya for the purpose of a family priest, O Bhārata.

sloka: abhyaṣiñcattato dhaumyo vyāsaśca sumahātapāḥ| nāradaṃ ca puraskṛtya devalaṃ cāsitaṃ munim||
translation: Then Dhaumya, along with Vyasa of great austerities, and preceded by Narada, initiated Devala as a student.

sloka: vyāghrapāda iti khyāto vedavedāṅgapāragaḥ| tasyāhamabhavaṃ putro dhaumyaścāpi mamānujaḥ||
translation: I am known as Vyaghrapada, the expert in Vedangas (auxiliary branches of Vedas). Dhaumya is my younger brother.

sloka: kṣīrodanasamāyuktaṃ bhojanaṃ hi prayaccha me||
translation: Please offer me a meal that is associated with Kshiroda.

sloka: śakrarūpaṃ sa kṛtvā tu sarvairdevagaṇairvṛtaḥ| sahasrākṣastadā bhūtvā vajrapāṇirmahāyaśāḥ||
translation: Assuming the form of Indra, filled with joy and approved by all groups of gods, becoming a thousand-eyed one, wielding a thunderbolt and possessing great fame.

sloka: etasminnantare kaścidṛṣirdhaumyo nāmāyodastasya śiṣyāstrayo babhūvurupamanyurāruṇirvedaśceti||
translation: In the next mantra, there were three disciples of the sage named Ṛṣyadorjita: Upamanyu, Aruṇi, and Veda.

sloka: sa ekaṃ śiṣyamāruṇiṃ pāñcālaṃ preṣayāmāsa gaccha kedārakhaṇḍaṃ badhāneti|| ta tatra saṃviveśa kedārakhaṇḍe śayāne ca tathā tasmiṃstadudakaṃ tasthau||
translation: He (Shiva) sent a single disciple, from the Pancala region named Aruni, to Kedara. He entered and rested there, standing near the water in that very place.

sloka: sa evamukta upādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca yasmādbhavānkedārakhaṇḍaṃ vidāryotthitastasmātuddālaka eva nāmnā bhavānbhaviṣyatītyupādhyāyenānugṛhītaḥ||
translation: Having been addressed thus by the teacher, the one who became separate from the portion of earth (Prithivi) spoke back, "That's why you will be known as Uddalaka (separated from earth), henceforth."

sloka: sa upādhyāyaṃ pratyuvāca bho bhaikṣyeṇa vṛttiṃ kalpayāmīti||
translation: He said to his teacher, "I will subsist on alms."

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca mayyanivedya bhaikṣyaṃ nopayoktavyamiti|| sa tathetyuktvā bhaikṣyaṃ caritvopādhyāyāya nyavedayat||
translation: The teacher replied to him, "One should not ask for alms." He then acted accordingly and later reported this to the teacher.

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca naiṣā nyāyyā guruvṛttiranyeṣāmapi bhaikṣyopajīvināṃ vṛttyuparodhaṃ karoṣi ityevaṃ vartamāno lubdho'sīti ||
translation: The teacher replied, "This is not a justifiable practice, even for those who live on alms. By acting in such a way, you have become greedy."

sloka: sa tairarkapatrairbhakṣitaiḥ kṣāratiktakaṭurūkṣaistīkṣṇavipākaiścakṣuṣyupahato'ndho babhūva|| tataḥ so'ndho'pi caṅkramyamāṇaḥ kūpe papāta||
translation: With those blind-folded leaves consumed, splashed with the juices of the sour Katuruka fruit, his eyes became damaged. Then, even though he was already blind, while walking, he stumbled into a well.

sloka: tamaśvināvāhatuḥ prītau svastavānayā gurubhaktyā upādhyāyasya te kārṣṇāyasā dantā bhavato'pi hiraṇmayā bhaviṣyanti cakṣuṣmāṃśca bhaviṣyasīti śreyaścāvāpsyasīti||
translation: May your teeth, become gold-like, through the pursuit of learning from your revered teacher, the son of Kaurava, with devotion, and pleasure. You will also gain sharp eyesight and ultimately achieve what is truly auspicious.

sloka: tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bheryaśca paṇavānakagomukhāḥ | sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdastumulo'bhavat || tataḥ śvetairhayairyukte mahati syandane sthitau | mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaścaiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ || pāñcajanyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṃ dhanañjayaḥ | pauṇḍraṃ dadhmau mahāśaṅkhaṃ bhīmakarmā vṛkodaraḥ ||
translation: Then, conches including the "Shankh," "Bheri," "Pana," "Anaka," and "Gomukh" were blown all at once, creating a tremendous sound. Seated in a grand chariot drawn by white horses, Madhav (Krishna) and Pandava (Arjuna) blew their divine conches "Panchajanya" and "Devadatta," respectively. The mighty Bhima, known for his fierce deeds, sounded the "Paundra" conch.

sloka: asthānasnehakārpaṇyadharmādharmadhiyā''kulam | pārthaṃ prapannamuddiśya śāstrāvataraṇaṃ kṛtam || ||
translation: With the intent of guiding Arjuna, who has sought refuge, a treatise on dharma and adharma has been composed, taking into account factors such as family lineage, compassion, and graciousness.

sloka: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ | māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata saṃjaya ||
translation: Dhritarashtra said to Sanjaya: "Assembled on the battlefield of Kurukshetra are parties eager for fight, my people and the Pandavas. What are they doing?"

sloka: dharmakṣayāt trāyate iti dharmakṣetram |
translation: "Called the field of righteousness, for it delivers one from the destruction of righteousness."

sloka: sañjaya uvāca dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṃ vyūḍhaṃ duryodhanastadā | ācāryamupasaṃgamya rājā vacanamabravīt || paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍuputrāṇāmācārya mahatīṃ camūm | vyūḍhāṃ drupadaputreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Seeing the Pandava army arrayed, King Duryodhana approached his teacher and spoke these words: "Have you seen this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by your intelligent disciple, Drupada's son?"

sloka: aparyāptaṃ tadasmākaṃ balaṃ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam | paryāptaṃ tvidameteṣāṃ balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam || ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ | bhīṣmamevābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi ||
translation: Our strength is not sufficient, being protected by Bhishma; but theirs (Pandavas') is sufficient, being protected by Bhima. Being stationed in each respective battle formation, all of you should protect Bhishma alone.

sloka: mahīpate | senayorubhayormadhye rathaṃ sthāpaya me'cyuta || yāvadetānnirikṣe'haṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān | kairmayā saha yoddhavyamasmin raṇasamudyame || yotsyamānānavekṣe'haṃ ya ete'tra samāgatāḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddheryuddhe priyacikīrṣavaḥ ||
translation: O king, place my chariot in the middle of both armies so that I may observe those who are eager to fight and decide with whom I should fight in this battle, as I see fit, those who have gathered here for the unrighteous Duryodhana's war.

sloka: pārtha paśyaitānsamavetānkurūniti ||
translation: Behold, Pārtha, these Kurus gathered here (on the battlefield)!

sloka: dṛṣṭvemaṃ svajanaṃ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṃ samupasthitam || sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṃ ca pariśuṣyati vepathuśca śarīre me romaharṣaśca jāyate || gāṇḍīvaṃ sraṃsate hastāttvakcaiva paridahyate na ca śaknomyavasthātuṃ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ || nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni keśava na ca śreyo'nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanamāhave || na kāṅkṣe vijayaṃ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṃ sukhāni ca kiṃ no rājyena govinda kiṃ bhogairjīvitena vā ||
translation: Seeing my kinsmen standing arrayed in battle, my limbs grow weak, my mouth becomes dry, my body shivers and my hair stands on end. The bow, Gāṇḍīva, slips from my hand and my skin burns all over. I am unable to stand still, my mind seems to be whirling. And I see adverse omens, O Kṛṣṇa. I do not see any good in killing my own kinsmen in this battle, nor does victory, or kingdom, or pleasure, or even life itself seem to be worthwhile, O Govinda.

sloka: aho bata mahatpāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam | yadrājyasukhalobhena hantuṃ svajanamudyatāḥ || yadi māmapratīkāramaśastraṃ śastrapāṇayaḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyustanme kṣemataraṃ bhavet ||
translation: Alas, we have decided to commit a great sin, eager to kill our own kin due to our attachment to royal pleasure. If, wielding weapons, the Dhartarastras were to kill me in battle, it would be beneficial for me.

sloka: kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ | dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnamadharmo'bhibhavatyuta || utsannakuladharmāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana | narake'niyataṃ vāso bhavatītyanuśuśruma ||
translation: When the family's natural order is destroyed after its destruction, O Janardana, the traditional duties of the family also perish. With the eradication of righteousness, lawlessness prevails in the entire family. It has been heard that when the family's traditional duties are lost, people of such families inevitably dwell in hell.

sloka: yadyapyete na paśyanti lobhopahatacetasaḥ | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ mitradrohe ca pātakam || kathaṃ na jñeyamasmābhiḥ pāpādasmānnivartitum | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ prapaśyadbhirjanārdana ||
translation: Even if they don't see (the faults) due to their minds being clouded by greed, how can we not recognize and turn away from the transgression caused by the destruction of the family lineage and hostility towards friends? Those who see should understand.

sloka: nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrānnaḥ kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana | pāpamevāśrayedasmānhatvaitānātatāyinaḥ || tasmānnārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ dhārtarāṣṭrānsvabāndhavān | svajanaṃ hi kathaṃ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava ||
translation: What pleasure can there be, oh Janardana, in killing the Dhartarastras? It would be better to pardon them. How could we be happy after killing our own kin? O Madhava, it is not befitting us to kill our own kinsmen, the Dhartarastras.

sloka: ū॒rdhva ū॒ ṣu ṇo̭ adhvarasya hota॒ragne॒ tiṣṭha̭ de॒vatā̭tā॒ yajī̭yān |
translation: Rise, oh Hotar, and stand at the forefront of the ritual, as the priest in charge. Invoke the gods and offer sacrifices.

sloka: agnirekākṣareṇa vāca mudajayat
translation: The fire has started to blaze brilliantly with the single utterance of "ekākṣara" (the syllable "Om").

sloka: vākyaṃ syādyogyatākāṅkṣāsattiyuktaḥ padoccayaḥ |
translation: A statement expressing a desire to know about the meaning of a sentence, endowed with sincerity.

sloka: śabdaḥ anumānaṃ arthasya anupalabdheḥ anumeyatvāt ||
translation: Sound is the means of inferring something in the absence of its direct perception, due to its being a basis for inference.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ|
translation: The word means "The instruction given by a competent person."

sloka: āptaḥ khalu sākṣātkṛtadharmā |
translation: The one who has directly realized the eternal duties (dharma).

sloka: āptopadeśasāmarthyātśabdātarthasampratyayaḥ || pūraṇapradāhapāṭanānupalabdheḥ ca sambandhābhāvaḥ ||
translation: The connection (of words and their meanings) is established through proper instruction, understanding the meaning from the word itself, or through the absence of anticipated connections in the context.

sloka: yenoccāritena sāsnālāṅgūlakakudakhuraviṣāṇināṃ saṃpratyayo bhavati sa śabdaḥ |
translation: The sound made by the movement of the finger on the Sanskrit word "cāritena" indicates an affirmative understanding.

sloka: svapnādipratyaye bāhyaṃ sarvathā na hi neṣyate || ||sarvatrālambanaṃ bāhyaṃ deśakālānyathātmakam | janmanyekatra bhinne vā tathā kālāntare'pi vā || ||taddeśo vānyadeśo vā svapnajñānasya gocaraḥ | alātacakre'lātaṃ syācchīghrabhramaṇasaṃskṛtam || ||gandharvanagare'bhrāṇi pūrvadṛṣṭaṃ gṛhādi ca | pūrvānubhūtatoyaṃ ca raśmitaptoṣaraṃ tathā || ||mṛgatoyasya vijñāne kāraṇatvena kalpyate | dravyāntare viṣāṇaṃ ca śaśasyatmā ca kāraṇam || ||śaśaśṛṅgadhiyo mauṇḍyaṃ niṣedhe śiraso'sya ca | vastvantarairasaṃsṛṣṭaḥ padārthaḥ śūnyatādhiyaḥ || ||kāraṇatvaṃ padārthānāmasadvākyārthakalpane | atyantānanubhūto'pi buddhyā yo'rthaḥ prakalpyate ||
translation: The external objects are not carried over from dreams and other similar states, as they are distinct in terms of place, time, and cause. The locus of knowledge of dreams is the mind, which has been endowed with subtle movements like those of an ant's legs. In the city of the gandharvas (a celestial realm), one experiences previously seen houses and other things. The knowledge of water in a deer's antlers is ascribed to it as its cause, just as poison is attributed to a snake. The de-horned state of a deer or the shaving of its horns is not caused by external objects but is a product of human intention. Similarly, the ultimate determination of an object's nature, whether experienced or not, is a construct of the intellect through linguistic and conceptual means.

sloka: atyantāsatyapi jñānamarthe śabdaḥ karoti hi|
translation: The word indeed makes knowledge of the absolute truth known.

sloka: tasya retaḥ pracaskanda dṛṣṭvāpsarasamurvaśīm| apsūpaspṛśato rājanmṛgī taccāpibattadā|| tasyarṣeḥ śṛṅgaṃ śirasi rājannāsīnmahātmanaḥ| tenarṣyaśṛṅga ityevaṃ tadā sa prathito'bhavat||
translation: Upon seeing the drops of semen discharged into the water, resembling an apsara, a female deer also bathed in it, O king. At that moment, the noble-minded sage's ascetic power became well-known as "Rishyasringa," referring to the legend of the deer and the sage's semen in the water.

sloka: purohitāpacārācca tasya rājño yadṛcchayā| na vavarṣa sahasrākṣastato'pīḍyanta vai prajāḥ||
translation: Even the heavenly king Indra didn't withhold his showering out of respect for the king's purohita and due to the king's will. Thus, the people were not troubled.

sloka: ihāgato jaṭilo brahmacārī na vai hrasvo nātidīrgho manasvī| suvarṇavarṇaḥ kamalāyatākṣaḥ svataḥ surāṇāmiva śobhamānaḥ||
translation: Here comes the ascetic, a student of sacred knowledge, not overly thin or excessively tall, wise, with gold-like complexion and lotus-like eyes, shining in his own right like the celestials.

sloka: sa lomapādaḥ paripūrṇakāmaḥ sutāṃ dadāvṛṣyaśṛṅgāya śāntām| krodhapratīkārakaraṃ ca cakre gāścaiva mārgeṣu ca karṣaṇāni||
translation: That Lomapada, fulfilled in desires, gave his daughter to Rishyasringa, who is peaceful. He also made arrangements for cows and created obstacles on the paths (to prevent others from disturbing Rishyasringa).

sloka: ṛṣyaśṛṅgastu jāmātā putrāṃstava vidhāsyati sanatkumārakathitametāvadvyāhṛtaṃ mayā
translation: Rishyasringa, your father, will indeed carry out the promise he made to me.

sloka: brahmacārī gṛhasthaśca vānaprastho yatistathā | ete gṛhasthaprabhavāścatvāraḥ pṛthagāśramāḥ | yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yathā nadīnadāḥ sarve sāgare yānti saṃsthitim | tathaivāśramiṇaḥ sarve gṛhasthe yānti saṃsthitim |
translation: Just as all beings exist depending on the air, so do all ascetics live having taken shelter in the householder stage. Just as all rivers flow and merge into the ocean, similarly all ascetics reach their final goal by living in the householder stage.

sloka: gṛhasthaḥ pravarasteṣāṃ gārhasthyaṃ dharmamāśritaḥ|
translation: The householder is the foremost among those who have taken up the observance of domestic life as their duty.

sloka: samyaktapaścarantīha śraddadhānā vanāśrame | gṛhāśramasya te devi kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm ||
translation: Those who practice austerities with proper discipline and are devoted, in the forest or domestic setting, do not waste away even a sixteenth part of their (spiritual) endeavor, O Goddess.

sloka: yathā mātaramāśritya sarve jīvanti jantavaḥ | tathā gṛhāśramaṃ prāpya sarve jīvanti cāśramāḥ||
translation: Just as all beings live relying on their mothers, similarly, all beings living in the gṛhāśrama (householder stage of life) also survive.

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset |
translation: Having properly studied the Vedas or one of the Vedas, a perpetually celibate student may enter the life-stage of a householder.

sloka: adhītya vedānkṛtasarvakṛtyaḥ saṃtānamutpādya sukhāni bhuktvā| samāhitaḥ pracaredduścaraṃ taṃ gārhasthyadharmaṃ munidharmajuṣṭam||
translation: Having studied the Vedas and completed all duties, after enjoying pleasures in a content manner, one should properly perform the social duty of householder's life, which is in accordance with sage's way of life.

sloka: sarveṣāṃ api caiteṣāṃ vedasmṛtividhānataḥ | gṛhastha ucyate śreṣṭhaḥ sa trīnetānbibharti hi |
translation: Among all who have properly studied and understood the Vedas and smritis, the householder is considered the best, as they maintain the three debts (to the gods, sages, and ancestors).

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca ||
translation: A virtuous man, skilled and with self-control, who has faith and has conquered his senses, engages in actions among the threefold divisions of society, as well as among women, as long as is necessary for the purpose.

sloka: pañcayajñaviśuddhātmā ṛtunityo'nasūyakaḥ| dānto brāhmaṇasatkartā susaṃmṛṣṭaniveśanaḥ|| cakṣuḥśrotramanojihvāsnigdhavarṇapradaḥ sadā| atithyabhyāgatarataḥ śeṣānnakṛtabhojanaḥ|| pādyamarghyaṃ yathānyāyamāsanaṃ śayanaṃ tathā| dīpaṃ pratiśrayaṃ caiva yo dadāti sa dhārmikaḥ||
translation: A person with a pure mind, who is truthful, free from envy, self-controlled, engaged in the service of Brahmins and guests, always offers food and water to everyone as per custom, provides seat, water for washing feet, welcomes and offers proper reception, light, and protection to the guests; such a person is truly righteous.

sloka: mṛgoṣṭrakharamarkākhu sarīsṛpkhagamakṣikāḥ | ātmanaḥ putravatpaśyet taireṣāmantaraṃ kiyat ||
translation: Observing them as if they were his own sons, should one look at animals, trees, clay, stones, potsherds, and even worms with a sense of detachment.

sloka: svadāratuṣṭastvṛtukālagāmī niyogasevī na śaṭho na jihnaḥ| mitāśano devarataḥ kṛtajñaḥ satyo mṛduścānṛśaṃsaḥ kṣamāvān||
translation: A householder who is content with his simple living, devoted to religious duties, not deceitful or greedy, eating moderately, truthful, kind, and forgiving.

sloka: śarīramekaṃ daṃpatyorvidhātrā pūrvanirmitam| tasmātsvadāranirato brahmacārī vidhīyate||
translation: The single physical form that was created by the two partners before is what should be devotedly observed as a brahmachari (celibate).

sloka: ekenāṃśena dharmārthaḥ kartavyo hitamicchatā| ekenāṃśena kāmārthamekamaṃśaṃ vivardhayet||
translation: With a fraction of effort, one should pursue their duty and desire for the well-being of others; with another fraction, they should enhance their own pleasure and prosperity.

sloka: yāvad arthamupāsīno dehe gehe ca paṇḍitaḥ | virakto raktavat tatra nṛloke naratāṃ nyaset || divyaṃ bhaumaṃ cāntarīkṣaṃ vittaṃ acyutanirmitam | tatsarvaṃ upayuñjāna etatkuryāt svato budhaḥ ||
translation: As long as a wise person engaged in the contemplation of meaning resides in a body and a home, they should independently make use of all divine, earthly, and heavenly wealth, without attachment or preference for any one thing or person in this world.

sloka: yāvad bhriyeta jaṭharaṃ tāvat svatvaṃ hi dehinām | adhikaṃ yo'bhimanyeta sa steno daṇḍamarhati ||
translation: As long as the body is cared for, so long does one consider something as one's own; one who overly covets more than that deserves to be punished as a thief.

sloka: dānto vidheyo havyakavyāpramatto hyannasya dātā satataṃ dvijebhyaḥ| amatsarī sarvaliṅgapradātā vaitānanityaśca gṛhāśramī syāt||
translation: The householder who is always controlled, disciplined, devoted to the rituals, and regularly gives food to the Brahmins, free from jealousy, and gives away all belongings, is not ephemeral.

sloka: atithipriyatā dharmo dharmastretāgnidhāraṇam| iṣṭirvā paśubandhāśca vidhipūrvaṃ paraṃtapa||
translation: Hospitality towards guests is a duty, as is the proper maintenance of the sacred fire. Additionally, pleasing the gods and tending to animals are also duties to be performed first, O vanquisher of foes.

sloka: vaivāhike'gnau kurvīta gṛhyaṃ karma yathāvidhi | pañcayajñavidhānaṃ ca paktiṃ cānvāhikīṃ gṛhī |
translation: In the marriage fire, one should perform the nuptial rite as prescribed. One should also observe the five daily obligatory duties and the additional rites for ancestors.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan | tāsāṃ krameṇa sarvāsāṃ niṣkṛtyarthaṃ maharṣibhiḥ | pañca klptā mahāyajñāḥ pratyahaṃ gṛhamedhinām |
translation: The five gifts that a householder should offer to their guests are betel nuts, sesame seeds, a seat, water for washing feet, and an oil lamp. This is recommended by the great sages for the accomplishment of all duties of householders; it becomes the great sacrifices performed daily.

sloka: svādhyāyenārcayeta rṣīnhomairdevānyathāvidhi | pitṝñ śrāddhaiśca nṝnannairbhūtāni balikarmaṇā |
translation: Through daily study (svadhyaya) and offering worship to the rishis and devatas according to proper procedure, as well as through offerings made to pitrs and respect shown to men and beings through sacrificial acts (bali karmani).

sloka: pañcaitānyo mahāayajñānna hāpayati śaktitaḥ | sa gṛhe'pi vasannityaṃ sūnādoṣairna lipyate | devatātithibhṛtyānāṃ pitṝṇāṃ ātmanaśca yaḥ | na nirvapati pañcānāṃ ucchvasanna sa jīvati | svādhyāye nityayuktaḥ syāddaive caiveha karmaṇi | daivakarmaṇi yukto hi bibhartīdaṃ carācaram |
translation: Except for these five great sacrifices, no one who is capable can perform them while living at home without being tainted by small sins. The one who serves gods, guests, servants, ancestors, and oneself by performing the five sacrificial duties and engaging in daily study and prescribed actions, indeed supports all that moves and moves not.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī |
translation: By properly serving a guest in this way and giving alms to a ascetic, a twice-born person obtains the merit equivalent to giving away land to a deserving teacher.

sloka: saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam |
translation: Upon your arrival, he should offer you a seated position and water. Also, he should respectfully provide food according to his ability, following the proper procedures.

sloka: bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | devānṛṣīnmanuṣyāṃśca pitṝngṛhyāśca devatāḥ | pūjayitvā tataḥ paścādgṛhasthaḥ śeṣabhugbhavet |
translation: After satisfying the guests, oneself, and household servants, the householder should partake of the remaining food. Only then should one offer oblations to the gods, ancestors, sages, humans, and revered deities; only after performing their worship can a householder become one who partakes of what remains.

sloka: śuśrūṣante ye pitaraṃ mātaraṃ ca gṛhāśrame| bhartāraṃ caiva yā nārī agnihotraṃ ca ye dvijāḥ|| teṣuteṣu ca prīṇanti devā indrapurogamāḥ| pitaraḥ pitṛlokasthāḥ svadharmeṇa sa rajyate||
translation: Those who serve their father, mother, and wife, as well as the household fire, and those chaste men who perform the agnihotra - the celestial beings, led by Indra, are pleased with them. And so do they prosper in their own duty, and reach the abode of their forefathers.

sloka: maharṣipitṛdevānāṃ gatvānṛṇyaṃ yathāvidhi | putre sarvaṃ samāsajya vasenmādhyasthyaṃ āśritaḥ |
translation: After properly visiting the great sages, ancestors, and gods, having bestowed all [his duties] upon his son, he resides relying on their support.

sloka: ekākī cintayennityaṃ vivikte hitaṃ ātmanaḥ | ekākī cintayāno hi paraṃ śreyo'dhigacchati |
translation: Meditating alone continuously in solitude, one finds what is beneficial for oneself; meditating alone, indeed, is the means to attain the highest good.

sloka: satsaṅgācchanakaiḥ saṅgaṃ ātmajāyātmajādiṣu | vimuñcen mucyamāneṣu svayaṃ svapnavadutthitaḥ ||
translation: Emerging on one's own like in a dream, one should abandon attachment to son, daughter, and other close relatives that arise from constant good company.

sloka: siddhairyajñāvaśiṣṭārthaiḥ kalpayed vṛttimātmanaḥ | śeṣe svatvaṃ tyajan prājñaḥ padavīṃ mahatāmiyāt ||
translation: The wise one should establish the means of livelihood for himself with the remaining (after performing) ritual offerings and accomplishments. Only then should he renounce individual ownership of even that (means of livelihood). This is the path of the great-souled ones.

sloka: eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram ||
translation: Bathing, chanting, performing fire rituals, and observing vows are dedicated to gods, brahmins, and ancestors when offered.

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ || ||
translation: Striving for what is beneficial, one should frequently resort to these places. For, righteousness, which yields the fruit of a thousand sacrifices, is conducive to the welfare of people.

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ ||
translation: A virtuous person who desires what is auspicious should frequently resort to these places, for dharma is the source of thousands of fruits for people.

sloka: ye śāstravidhimutsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ | teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvamāho rajastamaḥ ||
translation: Those who worship without adhering to scriptural rules, endowed with faith, what is their resolve, Krishna? Is it of sattva, raja, or tama?

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā | sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: Faith in beings is of three kinds, and it arises naturally; it can be sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic – listen to their descriptions.

sloka: sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata | śraddhāmayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yacchraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
translation: The faith of everyone, O Bharata, conforms to their predominant guna (quality). Indeed, this person is nothing but the embodiment of the faith that he holds.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: In the presence of happiness, the mode of goodness (sattva) becomes active, O Bharata. When engaged in actions, the mode of passion (raja) manifests, and when there is delusion, the mode of ignorance (tama) predominates.

sloka: yaḥ śāstravidhimutsṛjya vartate kāmakārataḥ | na sa siddhimavāpnoti na sukhaṃ na parāṃ gatim || tasmācchāstraṃ pramāṇaṃ te kāryākāryavyavasthitau | jñātvā śāstravidhānoktaṃ karma kartumihārhasi ||
translation: One who abandons scriptural rules and acts according to his own desires does not attain success, happiness, or the highest goal. Therefore, scripture is your authority in determining what ought and ought not to be done. Having known what is prescribed by scriptural rules, you should be eager to perform such action.

sloka: aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṃkārasaṃyuktāḥ kāmarāgabalānvitāḥ || karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ | māṃ caivāntaḥśarīrasthaṃ tānviddhyāsuraniścayān ||
translation: Those who practise austerities, which are not in accordance with the scriptures, are driven by arrogance and desire, and torment not only their own physical constituents but also me, who reside within them. Know them to be of demonic resolve.

sloka: āhārastvapi sarvasya trividho bhavati priyaḥ | yajñastapastathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedamimaṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: The nourishment (āhāra) for all is of three kinds and is dear to everyone. Likewise, there are also three types of yajña (sacrifice), tapa (austerity), and dāna (charity). Listen to their distinction.

sloka: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇāstena vedāśca yajñāśca vihitāḥ purā ||
translation: The threefold definition of Brahman, "om tatsad," has been mentioned. In the past, Vedas and sacrifices have been established by Brahmins who follow this.

sloka: tasmādomityudāhṛtya yajñadānatapaḥkriyāḥ | pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṃ brahmavādinām || tadityanabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajñatapaḥkriyāḥ | dānakriyāśca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣakāṅkṣibhiḥ || sadbhāve sādhubhāve ca sadityetatprayujyate | praśaste karmaṇi tathā sacchabdaḥ pārtha yujyate || yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ saditi cocyate | karma caiva tadarthīyaṃ sadityevābhidhīyate ||
translation: Having established "om" as the precondition, the rituals of sacrifice, charity, and austerity, as prescribed, are continually performed by Brahma-scholars. Relinquishing the thought of rewards from sacrifices, austerities, and charitable acts, as well as various other kinds of giving, are performed by those who seek liberation. The word "sat" is used in both the presence and absence of goodness, O Partha, and it is also used to describe steadfastness in rituals such as sacrifice, austerity, and charity, as well as actions aimed at that (ultimate) goal.

sloka: aśraddhayā hutaṃ dattaṃ tapastaptaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat | asadityucyate pārtha na ca tatpretya no iha ||
translation: Offered without faith, given, austerities performed, and actions done – all that is called Asadita, O Partha; it does not persist in the next world nor in this one.

sloka: sa hovāca pitaraṃ tata kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti
translation: Then he asked his father, "To whom should I offer (or hand over) myself?"

sloka: tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: This fire will be known by your name; take this one-formed (identical) firebrand.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū |
translation: Triñāchêtas, who has mastered the three types of knowledge, surpasses the cycle of birth and death through his performance of the three actions.

sloka: yaddurangatha bhavathi yachasyam bhutani gachati
translation: That which moves apart and that by which beings move.

sloka: pasunamehabhavati yathasma deva
translation: Like gods, animals also have life (consciousness).

sloka: gavamsuryaha paro guruhu
translation: The supreme teacher of cows and the sun.

sloka: atrā guru śabdha karanamaci
translation: The meaning of "guru" here is the cause of the word/sound.

sloka: nanavarnakrtini ca
translation: Having various colors and forms.

sloka: lokāḥ samastāḥ sukhino bhavantu |
translation: May all beings in the world be happy and peaceful.

sloka: tadyaddūrvā bhavatyoṣadhīnāmevāsmiṃstatkṣatraṃ dadhātyatho pratiṣṭhāmetāni ha vai
translation: I am indeed the one who makes the earth a resting place for plants and also establishes the rulership (of society); truly, I am.

sloka: ṛgbhyo jātaṃ vaiśyaṃ varṇamāhuḥ | yajurvedaṃ kṣatriyasyāhuryonim | sāmavedo brāhmaṇānāṃ prasūtiḥ |
translation: The vaishya class is born from the rgbhus (the modes of material nature). The Yajurveda is the traditional text for the kshatriyas, while the Samaveda is the origin of the brāhmaṇas.

sloka: brahma vā idamagra āsīt| ekameva tadekaṃ sanna vyabhavattacchreyo rūpamatyasṛjata kṣatraṃ yānyetāni devatrā kṣatrāṇīndro varuṇaḥ somo rudraḥ parjanyo yamo mṛtyurīśāna iti |
translation: In the beginning, Brahman alone existed; from that singular, unique essence, manifested the auspicious form of supreme authority, along with the various deities such as Indra, Varuna, Soma, Rudra, Parjanya, Yama, and Mrtyu.

sloka: sa śaudraṃ varṇamasṛjata pūṣaṇamiyaṃ vai pūṣeyaṃ hīdaṃ sarvaṃ puṣyati yadidaṃ kiṃ ca|
translation: Pushan, the god, is the one who created the sudra varna and causes everything here, including whatever it is, to grow.

sloka: udāttaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vidyānnīcaṃ kṣatriyameva ca| vaiśyaṃ tu svaritaṃ vidyād bhāradvājamudāttakam | nīcaṃ gautamamityāhurgārgyaṃ ca svaritaṃ viduḥ |
translation: A brāhmaṇa is to be recognized by his uddātta (high pitched) tone, a kṣatriya by his udatta-svarita (rising and falling) tone, a vaiśya by his svarita (falling and then rising) tone, and Gautama or Bhāradvāja by their nīca (low pitch) tone.

sloka: svarāstu brāhmaṇā jñeyā vargāṇāṃ prathamāśca ye dvitīyāśca tṛtīyāśca caturthāścāpi bhūmipāḥ
translation: The brāhmaṇa's voice is to be recognized as the foremost among the four classes, being the first, second, third, and also the fourth.

sloka: vargāṇāṃ pañcamā vaiśyā antasthāśca tathaiva ca ūṣmāṇaśca hakāraśca śūdrā eva prakīrtitāḥ
translation: The fifth among the social classes is known as the Vaisyas, who are situated in the middle, and so are the Hakaras (letter 'H') and those characterized by heat. The Sudras are likewise renowned.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ| tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam||
translation: The four-class system was created by me, based on qualities and actions; still, know me to be its imperishable creator.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The brahmin was born from his mouth, the ruler from his arms, the vaishya from his thighs, and the shudra from his feet.

sloka: brahma vai svaṃ mahimānaṃ brāhmaṇeṣvadadhād adhyayanaadhyāpanayajanayājanadānapratigrahasaṃyuktaṃ vedānāṃ guptyai ||
translation: For the protection of the Vedas, a brahmana should appropriately impart and receive teaching, study, procreation, procreation sacrifice, gift, and acceptance of gifts through their own self-expansion (i.e., realizing their true nature).

sloka: kṣatre balam adhyayanayajanadānaśastrakośabhūtarakṣaṇasaṃyuktaṃ kṣatrasya vṛddhyai ||
translation: The strength (of a Kshatriya) is associated with learning, ritual sacrifices, charity, scriptural knowledge, and the protection of treasures for the enhancement of the Kshatriyas.

sloka: viṭsv adhyayanayajanadānakṛṣivāṇijyapaśupālanasaṃyuktaṃ karmaṇāṃ vṛddhyai ||
translation: Engaging in agriculture, studying, performing fire sacrifices, giving, trading, and protecting animals, all for the purpose of growth.

sloka: śūdreṣu pūrveṣāṃ paricaryām ||
translation: The duty of serving (paricarya) in the earlier generations was assigned to the shudras (shudresu).

sloka: sarvasyāsya tu sargasya guptyarthaṃ sa mahādyutiḥ | mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ pṛthakkarmāṇyakalpayat |
translation: For the protection of all that is born, He of great brilliance has ordained separate actions for those with mouths, arms, and legs.

sloka: brāhmaṇānāṃ sito varṇaḥ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu lohitaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ pītako varṇaḥ śūdrāṇāmasitastathā ||
translation: The color of Brahmins is white, that of Kshatriyas is red, and that of Vaishyas is yellow, while that of Shudras is black.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ
translation: The four-class system was created by me, based on qualities and actions.

sloka: brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśāṃ śūdrāṇāṃ ca parantapa | karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāvaprabhavairguṇaiḥ ||
translation: The duties of the brāhmaṇa, kṣatriya, and vaiśya, as well as of the śūdra, are determined by their inherent qualities.

sloka: viprakṣatriyaviṭśūdrā mukhabāhūrupādajāḥ | vairājāt puruṣāt jātā ya ātmācāralakṣaṇāḥ ||
translation: Born from a brahmin, kshatriya, vaishya, or shudra mother and father, yet possessing unchanging self-characteristics.

sloka: na yonirnāpi saṃskāro na śrutaṃ na ca saṃtatiḥ | kāraṇāni dvijatvasya vṛttameva tu kāraṇam ||
translation: The causes of being a twice-born are not one's birth, upbringing, study, or lineage; but one's conduct alone.

sloka: brāhmaḥ svabhāvaḥ suśroṇiḥ samaḥ sarvatra me matiḥ | nirguṇaṃ nirmalaṃ brahma yatra tiṣṭhati sa dvijaḥ ||
translation: A Brahmin is naturally courteous, impartial, and has equanimity everywhere. That twice-born (dvija) is established in the pure, attributeless Brahman.

sloka: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svadharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ ||
translation: It is better to perform one's own duty (svadharma) imperfectly than to perform another's perfectly. Dying while performing one's own duty brings prosperity, while performing another's duty leads to danger.

sloka: etaiḥ karmaphalairdevi nyūnajātikulodbhavaḥ| śūdro'pyāgamasampanno dvijo bhavati saṃskṛtaḥ ||
translation: Even a person born in a low family becomes a Brahmin if endowed with scriptural knowledge, surpassing the fruit of actions.

sloka: nityakarmānuṣṭhānāddharmotpattirdharmotpatteḥ pāpahānistataścittaśuddhiḥ |
translation: From regular performance of duties arises religious merit, and from such religious merit comes the eradication of sin and the purification of the mind.

sloka: brāhmaṇyaṃ devi duṣprāpaṃ nisargāt brāhmaṇaḥ śubhe | kṣatriyo vaiśyaśūdrau vā nisargāditi me matiḥ ||
translation: The attainment of Brahminhood is difficult to achieve by nature, in my opinion. Whether it's a Kshatriya, Vaishya, or Shudra, they naturally have their respective roles.

sloka: ete yoniphalā devi sthānabhāganidarśakāḥ | svayaṃ ca varadenoktā brahmaṇā sṛjatā prajāḥ ||
translation: These, O goddess, are the reproductive fluids that themselves reveal their origin and are created by Brahma and granted (the power to create offspring).

sloka: karmabhiḥ śucibhirdevi śuddhātmā vijitendriyaḥ | śūdro'pi dvijavat sevya iti brahmābravīt svayam ||
translation: Even a shudra, if possessing purity of actions, pure soul, and controlled senses, is worthy of being served just like a dvija (twice-born), as Brahma himself declared.

sloka: svabhāvaḥ karma ca śubhaṃ yatra śūdro'pi tiṣṭhati | viśiṣṭaḥ sa dvijātervai vijñeya iti me matiḥ ||
translation: Where a shudra (social class in Hinduism) resides, possessing good nature and actions, he should be considered superior to a dualja (twice-born, referring to the three upper classes). This is my opinion.

sloka: yasya yallakṣaṇaṃ proktaṃ puṃso varṇābhivyañjakam | yadanyatrāpi dṛśyeta tattenaiva vinirdiśet || ||
translation: Of a person, whose characteristics are described by the markers of caste, if something similar is seen elsewhere, it should be considered as the same.

sloka: yasya yallakṣaṇaṃ proktaṃ puṃso varṇābhivyañjakam | yadanyatrāpi dṛśyeta tattenaiva vinirdiśet ||
translation: Of a person, whose characteristics are described by the markings on their body, if something similar is seen elsewhere, it should be designated as belonging to that same category.

sloka: athavā brāhmaṇasvabhāvasya sattvaguṇaḥ prabhavaḥ kāraṇam tathā kṣatriyasvabhāvasya sattvopasarjanaṃ rajaḥ prabhavaḥ vaiśyasvabhāvasya tamaupasarjanaṃ rajaḥ prabhavaḥ śūdrasvabhāvasya rajaupasarjanaṃ tamaḥ prabhavaḥ praśāntyaiśvaryehāmūḍhatāsvabhāvadarśanāt caturṇām |
translation: Or, the predominance of the sattva guna (quality of purity, knowledge, and harmony) is the cause of the Brāhmaṇa's inherent nature; the emergence of rajo guna (quality of passion, activity, and restlessness) causes the Kṣatriya's inherent nature; the increase in tamo guna (quality of inertia, ignorance, and delusion) results in the Sudrā's inherent nature; and the balance of raja and tama gunas leads to the recognition of the divine nature in all beings.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ saṃtoṣaḥ kṣāṃtirārjavam | mad‍bhaktiśca dayā satyaṃ brahmaprakṛtayastvimāḥ || || tejo balaṃ dhṛtiḥ śauryaṃ titikṣaudāryamudyamaḥ | sthairyaṃ brahmaṇyataiśvaryaṃ kṣatra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || || āstikyaṃ dānaniṣṭhā ca adaṃbho brahmasevanam | atuṣṭiḥ arthopacayaiḥ vaiśya prakṛtayastvimāḥ || || śuśrūṣaṇaṃ dvijagavāṃ devānāṃ cāpi amāyayā | tatra labdhena saṃtoṣaḥ śūdra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || ||
translation:
Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, contentment, forgiveness, piety, compassion, and truthfulness are the inherent qualities of a Brahmana.
Power, strength, courage, fortitude, patience, and heroism are the inherent qualities of a Kshatriya.
Faith, charity, sincerity, humility, and service to Brahmins without any ulterior motive, and pleasure from serving others with what one has acquired legitimately are the inherent qualities of a Vaisya.
Dutifulness, respect for elders, and cleanliness are the inherent qualities of a Shudra.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ saṃtoṣaḥ kṣāṃtirārjavam | mad‍bhaktiśca dayā satyaṃ brahmaprakṛtayastvimāḥ || tejo balaṃ dhṛtiḥ śauryaṃ titikṣaudāryamudyamaḥ | sthairyaṃ brahmaṇyataiśvaryaṃ kṣatra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || āstikyaṃ dānaniṣṭhā ca adaṃbho brahmasevanam | atuṣṭiḥ arthopacayaiḥ vaiśya prakṛtayastvimāḥ || śuśrūṣaṇaṃ dvijagavāṃ devānāṃ cāpi amāyayā | tatra labdhena saṃtoṣaḥ śūdra prakṛtayastvimāḥ ||
translation: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, contentment, forgiveness, piety, compassion, and truthfulness are the divine qualities; courage, power, determination, patience, and stamina are the royal qualities. Faith, generosity, kindness, modesty, service to Brahmins, gratitude for wealth, and sincere service to elders and deities with devoid of selfishness - these are the qualities of the mercantile class. The ability to fulfill duties towards superiors selflessly is the quality of the servant class.

sloka: brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyo vaiśyastrayo varṇā dvijātayaḥ | caturtha ekajātistu śūdro nāsti tu pañcamaḥ |
translation: The four social classes are the Brahmin, Kshatriya, and Vaishya, all of whom are twice-born. The fourth is a single caste, the Shudra; there is no fifth.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: In the case of a Kshatriya, self-control, steadfastness, asceticism, cleanliness, forbearance, honesty, knowledge, realization, and acting in accordance with Brahmanical duties are natural. For a Vaisya, agriculture, tending to cows, trade, and lending money are natural. The natural duty of a Shudra consists of service-oriented tasks.

sloka: sve sve karmaṇyabhirataḥ saṃsiddhiṃ labhate naraḥ | svakarmanirataḥ siddhiṃ yathā vindati tacchṛṇu ||
translation: A person attains success in their own respective duties, hear how one finds success through being devoted to their own duty.

sloka: yaḥ kaścidātmānamadvitīyaṃ jātiguṇakriyāhīnaṃ ṣaḍūrmiṣaḍbhāvetyādisarvadoṣarahitaṃ satyajñānānandānantasvarūpaṃ svayaṃ nirvikalpamaśeṣakalpādhāraśeṣabhūtāntaryāmitvena vartamānamantaryahiścākāśavadanusyūtamakhaṇḍānandasvabhāvamaprameyamanubhavaikavedyamaparokṣatayā bhāsamānaṃ karatalamalakavatsākṣādaparokṣīkṛtya kṛtārthatayā kāmarāgādidoṣarahitaḥ śamadamādisampanno bhāvamātsaryatṛṣṇāśāmohādirahito dambhāhaṅkāradibhirasaṃspṛṣṭacetā vartata evamuktalakṣaṇo yaḥ sa eva brāhmaṇeti śrutismṛtītihāsapurāṇānāmabhiprāyaḥ | anyathā hi brāhmaṇatvasiddhirnāstyeva |
translation: The one who, being the undivided Self, devoid of other-ness, birth, qualities, and actions; free from all defects such as false knowledge, etc., possessing the nature of absolute truth, consciousness, and bliss; illuminating oneself and others without any support, like the ether, with a form made of a handful of bliss; who is directly and indirectly experienced as the limitless experience, yet inconceivable; whose true nature is not known through any other means, except by the mark of being free from desire, anger, etc., tranquility, self-control, etc., devoid of miserliness, envy, delusion, pride, etc.; and whose mind does not get tainted with false identifications such as arrogance, egoism, etc.—such a one is indeed called a brahmana according to the conclusion of shruti, smriti, itihasa, purana texts. Otherwise, the establishment of brahmanahood would not be possible.

sloka: adhyāpanaṃ adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānāṃ akalpayat | prajānāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānaṃ ijyādhyayanaṃ eva ca | viṣayeṣvaprasaktiśca kṣatriyasya samāsataḥ | paśūnāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānaṃ ijyādhyayanaṃ eva ca | vaṇikpathaṃ kusīdaṃ ca vaiśyasya kṛṣiṃ eva ca | ekaṃ eva tu śūdrasya prabhuḥ karma samādiśat | eteṣāṃ eva varṇānāṃ śuśrūṣāṃ anasūyayā | sarvaṃ svaṃ brāhmaṇasyedaṃ yatkiṃ cijjagatīgatam | śraiṣṭhyenābhijanenedaṃ sarvaṃ vai brāhmaṇo'rhati |
translation: Of the four social classes, it is declared that the primary duty of a brahmin is to teach and study (adhyapanam, adhyayanam), perform rituals (yajana, yajana), give (dana), accept gifts (pratigraha), protect subjects (prajannam raksanam), and engage in impartial service (susrusam anasuyaya). The kshatriya's main duties are to protect (pashunam raksanam), donate, perform rituals, and study. The primary duty of a vaisya is agriculture (krishi), trade (vanikpatham), and tending to cattle (kusidam). A sudra has one lord and duty, which is to follow the instructions of the other three classes. All these duties and objects in the world are appropriately deserved by the brahmin through his superior birth.

sloka: paṇiḥ vaṇik bhavati |paṇiḥ paṇanāt | vaṇik paṇyaṃ nenekti |
translation: A trader becomes a thief if he doesn't follow fair trading practices.

sloka: kadū mahīradhṛṣṭā asya taviṣīḥ kadu vṛtraghno astṛtam | indro viśvānbekanāṭā~ ahardṛśa uta kratvā paṇī~rabhi ||
translation: When will the earth-shaker (Indra), who is unrivaled in strength and valor, ever be shaken himself? Indeed, he is the one who supports all beings with his power.

sloka: vadhīrhi dasyuṃ dhaninaṃ ghanena~ ekaścarannupaśākebhirindra | dhanoradhi viṣuṇakte vyāyannayajvānaḥ sanakāḥ pretimīyuḥ ||
translation: Indra, alone and with just a single stroke of his thunderbolt, strikes down the wealthy demon; meanwhile, Sanaka and others, always engaged in meditation and sacrifice, attain devotion.

sloka: saṃ vāṃ karmaṇā samiṣā hinomīndrāviṣṇū apasaspāre asya | juṣethāṃ yajñaṃ draviṇaṃ ca dhattamariṣṭairnaḥ pathibhi: pārayantā ||
translation: Together with you, I am wasting away by this misdeed, O Indra and Vishnu; those who are deserving should enjoy the ritual offering and wealth. Let not those who are undeserving reach them.

sloka: māsebhyaḥ pitṛlokaṃ pitṛlokādākāśamākāśāccandramasameṣa somo rājā taddevānāmannaṃ taṃ devā bhakṣayanti ||
translation: The moon, king Soma, consumes the offerings from the new moon to the full moon; to the moon-world it goes, and from there to the sky, which the gods then consume.

sloka: māsebhyaḥ pitṛlokaṃ pitṛlokādākāśamākāśāccandramasameṣa somo rājā taddevānāmannaṃ taṃ devā bhakṣayanti ||
translation: The moon, king Soma, consumes the offerings from the new moon to the full moon; to the sky from the world of fathers; and from the sky to the moon itself, the gods partake that.

sloka: apāma somamamṛtā abhūmāganma jyotiravidāma devān | kiṃ nūnamasmānkṛṇavadarātiḥ kimu dhūrtiramṛta martyasya ||
translation: We have drunk the Soma, we have become immortal, we have approached the light, we have known the Gods. What injury, what hostility can there be for the mortal now?

sloka: tasyāśitādyādāhārādbalaṃ varṇaśca vardhate yasyartusātmyaṃ viditaṃ ceṣṭāhāravyapāśrayam
translation: The strength and complexion of one who has identified the self with the body increases with each intake of food, starting from "aśitā."

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: Acquires a long life, memory, intelligence, good health, youthfulness, strength, radiance, physical beauty, and excellence in speech; not through medicinal herbs or elixirs, but only through respecting and following the guidance of the wise.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The one who is established in the foremost duty of performing prescribed sacrifices and hospitality to guests, according to tradition, is remembered as ṛtvik. Neglecting this duty can lead to quick onset of disease due to lack of harmony with natural order.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The one who is established in the fore-mentioned duties of the seasons, etc., is remembered as ṛtvantyādisaptasandhiri. Among them, the first one, vidhi, should be performed; offerings should be made to him. Otherwise, diseases arising from improper conduct may occur suddenly due to giving up (tyāga) of those duties.

sloka: yad ṛtviyād asṛjat tad ṛtūnāṃ ṛtutvam |
translation: What was created by the sacrificial rite, that is the true nature of the seasons.

sloka: ṛtusandhiṣu vyādhayaḥ jāyante ṛtusandhiṣu yajñāḥ kriyante|
translation: Diseases are born in the transition periods of seasons, and sacrifices are performed.
